DT Article
TI A new species of Petaloptila from the province of Malaga (Spain)
   (Orthoptera, Gryllidae).
FT Una nueva especie de Petaloptila de la provincia de Malaga (Espana).
   (Orthoptera, Gryllidae).
AU Barranco, Pablo (pbvega@ual.es) 
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 34
IS 1-2
PS 207-217
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Petaloptila (Zapetaloptila) is described from several
   caves in the province of Malaga (Spain). This new species is very close
   to P. (Z.) barrancoi Gorochov y Llorente, 2001 from the Gador mountains
   range in Almera (Spain). Both species differ in the male genitalia
   shape, which is studied by SEM. The biometric parameters separate one
   species from the other, the species from Almera being larger.
C1 Barranco, Pablo; Dpto. Biologia Aplicada, Cite II-B, Universidad de
   Almeria, 04120 Almeria, Spain, Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR14707054372
DT Article
TI Amendments to the Catalogue of Palearctic Coleoptera Bruchinae of Loebl
   & Smetana (2010) (Coleoptera: Bruchidae).
FT Correcciones al Catalogo de Coleopteros Bruchinae Palearticos de Loebl &
   Smetana (2010) (Coleoptera: Bruchidae).
AU Ramos, Rafael Yus (rafayus@telefonica.net) 
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 34
IS 1-2
PS 219-234
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper presents the results of a review of the recently published
   Palearctic Catalogue of Coleoptera of LOEBL & SMETANA (2010), in the
   particular case of bruchids (volume 6: Chrysomeloidea: Bruchinae). As a
   result, 68 amendments have been proposed, most of which (57) correspond
   to the inclusion of Palaearctic localities, mainly in Spain (SP),
   Portugal (PT), Morocco (MO), and the Canary Islands (CI), as well as
   some Central European countries, which have not recorded certain
   species, perhaps because the authors of this catalogue were unaware of
   the publications containing these records. Other amendments are due to
   synonyms (7), or species that have not been included in the Palaearctic
   fauna (4). Finally, we propose a new code not listed in that catalogue,
   to comment on the questionable or unproven character of some references,
   using a question mark(?).
C1 Ramos, Rafael Yus; Urbanizacion "El Jardn" no 22, 29700 Velez-Malaga,
   Spain, Spain.
EM rafayus@telefonica.net
SC Zoology
SN 0210-8984
BD Documentation; Publications; Land zones
DE Bruchinae [Catalogues / Amendments to catalogue / Systematics]
   [Palaearctic region /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Bruchidae
OR Bruchinae (Bruchidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14707054372

   of Oman, Arabian Peninsula (Coleoptera: Bruchidae).
FT Caryedon omanensis nov. sp., una nueva especie para la fauna de
   bruquidos del Sultanato de Oman, Peninsula Arabiga (Coleoptera:
   Bruchidae).
AU Yus Ramos, Rafael (rafayus@telefonica.net) 
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 34
IS 3-4
PS 257-265
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe the male and female of Caryedon omanensis, a new species of
   tribe Caryedontini, subfamily Pachymerinae (Coleoptera: Bruchidae) found
   in the Sultanate of Oman (Arabian Peninsula), of acaciae group, and near
   Caryedon yemenensis Decelle, 1979. In addition to the description of
   both sexes, a key is provided to differentiate between the two species
   using the external morphology and the genitalia of the male and female.

AB Illinoia morrisoni, Neuquenaphis bulbicauda and N. essigi (Hemiptera
   Aphididae) are corded for first time in Argentina, caught on Cupressus
   sempervirens and Nothofagus sp. New records for Argentina of another 3
   Neuquenaphis species are given, with new data on the geographic
   distribution and host plants of these species. The color when alive, the
   place of the plant on which they feed, and the way of life of four
   Neuquenaphis species are presented for first time.

DT Article
TI Zophoscolex albacetensis sp. nov. A new species of earthworm from
   Albacete, Spain (Annelida, Oligochaeta).
FT Zophoscolex albacetensis sp. nov. Una nueva especie de lombriz de tierra
   procedente de Albacete, Espana (Annelida, Oligochaeta).
AU Perez-Onteniente, Antonio
   Rodriguez-Babio, Celso
SO Boletin de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural Seccion
   Biologica
VL 104
IS 1-4
PS 29-33
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on the results of a research about earthworm in the province of
   Albacete (Castilla-La Mancha, Spain) a description of a new species
   Zophoscolex albacetensis has been carried out. Its inclusion in the
   genus Zophoscolex Qiu & Bouche, 1998 is due to the presence of double
   spermathecae in the segments 9 and 10, the location of the gizzard in
   the 18-19 segments and the presence of expansions of the Morren's gland
   in the segments 13-14 amongst other characteristics. The most related
   species would be: Zophoscolex (Zophoscolex) micella (Bouche, 1972), Z.
   (Z.) graffr (Bouche, 1972), Z. (Z.) zhongi Qiu & Bouche, 1998 and Z.
   (Aquilonibericus) aragonensis Qiu & Bouche, 1998, distinguished clearly
   of them by the location of clitellus an the tubercula pubertatis.
C1 Perez-Onteniente, Antonio; Departament de Zoologia, Facultat de Ciencies
   Biologiques, Universitat de Valencia, 46100 Burjassot (Valencia), Spain,
   Spain.
SC Zoology
SN 0366-3272
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Zophoscolex albacetensis [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta
OR Zophoscolex - Qiu & Bouche 1998 (Oligochaeta): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, Species differentiation, p. 32]. 
   Zophoscolex albacetensis (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 30].

IS 1-4
PS 97-105
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB Holotrochus hispanicus is described of the province of Valencia, Spain
   with specimens collected in pitfall traps in citrus groves.
   Gender-dominated Holotrochus neotropical species. On the structure of
   the aedeagus the nearest species is H. acromyrmicis Bernhauer, 1921
   described from Argentina. His behavior is described of thanatosis of
   defense, consisting of the way of gathering the legs.

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of decapod crustaceans are described from upper Albian
   sediments of Central Iran. The small mecochirid lobster Huhatanka
   iranica n. sp. represents the second species of this genus, previously
   known from the Albian of Kansas, USA. Callianassa sensu lato is reported
   as an associated crustacean.

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027250
DT Article
TI On some Panamerican Cretaceous crabs (Decapoda: Raninoida).
AU Vega, Francisco J. (vegver@servidor.unam.mx) 
   Nyborg, Torrey
   Kovalchuk, Greg
   Luque, Javier
   Rojas-Briceno, Alexis
   Patarroyo, Pedro
   Porras-Muzquiz, Hector
   Armstrong, Adam
   Bermudez, Hermann
   Garibay, Luis
SO Boletin de la Sociedad Geologica Mexicana
VL 62
IS 2
PS 263-279
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://boletinsgm.igeolcu.unam.mx/igl/index.php?option=com_content&view=
   article&id=402:6202&catid=149:epoca4&Itemid=74
AW http://boletinsgm.igeolcu.unam.mx/epoca04/6202/(6)Vega.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Decapod crustacean specimens recently collected from new and previously
   reported localities of USA, Mexico, and Colombia, as well as a review of
   species of uncertain affinity, add important information to complete the
   descriptions and paleobiological knowledge of some Cretaceous primitive
   crabs. The stratigraphic range for the genus Cenomanocarcinus is
   formally extended from the upper Albian to Campanian, based on
   occurrences from Colombia, Oklahoma and Mexico. Specimens of
   Cenomanocarcinus vanstraeleni from the Turonian of Mexico and Colombia
   include features not described previously for this species, such as
   variation in the shape and ornament of chelae. Necrocarcinus renfroae is
   here included in the genus Cenomanocarcinus, based on features of dorsal
   and ventral carapaces, as well as shape of pereiopods, and its
   occurrence is documented from the upper Albian of Colombia. Orithopsis
   tricarinata is reported for the first time in America from upper Albian
   deposits of Oregon and Colombia; the shape of the sternum confirms close
   affinities with the Cenomanocarcinidae and the family Orithopsidae is
   here included in the section Raninoida and restricted to the genus
   Orithopsis.
C1 Vega, Francisco J.; Instituto de Geologia, UNAM, Ciudad Universitaria,
   Coyoacan, Mexico, DF 04510, Mexico, Mexico.
EM vegver@servidor.unam.mx

   Alexis/0000-0002-1063-9102; Luque, Javier/0000-0002-4391-5951; Bermudez,
   Hermann/0000-0003-0656-2007
SC Zoology
SN 1405-3322
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Description; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical

PT J
AN ZOOR14707053624
DT Article
TI [New species of Phymaturus ("palluma" group) for the central Cordillera
   zone of Chile (Reptilia, Sauria, Liolaemidae).]
FT NUEVAS ESPECIES DE PHYMATURUS (GRUPO "PALLUMA") PARA LA ZONA
   CORDILLERANA CENTRAL DE CHILE (REPTILIA, SAURIA, LIOLAEMIDAE).
AU Nunez, Herman (hnunez@mnhn.cl) 
   Veloso, Alberto
   Espejo, Pablo
   Veloso, Claudio
   Cortes, Arturo
   Araya, Sergio
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Chile
VL 59
PS 41-74
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe four new species of the Phymaturus genus, within the
   "palluma" group. They inhabit the Andean range, above 1,500 m, from
   Coquimbo to El Maule administrative regions. These descriptions include
   morphological and osteological features, we remarks the existence of an
   autapomorphy related to the lacking of incisive process in those
   populations from El Maule region. These descriptions increase from two
   to six the species belonging to Phymaturus genus; probably this number
   is still underestimated due to the singular topography of the occidental
   slope of the Andean range. We propose the radiation of this genus as a
   consequence of the changing state due to Pleistocenic glaciations
   occurring in the area, resulting in the geographic isolation of lizards
   populations living in the high Andes. We discuss the particular response
   of Phymaturus, with Liolaemus (Liolaemidae) species living at present in
   the same high andean habitats.
C1 Nunez, Herman; Museo Nacional de Historia Natural, Santiago, Chile,
   Chile.
EM hnunez@mnhn.cl
SC Zoology
SN 0027-3910
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Phymaturus [Chile /  / Key to species]. 
   Phymaturus alicahuense; Phymaturus darwini; Phymaturus maulense;
   Phymaturus paihuanense [Chile /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Phymaturus - Gravenhorst 1838 (Iguanidae): [Key to species, Chile, P.
   69]. 
   Phymaturus alicahuense (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 51]. 
   Phymaturus darwini (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 43]. 
   Phymaturus maulense (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 63]. 
   Phymaturus paihuanense (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 58].

DT Article
TI Review of the Chinese subgenus Circinatus of Pterostichus, with
   description of six new species (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Allegro, Gianni (gianni.allegro@entecra.it) 
   Sciaky, Riccardo
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 34
PS 3-18
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Six new Chinese species of Pterostichus belonging to the subgenus
   Circinatus Sciaky, 1996 are described: P. dentifer n. sp., P. cavazzutii
   n. sp., P. bullatus n. sp., P. agilis n. sp. and P. xilingensis n. sp.
   from Sichuan, P. wenxianensis n. sp. from Gansu. Moreover, new data on
   the distribution and the aedeagal morphology of the seven species of
   Circinatus previously known are provided. Basing on aedeagal features
   and particularly on the armature of endophallus, three species groups
   are recognized within the subgenus.
C1 Allegro, Gianni; CRA-PLF unita di Ricerca per le Produzioni Legnose
   Fuori Foresta, Casale Monferrato, Allwsandria, Melan, Italy, Italy.
EM gianni.allegro@entecra.it

TI Thamiaraeini, Lomechusini, Oxypodini, Hoplandriini and Aleocharini from
   Taiwan (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
FT Thamiaraeini, Lomechusini, Oxypodini, Hoplandriini e Aleocharini di
   Taiwan (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 34
PS 19-54
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper 23 genera of which 16 new for Taiwan (Thamiaraea,
   Mimacrotona, Pseudatheta, Eutaenoglossa, Orphnebius, Tetrabothrus,
   Ischnopoda, Amarochara, Apimela, Parapimela, Homoeusa, Smetanaetha,
   Ocyusa, Hygropetrophila, Oxypoda, Tetrasticta) and 3 new for the science
   (Zyratheta, Pselaphoykodes, Taiwanusa) and 58 species of which 46
   described as new for the science, are recognized. The keys of the
   species of Taiwan of 5 genera (Tetrabothrus, Smetanaetha,
   Hygropetrophila, Oxypoda, Pseudoplandria) are given. The comparisons are
   accomplished generally on typical material examined by the author. Every
   new species and every new genus is illustrated.

TI Two new taxa of Eocene rabbitfishes (Perciformes, Siganidae) from the
   North Caucasus (Russia), with redescription of Acanthopygaeus agassizi
   (Eastman) from Monte Bolca (Italy) and a phylogenetic analysis of the
   family.
AU Bannikov, Alexandre F. (aban@paleo.ru) 
   Tyler, James C.
   Sorbini, Chiara
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 34
PS 3-21
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new genera and species of siganid rabbitfishes (Caucasiganus
   eocaenicus and Lagosiganus parinterneuralis) are described from the
   uppermost Middle Eocene locality of Gorny Luch in the North Caucasus,
   S.W. Russia, and the holotype of Acanthopygaeus agassizi (Eastman, 1904)
   from the Eocene of Monte Bolca, Italy, is redescribed and referred to
   the Siganidae. A phylogenetic analysis is presented of the relationships
   of the eight genera now known of fossil siganids and of the single
   extant genus.

DT Article
TI The Cretaceous fishes of Nardo. 32[degree]. Three new Perciformes:
   Zorzinperca weverberghi gen. and sp. nov., Johnsonperca annavaccarii
   gen. and sp. nov. and Bannikovperca apula gen. and sp. nov. (Teleostei,
   Percomorpha).
FT Les poissons cretaces de Nardo. 32[degree]. Trois nouveaux Perciformes:
   Zorzinperca weverberghi gen. et sp. nov., Johnsonperca annavaccarii gen.
   et sp. nov. et Bannikovperca apula gen. et sp. nov. (Teleostei,
   Percomorpha).
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 34
PS 51-80
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new perciform genera are described in the Campano-Maastrichtian
   marine ichthyofauna of Nardo (Apulia, southern Italy). The first one,
   Zorzinperca weverberghi gen. and sp. nov., belongs to the family
   Nardoichthyidae. It differs from Nardoichthys francisci by its short
   frontal, its very large supraoccipital, its supraoccipital crest forming
   a marked angle with the frontal profile, its premaxilla with a short
   oral branch, its large opercle, its four long branchiostegal rays, its
   very short hyoidean bar, its posttemporal not very enlarged ventrally,
   its predorsal formula 0/0/0 + 1/1/1 and its small scales. The caudal
   skeleton of the two genera is similar and highly specialized, with a
   complete neural spine on the second preural centrum, the loss of the
   stegural and the uroneurals, the fused hypurals forming two broad plates
   attached to the terminal vertebra and the parhypural fused to the
   ventral hypural plate. But Zorzinperca possesses a single epural while
   Nardoichthys exhibits two epurals. Both genera have a caudal fin with 14
   principal rays. An emended diagnosis is proposed for the
   Nardoichthyidae. The relationships of the family are discussed and
   comparisons are made with some other Cretaceous Perciformes. A
   systematic position within the Percoidei and close to the Nandidae is
   proposed. Only the head and the abdominal region are preserved in the
   second fish, Johnsonperca annavaccarii gen. and sp. nov. The head is as
   deep as long. The maximum depth of the body is equal to the depth of the
   head. The supraoccipital crest is highly developed. The epiotic forms a
   crest getting ahead of the neurocranial posterior face. The jaws bear a
   row of conical teeth. The oral branch of the premaxilla is short, its
   symphyseal ascending process very long, its articular process feebly
   developed and its postmaxillary process present. The preopercle exhibits
   a spiny posterior border and a ventral border devoid of spines. There
   are 7 long branchiostegal rays of which the fourth is the broader. The
   posttemporal is narrow and divided in two branches. The dorsal branch of
   the cleithrum is short and very broad and its ventral branch long,
   narrow and obliquely oriented. The pectoral fin is short and possesses 8
   rays. There are 3 supraneurals. Th e predorsal formula is /0 + 0/0 +
   1/1/1/1. The pelvic fin has I spine and 4 soft rays. The dorsal fin
   begins with at least 4 spines. The scales are small and cycloid. Th is
   new genus is probably a member of the Percoidei and is left family
   incertae sedis. The caudal region is the only part preserved of the
   third genus, Bannikovperca apula gen. and sp. nov. This fossil fish
   exibits 13 caudal vertebrae, a caudal rib, a short anal fin with 3
   spines, an haemanal complex of type II with the first anal pterygiophore
   reaching the axial skeleton, a short neural spine on the second preural
   centrum, 3 epurals, autogenous parhypural and hypurals, the second
   hypural broader than the first one, 2 uroneurals, no procurrent spur and
   19 principal caudal rays. This new genus must probably be ranged within
   the Percoidei and is left family incertae sedis.
C1 Taverne, Louis; Residence "Les Platanes", Boulevard du Souverain 142
   (Boite 8), B-1170 Bruxelles, Belgium, Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8402
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Bannikovperca; Johnsonperca; Zorzinperca [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Bannikovperca apula; Johnsonperca annavaccarii; Zorzinperca weverberghi
   [Italy /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Nardoichthyidae
OR Bannikovperca (Perciformes): [Gen nov, Of suborder Percoidei?, family
   incertae sedis, Type species Bannikovperca apula, p. 63, Cretaceous;
   Fossil]. 
   Bannikovperca apula (Perciformes): [Sp nov, Italy, Cretaceous, P. 63;
   Fossil]. 
   Johnsonperca (Perciformes): [Gen nov, Of suborder Percoidei?, family
   incertae sedis, Type species Johnsonperca annavaccarii, p. 59,
   Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Johnsonperca annavaccarii (Perciformes): [Sp nov, Italy, Cretaceous, P.
   60; Fossil]. 
   Nardoichthyidae (Perciformes): [Emended diagnosis, P. 53; Taxonomic
   position, P. 69]. 
   Zorzinperca (Nardoichthyidae): [Gen nov, Type species Zorzinperca
   weverberghi, p. 53, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Zorzinperca weverberghi (Nardoichthyidae): [Sp nov, Italy, Cretaceous,
   P. 53; Fossil].

AN ZOOR14701000735
DT Article
TI Origin and evolution of the early Silurian (Rhuddanian) virgianid
   pentameride brachiopods - the extinction recovery fauna from Anticosti
   Island, eastern Canada.
AU Jin, Jisuo (jjin@uwo.ca) 
   Copper, Paul
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 49
IS 1
PS 1-11
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Discovery of a suite of post-mass extinction virgianid brachiopods fawn
   the basal Silurian Becscie Formation of Anticosti Island demonstrates
   either that the Virgiana lineage originated from Brevilamnulella, or
   that the two lineages were sister groups. Gradational modifications are
   observed in a morphoseries from the Hirnantian genus Brevilamnulella, to
   the early Rhuddanian genus Viridita, and then to the middle-late
   Rhuddanian genus Virgiana. Four main evolutionary trends were
   ascertained: 1) adult shell size changed from < 15 nun to about 30 Mill
   in length, and the shell outline from slightly transverse or
   equidimensional to markedly elongate, with a profile from nearly
   equibiconvex to strongly ventribiconvex; 2) the ventral umbo changed
   from low and narrow (1-2 mm above hinge line), with a suberect beak, to
   high, obtuse, and galeate, with a strongly incurved beak; 3) the shell
   surface is smooth in Brevilamnulella the besensis, becoming quasi-smooth
   to gently costate in Viridita lenticularis, and then moderately costate
   in Viridita glomerosa sp. nov. and Virgiana barrandei; 4) the fold and
   sulcus are absent in Brevilamnulella and also in the early growth stage
   (up to 5 mm length) of Viridita lenticularis; at later growth stages, a
   ventral sulcus and a dorsal fold are developed extending to the anterior
   margin to produce a uniplicate commissure; such a fold and sulcus are
   present only in the early growth stage of Virgiana barrandei. On the
   basis of internal structures, it is also suggested that the Clorinda
   lineage had its origin in Brevilamnulella or Viridita during the late
   Rhuddanian, and became successful mainly in deeper-water; outer-shelf
   environments.
C1 Jin, Jisuo; Univ Western Ontario, Dept Earth Sci, London, ON, Canada,
   Canada.
EM jjin@uwo.ca
OI Jin, Jisuo/0000-0002-6109-7657
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 0375-7633
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Evolutionary adaptation;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; Canada; Geological time
   periods; Palaeozoic
DE Virgianidae [Adaptive radiation /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Quebec /
   Anticosti Island / ] [Silurian / Rhuddanian / ]. 
   Viridita glomerosa [Quebec /  / new species] [Silurian /  / ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda
OR Virgianidae (Brachiopoda): [Fossil]. 
   Viridita glomerosa (Brachiopoda): [Sp nov, Quebec, Silurian, P. 8;
   Fossil].

AN ZOOR14703021571
DT Article
TI Cingolites n. gen., a new lower Toarcian Hildoceratinae (Ammonitina)
   from the Marchean Apennines (Cingoli, Macerata, Italy).
AU Sassaroli, Stefano (dtocsa@tin.it) 
   Venturi, Federico
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 49
IS 2
PS 97-118
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New biostratigraphic data are provided from the Marchean Apennines
   (Marconessa quarry near Cingoli, Macerata Italy) where a lower Jurassic
   outcrop yielded a remakable Toarcian ammonite assemblage, very rich in
   early Hildoceratinae (Ammonitina). The site is historically meaningful,
   because in the past two centuries Italian palaeontologists have figured
   ammonoid specimens from "Marconessa". Here, the nodular limestone and
   grey marl of the Bugarone Formation have recorded a great amount of well
   preserved Toarcian inner moulds of ammonoids sometimes large sized. From
   the lower and middle Toarcian layers of the Marconessa quarry sections
   we collected several ammonite genera, such as Hildaites, Orthildaites,
   Hildoceras Harpoceras, Taffertia, Rakusites, Martanites,
   Praemercaticeras, Mercaticeras, Leukadiella, Frechiella, Phymatoceras,
   Rarenodia, Praepolyplectus, Polyplectus, Orthodactylites,
   Mesodactylites, Nodicoeloceras, very rare Dactylioceras and Nejdia,
   Lytoceras, Calliphylloceras, Phylloceras. We establish herein a new
   genus Cingolites, to which we ascribe three new species (C. clavatus, C.
   picenus and C. spiralis) and an already established species (C.
   stefaninii), which was previously assigned by Merla (1932) to the genus
   Mercaticeras. To the present-day the genus Cingolites seems to have a
   Mediterranean Tethys dispersal, mainly in the Apennines, where it occurs
   with other endemic Hildoceratinae fauna. These ammonite assemblages
   found in our Apennines sections seem to show a certain amount of
   provincialism that affected some Hildoceratinae lineages of the lower
   Toarcian.
C1 Sassaroli, Stefano; Via S Michele 33, Rosora, AN, Italy, Italy.
EM dtocsa@tin.it
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0375-7633
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

AN ZOOR14705038253
DT Article
TI Silurian and lowermost Devonian conodonts from the Passo Volaia area
   (Carnic Alps, Italy).
AU Corradini, Carlo (corradin@unica.it) 
   Corriga, Maria G.
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 49
IS 3
PS 237-253
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two sections (Rifugio Lambertenghi Fontana - RLF - and Rifugio
   Lambertenghi Fontana III - RLF III) of the Orthoceras limestones that
   crop out just South of Passo Volaia in the Carnic Alps yielded a rich
   and diverse conodont fauna. Twenty-six taxa belonging to eleven genera
   (Belodella, Coryssognathus, Dapsilodus, Dvorakia, Icriodus, Oulodus,
   Ozarkodina, Panderodus, Pseudooneotodus, Wurmiella and Zieglerodina)
   were discriminated. Wurmiella alternata n. sp. is described, and
   Belodella coarctata, Dvorakia amsdeni and Zieglerodina zellmeri are
   reported for the first time from the Carnic Alps. The fauna allows
   recognition of five late Silurian-earliest Lochkovian conodont zones
   (snajdri, crispa, eosteinhornensis s.l., detortus and woschmidti). The
   Silurian/Devonian boundary is interpreted to occur in the upper part of
   the RLF III section.
C1 Corradini, Carlo; Univ Cagliari, Dipartimento Sci Terra, Via Trentino
   51, Cagliari, Italy, Italy.

PT J

DT Article
TI Early Pleistocene sediments on Store Koldewey, northeast Greenland.
AU Bennike, Ole (obe@geus.dk) 
   Knudsen, Karen Luise
   Abrahamsen, Niels
   Bocher, Jens
   Cremer, Holger
   Wagner, Bernd
SO Boreas (Oslo)
VL 39
IS 3
PS 603-619
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Marine Quaternary deposits, here named the Store Koldewey Formation, are
   found at [approximately]120 m above sea level in northeast Greenland
   (76[degree]N). The sequence is referred to the Olduvai normal polarity
   subchron at 1.95-1.78 Ma BP based on palaeomagnetic studies
   (palaeomagnetically reversed), amino acid epimerization ratios and
   evidence from marine and non-marine fossils. The sediments and the fauna
   show that the sequence was deposited on a mid or inner shelf, and some
   elements of the marine mollusc and foraminiferal assemblages indicate
   water temperatures between -1 and +1 [degree]C and seasonal sea ice
   cover during deposition. Mean summer air temperatures were around 6
   [degree]C higher than at present, as demonstrated by the occurrence of
   southern extralimital terrestrial species. Well-preserved remains of
   land plants indicate that the adjacent land area was dominated by
   sub-arctic forest-tundra with the trees Larix and Betula, shrubs, herbs
   and mosses. Most of the species represented as fossils have recent
   circumpolar geographical ranges. An extinct brachiopod species and an
   extinct gastropod species have been found, but the other macrofossils
   are referred to extant species. The brachiopod is erected as a new genus
   and species, Laugekochiana groenlandica. Correlation of the Koldewey
   Formation with the Ile de France Formation farther to the north is
   suggested. Member A of the Kap Kobenhavn Formation in North Greenland is
   referred to the Late Pliocene, whereas Member B of the Kap Kobenhavn
   Formation is suggested to be slightly older than the Store Koldewey
   Formation.
C1 Bennike, Ole; Geol Survey Denmark & Greenland, Oster Voldgade 10,
   Copenhagen, Denmark, Denmark.
EM obe@geus.dk
RI Wagner, Bernd/J-4682-2012; Bennike, Ole/G-7070-2018; Abrahamsen,
   Niels/A-3553-2012; Knudsen, Karen Luise/A-4849-2012
OI Wagner, Bernd/0000-0002-1369-7893; Bennike, Ole/0000-0002-5486-9946; 
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Paleontology

PT J
AN ZOOR14610072990
DT Article
TI Immunological and genetic study of 10 bat rabies virus isolates from Rio
   de Janeiro State, southeast Brazil.
FT Estudo imunologico e genetico de 10 isolados do virus da raiva de
   morcegos do Rio de Janeiro, sudeste do Brasil.
AU Mota, Carla da Silva (carla.mota1976@hotmail.com) 
   Ito, Fumio Honma
   Silva, Marlon Vicente
   Sato, Go
   Kobayashi, Yuki
   Itou, Takuya
   Sakai, Takeo
SO Brazilian Journal of Veterinary Research and Animal Science
VL 47
IS 1
PS 74-85
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 1
AB In the present study we analyzed ten bats rabies viruses isolated from
   Rio de Janeiro State, focusing on its genetic characteristics from genes
   N and G, and also in the response of mice vaccinated with cell-culture
   rabies vaccine, produced with the Pitman-Moore strain, after viral
   challenge with bat rabies isolates, using an immunologic essay based on
   NIH vaccine potency test. The vaccine used conferred protection in more
   than 80% of the mice vaccinated with 1:15 vaccine dilution, after viral
   challenge. N gene genetic analysis divided the rabies virus isolates
   into haematophagous and insectivorous bat variants, with all isolates
   from Artibeus sp. frugivorous bats being clustered with the variant
   characteristic of the Desmodus rotundus vampire bat. Phylogenetic
   differences between isolates from Northeast Region and those from the
   Metropolitan and South Regions of Rio de Janeiro State were observed.
   The substitution of an aspartic acid to a glutamic acid found in the
   position 118 of G gene genetic characterization from samples 704/97BR-DR
   and 151/98BR-DR seems to be related to viral antigenicity. There were no
   time-related genetic differences between the studied samples. The
   vaccine employed was found with satisfactory protection against the
   majority of the isolates used.
C1 Mota, Carla da Silva; 450 Sherbrook Est., ap. 1201, Quebec, Montreal,
   H2L 1J8, Canada, Canada.
EM carla.mota1976@hotmail.com
SC Infectious Diseases; Zoology
SN 1413-9596

   diseases
DE Chiroptera [Viral diseases / Rabies virus transmission / epidemiology;
   host parasite relationships; immunological & genetic study]
   [Transmission /  / ]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

PT J
AN ZOOR14610072114
DT Article
TI [Boraras merah is a synonym of Boraras brigittae!]
FT Boraras merah ist doch ein Synonym von Boraras brigittae!
AU Koerner, Hans-Juergen
SO BSSW Report
VL 22
IS 2
PS 21-28
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two different species of Boraras, B. brigittae and B. merah, are known
   from Kalimantan Borneo. According to KOTTELAT (1991) they are different
   in their colour pattern only. But from the eastern population -
   described by VOGT in 1978 and introduced to Germany by WILKERLING - it
   is well known, that B. brigittae is of sexual dichromatism. Commercial
   imports of Boraras are available mainly from the central province of
   Kalimantan. KOTTELAT described a mixed population there, including both
   B. brigittae and B. merah. But the B. brigittae of that population are
   males and the B. merah are of femal sex there. Their offspring results
   in males of the B. brigittae-type and females of the B. merah-type.
   Males of the B. merah-type were found in the west-ern population only.
   They are charactericed by red coloured bodies and red lateral stripes in
   their caudal fin, These patterns are found by male B. brigittae too.The
   conclusion is drawn, that the central and western populations of Boraras
   of Kalimantan also are sexual dichromatic ones and B. merah is a
   synonyme of B. brigittae.
SC Zoology
SN 0936-0336
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Boraras brigittae [Asia /  / Biology; distribution; natural history;
   systematics]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Boraras brigittae - (Vogt 1978) (Cyprinidae): [Syn nov, Boraras merah
   (Kottelat 1991), p. 22].

DT Article
TI Taxonomy and biostratigraphy of some proetid trilobites in the Middle
   Devonian of the Ardennes and Eifel (Rhenohercynian Zone).
AU Van Viersen, Allart P. (apvanviersen@gmail.com) 
   Prescher, Harald
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique
   Sciences de la Terre
VL 80
PS 5-45
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Proetids are common trilobites in the Middle Devonian of the Ardennes
   and Eifel. They are known from ample material and so provide an
   excellent basis for taxonomic and biostratigraphic studies. Seven new
   species are recorded from the Ardennes, Belgium (Gerastos circus n. sp.,
   Gerastos couvinensis n. sp., Gerastos snellingsi n. sp., Astycoryphe
   exilis n. sp., Astycoryphe jorusi n. sp., Cornuproetus latentissimus n.
   sp., Dechenella rossumi n. sp.) and four additional ones from the Eifel,
   Germany (Gerastos kippingi n. sp., Gerastos batrachus n. sp., Gerastos
   rommersheimensis n. sp., Dohmiella acanthonota n. sp.), on the basis of
   recent collecting and examination of institutional collections.
   Astycoryphe sp. B, Cornuproetus cf latentissimus n. sp. and Cornuproetus
   sp. 2 (Ardennes) are also described. The holotype of Astycoryphe
   senckenbergiana RICHTER & RICHTER (Eifel) is refigured. A preliminary
   overview of the stratigraphic distributions of species in Eifelian to
   lowermost Givetian strata in the Ardennes and Eifel is presented, so far
   encompassing the genera Gerastos, Dohmiella (Proetinae), Cornuproetus,
   Diademaproetus (Cornuproetinae), Astycoryphe, Tropidocoryphe
   (Tropidocoryphinae) and Dechenella (Dechenellinae).
C1 Van Viersen, Allart P.; Nat Hist Museum, Bosquetpl 6-7, Maastricht,
   NL-6211 KJ, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM apvanviersen@gmail.com

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069473
DT Article
TI Re-examination of the Late Emsian rhynchonellid (brachiopod) Terebratula
   daleidensis Roemer, 1844 from the Eifel area, and of some related
   species.
AU Sartenaer, Paul
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique
   Sciences de la Terre
VL 80
PS 47-84
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Upper Emsian Terebratula Daleidensis ROEMER, 1844 (now
   Oligoptycherhynchus daleidensis) from the Daleiden "Muldengruppe", Eifel
   area, is scrutinized. The ubiquity and considerable stratigraphic range
   gained by the species in the course of time are exposed and questioned.
   After examination of the lectotype, here designated, and rich existing
   collections, return to the original definition of this abundant species
   is recommended. Rhynchonella inaurita SANDBERGER, G. & F., 1856,
   commonly mistaken for daleidensis, is assigned to Inaequalibellirostrum
   n. gen., the type genus of Inaequalibellirostridae n. fam. The
   geographic distribution, the stratigraphic range, and affinities of the
   type species of the new genus, I. pareti (de VERNEUIL, 1850a) from the
   middle part of the Emsian of the Cantabrian Cordillera (Province of
   Leon) resulted, among others, in the reassessment of the genus
   Stenorhynchia BRICE, 1981, and its questionable presence in the
   Armorican Massif.
C1 Sartenaer, Paul; Royal Belgian Inst Nat Sci, Dept Palaeontol, Rue
   Vautier 29, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
SC Zoology
SN 0374-6291
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Geological time
   periods; Palaeozoic
DE Inaequalibellirostridae [Devonian /  / New family]. 
   Inaequalibellirostrum [Devonian /  / New genus]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda
OR Hemithyris pareti - de Verneuil 1850 (Brachiopoda): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Inaequalibellirostrum, p. 64; Lectotype
   designated, P. 67]. 
   Inaequalibellirostridae (Brachiopoda): [Fam nov, Type genus
   Inaequalibellirostrum, p. 63, Devonian; Fossil]. 
   Inaequalibellirostrum (Brachiopoda): [Gen nov, Of new family

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069475
DT Article
TI Ichthyodectidae (Teleostei, Ichthyodectiformes) from the Aptian (Lower
   Cretaceous) bituminous shales of Equatorial Guinea and Gabon.
FT Les Ichthyodectidae (Teleostei, Ichthyodectiformes) des schistes
   bitumineux de l'Aptien (Cretace inferieur) de Guinee Equatoriale et du
   Gabon.
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique
   Sciences de la Terre
VL 80
PS 115-143
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The osteology and the phylogenetic relationships of three ichthyodectids
   from the Aptian bituminous shales of Equatorial Guinea and Gabon are
   studied. The first species was already known as Chirocentrites
   guinensis. It is a valid species but its skeleton shows that it does not
   belong to Chirocentrites but to Chiromystus, a genus characterized by
   its enlarged and branched pectoral rays and a short vertebral axis. The
   differences between Chiromystus and Cladocyclus are brought to light to
   demonstrate the validity of Chiromystus. The second species is only
   known by some cranial fragments, particularly the jaws. It is a new
   genus and species, Africathrissops welled, which seems primitive and
   close to Thrissops. Its articulation facet for the quadrate is formed by
   the retroarticular and the articular without a participation of the
   angular. The third species Verraesichthys bloti is new and represents a
   new genus too, also characterised by a short axial skeleton, but its
   skull and its pectoral girdle strongly differ from those of Chiromystus.
   The caudal skeleton of an unnamed but specialised ichthyodectid is also
   described
C1 Taverne, Louis; Residence Les Platanes, Blvd Souverain 142,Boite 8,
   Brussels, B-1170, Belgium, Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069478
DT Article
TI New representatives of the genus Septatoechia Lobatscheva & Titova, 1977
   (Brachiopoda, Rhynchonellida, Tetrarhynchiidae) from the Maastrichtian
   of Western Europe.
AU Simon, Eric (ericsimon98brach@yahoo.fr) 
   Motchurova-Dekova, Neda
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique
   Sciences de la Terre
VL 80
PS 171-186
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB PETTITT (1950) erected the species Cretirhynchia magna for a
   rhynchonellide brachiopod collected from the Upper Chalk of Trimingham,
   Norfolk, England. On the basis of specimens of this species made
   available to the authors, serial transverse sections and SEM examination
   of the shell microstructure were performed. Macro-morphological
   characters observed assign this material to the genus Septatoechia
   LOBATSCHEVA & TITOVA, 1977. The early Maastrichtian Cyclothyris elegans
   (VON HANSTEIN, 1879) collected from Ciply (Hainaut, Belgium) is
   reappraised and its generic allocation is also changed due to the
   macromorphological characteristics fitting the genus Septatoechia. The
   shell microstructure pattern of the secondary shell layer of both
   species is 'fine fibrous' (leptinoid). The discrepancy in the shell
   microstructure patterns between western representatives (S. magna and S.
   elegans) and the eastern representatives (S. inflata and S.
   amudariensis) stimulated revision of previous published information.
   Careful re-examination of unpublished results revealed problems with the
   original description of the shell microstructure of S. inflata and S.
   amudariensis due to the use of oblique lateral sections of the fibres.
   Emended description of the shell microstructure of S. inflata and S.
   amudariensis is herein provided. Thus all four species belonging to the
   genus Septatoechia have 'fine fibrous' (leptinoid) shell microstructure,
   typical of superfamily Hemithiridoidea.
C1 Simon, Eric; Inst Royal Sci Nat Belgique, Dept Paleontol, Rue Vautier
   29, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM ericsimon98brach@yahoo.fr
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0374-6291
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Septatoechia [Belgium / Hainaut / systematics; records] [England /
   Norfolk / ] [Cretaceous / Maastrichtian / ]. 
   Septatoechia amudariensis; Septatoechia inflata [Shell morphology /
   Shell microstructure / ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda
OR Cretirhynchia magna - Pettitt 1950 (Brachiopoda): [Referred to,
   Septatoechia, p. 173; Fossil]. 
   Cyclothyris elegans - Von Hanstein 1879 (Brachiopoda): [Referred to,
   Septatoechia, p. 174; Fossil].

   173; Fossil]. 
   Septatoechia amudariensis (Brachiopoda): [Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069479
DT Article
TI Priacanthidae (Teleostei, Perciformes) from the Lede Sands (Middle
   Eocene, Belgium): osteology and otoliths.
FT Les Priacanthidae (Teleostei, Perciformes) des Sables de Lede (Eocene
   moyen, Belgique): osteologie et otolithes.
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
   Nolf, Dirk
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique
   Sciences de la Terre
VL 80
PS 187-243
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB The osteology of the fossil priacanthid Pristigenys ruloti (= P. caduca)
   (Teleostei, Percoidei) from the Sands of Lede (marine Middle Eocene,
   Belgium) is described in details thanks to a nearly complete specimen
   with a skull preserved in volume and to other samples with isolated
   bones. A new species, Pristigenys hermani, also from the Sands of Lede,
   is erected on the basis of isolated bones and otoliths. The two species
   are compared together. It is shown that the skeletal elements and the
   otoliths of Pristigenys dentifer from the Eocene of England are
   identical to the homologous pieces of P. rutoti. The English species is
   put into synonymy of the Belgian species which has the priority. The
   evolution of the sagitta within Priacanthidae is discussed.
C1 Taverne, Louis; Residence Les Platanes, Blvd Souverain 142,Boite 8,
   Brussels, B-1170, Belgium, Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Otolith / ] [Belgium /  / ] [Eocene / Middle Eocene / ].

DT Article
TI Reassessment of the Bivalvia (Mollusca) from the Boom Formation
   (Rupelian, Oligocene) of Belgium, with description of new species.
AU Marquet, Robert (Robert.MARQUET@HUBrussel.be) 
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique
   Sciences de la Terre
VL 80
PS 253-282
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The bivalve species found in the Boom Formation (Rupelian, Early
   Oligocene) in Belgium are taxonomically revised. The distribution of the
   species over the Members and beds of this Formation is detailed. Of the
   39 species occurring in the Boom Formation, 11 are recorded for the
   first time in Belgium, four of which are new to science: Semierycina
   (Semierycina) kruibekensis nov. sp., Scacchia (Scacchia) dufraingi nov.
   sp., Thracia (Thracia) vanremoorteli nov. sp. and Cardiomya (sensu Into)
   annamariae nov. sp. The large majority of the species seems to be
   endemic to the North Sea Basin. It is attemped to link the distribution
   of the species to ecological conditions (especially bathymetry) of the
   different beds.
C1 Marquet, Robert; Constitutiestr 50, Antwerp, B-2060, Belgium, Belgium.

TI [Observations of turtles, seabirds and marine mammals off the Atlantic
   coasts of Morocco during Autumn 2010.]
FT Observations de Tortues, d'Oiseaux et de Mammiferes marins au large des
   cotes atlantiques marocaines durant l'automne 2010.
AU Gutierrez Ezposito, Carlos
   Qninba, Abdeljebbar
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Scientifique Section Sciences de la Vie - Rabat
VL 32
IS 2
PS 129-132
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB We expose data on marine mammals and turtles as well as of some seabirds
   noted along the Moroccan coast during a ship trip by one of us (C.G.E.)
   from Almunecar (Almeria, SE Spain) to the Canary Islands from september
   9th to 11th. Species, number of individuals and coordinates were noted.
   Observations include Loggerhead Sea Turtle (Caretta caretta), Bulwer's
   Petrel (Bulweria bulwerii), Great Shearwater (Puffinus gravis), Madeira
   Storm-petrel (Oceanodroma castro), Pomarine Skua (Stercorarius
   pomarinus), Sabine's Gull (Xema sabini), Minke Whale (Balaenoptera
   acutorostrata), Pilot Whale (Globicephala sp.), Cuvier's Beaked Whale
   (Ziphius cavirostris) and Atlantic Spotted Dolphin (Stenella frontalis).
   For Cuvier's Beaked Whale this is the second record for Morocco, and the
   first of wild living animals, and the two observations of Atlantic
   Spotted Dolphins constitute the first sightings in Moroccan waters.

TI Review of the endemic genus Pyreneosoma Mauries, 1959: history and new
   taxa (Diplopoda, Craspedosomatida, Haplobainosomatidae).
FT Revision du genre endemique Pyreneosoma Mauries, 1959: historique,
   nouveautes (Diplopoda, Craspedosomatida, Haplobainosomatidae).
AU Mauries, Jean-Paul (mauries.jean-paul@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe d'Histoire Naturelle de Toulouse
VL 146
PS 21-46

LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present review of the endemic Pyrenean genus Pyreneosoma Mauries,
   1959 contains, after brief historical notes: a) a list of the published
   and unpublished localities for the four already known species: P.
   ribauti and P. digitatum Mauries, 1959 (lectotypes designation), P.
   barbieri (Mauries, 1971) and P. bessoni Mauries, 1974; b) the
   descriptions of 7 new taxa: two are gathered from caves of the Spanish
   provinces Huesca (P. bessoni huescanus) and Lerida (P. grandicoxae);
   five live in nival zones, one in Spain, in the Valle de Aran (P.
   aranensis ). and the four others in the french departments of
   Haute-Garonne (P. convenarum) and Ariege (P birosensis, P. consoranensis
   and P. vicdessosensis).

PT J
AN ZOOR14608055053
DT Article
TI Biodiversity in the stygobiontic cirolanids (Crustacea, Isopoda) from
   the Mediterranean Basin: II - systematics, ecology and historical
   biogeography of Typhlocirolana tiznitensis n. sp., the first
   representative of the genus, South of the Moroccan High Atlas.
AU Boulal, M.
   Boulanouar, M.
   Boutin, Cl. (boutin@cict.fr) 
   Yacoubi-Khebiza, M.
SO Bulletin de la Societe d'Histoire Naturelle de Toulouse
VL 145
PS 11-28
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Typhlocirolana Racovitza, 1905 was known from the Western
   Mediterranean countries, mainly from North Africa, Spain and Sicily. For
   the first time a species of this genus, Typhlocirolana tiznitensis n.
   sp., is reported and described from a region located on the southern
   side of the Moroccan High Atlas. Thus the distribution area of the genus
   is significantly extended southwards. Ecological data, historical
   biogeography and phylogenetic relationships of the new species are
   presented. Within its genus, the new species belongs to a group of
   species which still exibits many characteristics of epibenthic marine
   species and which are considered as primitive traits inherited and
   retained from their ancestors. This group has representatives in
   different other regions, which were all reached and flooded by the sea
   during the Cenomano-Turonian marine transgressions. The occurrence of
   such a species in the Tiznit Province strongly suggests that the marine
   paleo-gulfs of Tarfaya in the South and the High Atlas gulf in North of
   the Province, apparently separated by an emerged land during the
   Mesozoic times - may have been in fact connected together, from the
   North to the South. The Cenomano-Turonian sea very probably covered the
   whole western margin of the present Morocco, including the Tiznit
   Province where the Mesozoic sediments have not been preserved.
C1 Boutin, Cl.; Universite Paul Sabatier, Toulouse III, Laboratoire
   d'Ecologie Fonctionnelle, UMR CNRS-UPS-INP No 5245, Ecolab,
   Stygobiologie, 39 Allees Jules Guesde, F-31400 Toulouse, France, France.
EM boutin@cict.fr
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0758-4113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Typhlocirolana [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Africa / Mediterranean region / ] [Morocco / South west / New record]
   [Eurasia /  / ]. 
   Typhlocirolana tiznitensis [Morocco /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Typhlocirolana (Isopoda): [New record]. 
   Typhlocirolana tiznitensis - Boulal, Boulanour & Boutin 2010 (Isopoda):
   [Sp nov, Morocco, P. 13].

DT Article
TI Description of Pseudocandona serfozoi n. sp. (Crustacea, Ostracoda,
   Candonidae) from Romania.
AU Gido, Zsolt (gidozso@freemail.hu) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe des Naturalistes Luxembourgeois
VL 111
PS 131-143
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pseudocandona serfozoi n. sp. of the zschokkei-group of Pseudocandona s.
   l. is described. The new species was collected from the hyporheic waters
   of the Tarnava Mare river and from several nearby springs of the
   Harghita mountains in Romania. The new species has a trapezoidal
   carapace and second male antennae with well-developed male bristles. It
   difers from the other four known trapezoidal species of Pseudocandona by
   that latter character and the morphology of the hemipenis. The taxonomic
   position of the trapezoidal species of the zschokkei-group is discussed.
C1 Gido, Zsolt; Szechenyi utca 25, H-7940 Szentlorinc, Hungary, Hungary.
EM gidozso@freemail.hu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0304-9620
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe

   Pseudocandona zschokkei species group [Phylogeny / Monophyly / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI A new Titanosaur genus (Dinosauria, Sauropoda) from the Late Cretaceous
   of southern France and its paleobiogeographic implications.
AU Garcia, Geraldine (geraldine.garcia@univ-poitiers.fr) 
   Amico, Sauveur
   Fournier, Francois
   Thouand, Eudes
   Valentin, Xavier
SO Bulletin de la Societe Geologique de France
VL 181
IS 3
PS 269-277
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new titanosaur, Atsinganosaurus velauciensis, gen. and sp. nov. is
   described from well-preserved remains from the new Upper Cretaceous
   locality of Velaux-La Bastide Neuve (Aix-en-Provence Basin, France).
   This taxon is mainly diagnosed by a combination of characters, which
   differentiates it without ambiguity from other European Late Cretaceous
   taxa (Lirainosaurus, Ampelosaurus and Magyarosaurus). Atsinganosaurus
   confirms the presence in western Europe during the latest Cretaceous of
   a third titanosaurian species, slender and less derived which allows us
   to better understand the evolutionary and paleobiogeographical history
   of this group during the Cretaceous.
C1 Garcia, Geraldine; Univ Poitiers, CNRS, 40 Ave Recteur Pineau, Poitiers,
   France, France.

TI Bryozoa from Marquesas Islands (French Polynesia) (1st part).
FT Bryozoaires des Iles Marquises (Polynesie Francaise) (1e partie).
AU d'Hondt, Jean-Loup
   Mascarell, Gerard
SO Bulletin de la Societe Linneenne de Bordeaux
VL 38
IS 2
PS 203-219
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 1
U2 1
AB 42 species of Bryozoa belonging to 32 genera and 30 families have been
   collected around the Marquesas Islands during the oceanograpic cruise
   MUSORSTOM 9 in 1997, in addition to the two single species (2 genera, 1
   family) up to now known from this archipelago Three new species are
   described Alcyonidium (7) vahine n sp, Micropora cervicornis n sp and
   Parasmittina breli n sp. These data are included here in the whole of
   the present general knowledges on the Bryozoa from the French Polynesia
   The number of the species collected seems be very variable from a
   archipelago to another inside the Territory, this apparent disparity
   proceeds probably from a very inegal prospection effort according to the
   islands Now, 93 species of Bryozoa, belonging to 63 genera and 46
   families, were collected inside the whole French Polynesia; the large
   majority is constituted by cheilostomes The bryozoan biodiversity of the
   islands of the French Polynesia appears to be more rich that we are
   imagining it up to now, and presents in a general point of view
   important affinities with the Indonesian's one

   Ledon, Daniel
SO Bulletin de la Societe Linneenne de Bordeaux
VL 38
IS 3
PS 349-359
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species Tectus (s.str.) blaviensis nov. sp. of Bartonian limestones
   (Middle Eocene) of Blaye (Gironde) is described from a very well
   preserved external print. It is the first record of the family
   Turbinidae in the Bartonian of the Aquitaine Basin. The species is
   compared with Tectus (s.str.) mitratus (DESHAYES, 1832) of Lutetian
   (Middle Eocene) of the Paris Basin.

TI The Recent molluscs from the 'Reserve Naturelle Geologique de Saucats-La
   Brede (Gironde, France).

   Brede (Gironde, France).
AU Charles, Laurent (l.charles@mairie-bordeaux.fr) 
   Greaume, Cyrille
SO Bulletin de la Societe Linneenne de Bordeaux
VL 38
IS 4
PS 437-448
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB We have drawn up the first inventory of the land and freshwater
   malacofauna of the Reserve Naturelle Geologique de Saucats-La Brede. A
   total of 50 species, 6 of which are aquatic, were observed in the
   various sites. To this list, we saw 5 more species observed in Saucats,
   very close to the Reserve area. Among the species encountered during
   this inventory, three of them are discussed : Balea heydeni VON MALTZAN,
   1881 noted for the first time in Aquitaine, Semilimax pyrenaicus
   (FERUSSAC, 1821) newly encountered in Gironde and Bythinella sp.,
   morphologically distinct from Bythinella ferussina (DES MOULINS, 1827),
   the only species of this genus recently recorded in the Gironde,
   suggesting a wider local diversity for the genus.

PT J
AN ZOOR14609059133
DT Article
TI Lower-Middle Devonian rugose coral faunas of Nevada: Contribution to an
   understanding of the 'barren' E Zone and Chotec Event in the Great
   Basin.
AU Pedder, Alan E.H. (apedder@telus.net) 
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 1
PS 1-26
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The "lower Middle Devonian" part of a coral zonation proposed for the
   region in 1974 comprised in ascending order D2 and D3 subzones and a
   "barren" E zone. In terms of the conodont zonation currently employed in
   Nevada, the D2 subzone is Emsian gronbergi and inversus zones. The
   original stratigraphic definition of the D3 subzone places it in the
   upper Emsian serotinus Zone on Lone Mountain, whereas the coral index
   defining the zone has been collected subsequently only from Eifelian
   upper costatus Zone beds. The original stratigraphic definition of the
   "barren" E zone places it in a lower part of the costatus Zone, above an
   inferred depositional break. Thus, as defined on Lone Mountain, the D3
   subzone is slightly younger than the E zone. These zones are not barren.
   Revised taxonomy and age determinations of previously described species,
   coupled with new data from the southern Sulphur Spring and northern
   Antelope ranges, have revealed four successive coral assemblages ranging
   from serotinus to costatus Zone age. Differences between the second and
   third of these assemblages are particularly significant, and may be
   considered to represent a local manifestation of the Chotec Event. A
   detailed review of the genus Synaptophyllum shows it to be an Emsian
   endemic in the Maghrebo-European Realm, not an early Eifelian endemic in
   the Eastern Americas Realm. New taxa comprise a family, one genus and
   two species. Romanophyllum paulyi gen. et sp. nov., which possibly
   represents one of the last vestiges of the Pragian-Emsian Great Basin
   coral province, is assigned to the Romanophyllidae fam. n. Xystriphyllum
   trojani sp. nov. is described as an example of one of earliest
   ptenophyllid species to return to the Great Basin after the absence of
   the family from the region since late Lochkovian time.
C1 Pedder, Alan E.H.; Geol Survey Canada, 8859 Pk Pacific Terrace, Sydney,
   BC, Canada, Canada.
EM apedder@telus.net
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1214-1119

   Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

TI A new aeduellid actinopterygian from the Lower Permian of the Krkonose
   Piedmont Basin (Bohemian Massif) and its relationships to other
   Aeduellidae.
AU Stamberg, Stanislav (s.stamberg@muzeumhk.cz) 
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 2
PS 183-198
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new aeduellid actinopterygian, Neslovicella elongata sp. nov., is
   described from the Lower Permian of the Krkonose Piedmont Basin
   (Bohemian Massif). The new taxon is based upon a collection of specimens
   that facilitated the revision of several characters of the Aeduellidae.
   N. elongata is described in detail and compared to other aeduellids. A
   second occurrence of this species in the Weissig Basin of Germany is
   also discussed.

PT J
AN ZOOR14612082286
DT Article
TI Early Cretaceous ribbed Aptychi - a proposal for a new systematic
   classification.
AU Mechova, Lucie (lucie.mechova@vsb.cz) 
   Vasicek, Zdenek
   Housa, Vaclav
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 2
PS 219-274
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The older system for classification of ribbed calcareous Early
   Cretaceous Aptychi consisted of two genera: Punctaptychus and
   Lamellaptychus. Later, I. Turculet divided Lamellaptychus into several
   subgenera. Within the framework of both the genera, species and
   subspecies were distinguished, which resulted in binominal and
   trinominal nomenclature. With regard to the richness of newly described
   species and subspecies in recent years, is not possible to continue
   using the original system. It is the basic ribbing that plays the
   decisive role in the generic and subgeneric classification of ribbed
   Aptychi. In the case of subspecies systematics, all details on the valve
   surface are used with the exception of the sigmoidal bend
   (fractocostatus) and radial lines (radiatus). The ribbed Aptychi are
   newly divided into the following families: Punctaptychidae fam. nov. and
   Lamellaptychidae fam. nov. Within the family Punctaptychidae we are able
   to distinguish two genera: Punctaptychus Trauth, 1927 and
   Cinctpunctaptychus gen. nov. The family Lamellaptychidae includes five
   genera differing in the basic arrangement of the ribs: Lamellaptychus
   Trauth, 1927, Beyrichilamellaptychus Turculet, 1994,
   Mortilletilamellaptychus gen. nov., Thorolamellaptychus Turculet, 1994
   and Didayilamellaptychus Turculet, 1994. Eight species and one
   subspecies are established as new: Cinctpunctaptychus undulatus,
   Beyrichilamellaptychus pseudostuderi, Mortilletilamellaptychus
   mortilletioides, M. submortilleti noricus, M. stanislavi,
   Didayilamellaptychus hennigi, D. andrusovi and D. renzi.
C1 Mechova, Lucie; Acad Sci Czech Republ, Inst Geon, Studentska 1768,
   Ostrava, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM lucie.mechova@vsb.cz
RI Housa, Vaclav/H-6797-2014
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1214-1119
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Type species; Type
   material; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Aptychi [Cretaceous / Early Cretaceous / Stratigraphical distribution;
   systematics; ribbed taxa]. 
   Beyrichilamellaptychus pseudostuderi; Cinctpunctaptychus undulatus;
   Didayilamellaptychus andrasovi; Didayilamellaptychus henningi;
   Mortilletilamellaptychus mortilletioides; Mortilletilamellaptychus
   stanislavi [Czech Republic /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Cinctpunctaptychus; Mortilletilamellaptychus [Mesozoic /  / New genus]. 
   Didayilamellaptychus renzi [North Atlantic /  / new species] [Cretaceous
   /  / ]. 
   Lamellaptychidae; Punctaptychidae [Mesozoic /  / New family]. 
   Mortilletilamellaptychus submortilleti noricus [Austria /  / new
   subspecies] [Mesozoic /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Aptychi
OR Aptychi (Cephalopoda): [Classification, New scheme for Early Cretaceous
   ribbed taxa, p. 230; Fossil]. 
   Aptychus beyrichi - Oppel 1865 (Aptychi): [Lectotype designated, P. 239;
   Fossil]. 
   Aptychus mortilleti - Pictet & Loriol 1858 (Aptychi): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Mortilletilamellaptychus, p. 243; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14612082287
DT Article
TI Bathonian (Middle Jurassic) cyclostome bryozoans from the Polish Jura.
AU Zaton, Michal (mzaton@wnoz.us.edu.pl) 
   Taylor, Paul D.
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 2
PS 275-302
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Cyclostome bryozoan assemblages encrusting bivalve shells and oncoliths,
   as well as coming from the host sediment, are described from the
   Bathonian (Middle Jurassic) ore-bearing clays of the Polish Jura. In
   total, 16 species belonging to the genera Stomatopora, Proboscinopora?,
   Microeciella, Reptomultisparsa, Hyporosopora, Mecynoecia, Ceriocava and
   unidentified 'entalophorids' are described. Twelve taxa could not be
   determined with certainty to species level. Two species are described as
   new: Reptomultisparsa kawodrzanensis sp. nov. and Mecynoecia kaimi sp.
   nov. The diagnosis of Hyporosopora bugajensis Zaton & Taylor, 2009a is
   emended. Combining the diversity data both from this and a previously
   published paper, a total of 29 species of cyclostome bryozoans are now
   known from the Bathonian of the Polish Basin, a stratigraphical stage
   during which the cyclostomes attained their peak-diversity for the
   Jurassic. This species richness is comparatively high, approaching the
   maximum recorded for a Jurassic assemblage, which is 33 species in the
   Bathonian of Normandy, France where the bryozoans are associated with
   sponge bioherms and hardgrounds as well as oncoliths and shells of
   bivalves and brachiopods.
C1 Zaton, Michal; Univ Silesia, Fac Earth Sci, Bedzinska 60, Sosnowiec,
   Poland, Poland.
EM mzaton@wnoz.us.edu.pl
OI Zaton, Michal/0000-0001-5136-5286; Taylor, Paul/0000-0002-3127-080X
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1214-1119
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Ecology; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Cyclostomata [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Poland / Jura / ]
   [Jurassic / Bathonian / ]. 
   Mecynoecia kaimi; Reptomultisparsa kawodrzanensis [Poland /  / new
   species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Bryozoans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Bryozoa
OR Cyclostomata (Bryozoa): [Fossil]. 
   Hyporosopora bugajensis - Zaton & Taylor 2009 (Bryozoa): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 289; Fossil]. 
   Mecynoecia kaimi (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Poland, Jurassic, P. 292; Fossil]. 
   Reptomultisparsa kawodrzanensis (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Poland, Jurassic, P.
   286; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14612082288
DT Article
TI Zlichovian faunas with early ammonoids from Morocco and their use for
   the correlation of the eastern Anti-Atlas and the western Dra Valley.
AU De Baets, Kenneth (kenneth.debaets@pim.uzh.ch) 
   Klug, Christian
   Plusquellec, Yves
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 2
PS 317-352
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two sections were sampled and measured at Mdaour-El-Kbir (Dra Valley,
   western Anti-Atlas) and at eastern Ouidane Chebbi (Tafilalt, eastern
   Anti-Atlas). In situ elements of two partially limonitized and one
   carbonatic fauna were found in both sections. We report this fauna from
   the upper Merz-Akhsai Formation and the lower Mdaour-el-Kbir Formation
   at Mdaour-el-Kbir for the first time. Based on these faunas, we recorded
   a correlation of the early Emsian (Zlichovian) strata in the Tafilalt
   and the Dra Valley regions, which are about 350 km apart. Additionally,
   new ammonoid finds (Teicherticeras cf. senior, Lenzites gesinae,
   Weyeroceras angustus) are figured and described including the
   stratigraphic context. The diagnoses of Lenzites gesinae and Weyeroceras
   angustus are emended. Tabulate corals (Michelinia mdaourensis sp. nov.,
   Petridictyum sp.) found in both the Tafilalt and Dra Valley are figured
   and described for the first time.
C1 De Baets, Kenneth; Univ Zurich, Palaontol Inst & Museum, Karl Schmid Str
   4, Zurich, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM kenneth.debaets@pim.uzh.ch

   Christian/0000-0002-4099-7453

SN 1214-1119
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Africa; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   distribution; systematics] [Devonian / Zlichovian / ]. 
   Michelinia mdaourensis [Morocco /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea

   Michelinia mdaourensis - Plusquellec 2010 (Tabulata): [Sp nov, Morocco,
   Devonian, P. 331; Fossil]. 
   Ammonoidea (Cephalopoda): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Lenzites gesinae (Ammonoidea): [Emended diagnosis, P. 343; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A review of silurian discinoid brachiopods from Gotland, Sweden.
AU Mergl, Michal (mmergl@kbi.zcu.cz) 
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 3
PS 367-384
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Silurian discinoid brachiopods from Gotland currently housed in the
   Swedish Museum of Natural History in Stockholm are revised. Fourteen
   species of genera Schizocrania, Acrosaccus, Ivanothele, Orbiculoidea and
   Rugadiscina are described; three species (Acrosaccus barabackensis, A.
   hallaensis and Rugadiscina petesviki) are new. Although generic
   composition of the Gotland discinoid fauna is very similar to that of
   the Welsh Borderland rather than to that of the Barrandian in Bohemia,
   the species differences confirm a biogeographic separation of all these
   areas in the Silurian.
C1 Mergl, Michal; Univ W Bohemia, Fac Educ, Klatovska 51, Plzen, Czech
   Republic, Czech Republic.
EM mmergl@kbi.zcu.cz
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1214-1119

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Acrosaccus barabackensis; Acrosaccus hallaensis; Rugadiscina petesviki
   [Sweden /  / new species] [Silurian /  / ]. 
   Discinoidea [Sweden / Gotland / systematics] [Silurian /  / ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda

   370; Fossil].

   Fossil].

   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Articulated hyoliths and other fosslis from the Sirius Passet
   Lagerstaette (early Cambrian) of North Greenland.
AU Peel, John S. (John.Peel@pal.uu.se) 
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 3
PS 385-394
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Hyolithids with helens and an operculum, and a second species of
   loricate cycloneuralian, Sirilorica pustulosa sp. nov., are described
   from the Sirius Passet Lagerstatte (early Cambrian; Cambrian Series 2,
   Stage 3) of Peary Land, North Greenland. An ethmophylloid archaeocyathan
   and a species of the bivalved arthropod Isoxys are described in open
   nomenclature. The association of trace fossils with body fossils is
   discussed.

   Uppsala, Sweden, Sweden.

DT Article
TI Relationships of the Triassic Eucycloidea Koken, 1897 (Mollusca,
   Gastropoda) to modern genera such as Pagodatrochus, Calliotropis and
   Euchelus, based on morphology of the early shell.
AU Bandel, Klaus (klausbandel@yahoo.com) 
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 85
IS 3
PS 435-486
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The aim of this study is to document the relationship that may exist
   between Triassic species of Eucycloscala, Ampezzotrochus, Sabrinella,
   Microcheilus, Eunemopsis and Pseudoclanculus and living species of
   genera such as Pagodatrochus, Turcica, Calliotropis, Danilia, and
   Euchelus. Their shell has a nacreous inner layer and ornament of axial
   ribs on the early teleoconch. This ornament distinguishes from living
   and fossil Vetigastropoda with Trochus, and Turbo-like shells.
   Eucycloscalidae, containing the Triassic genera Eucycloscala and
   Ampezzotrochus, can be distinguished from Eunemopsis and Pseudoclanculus
   and the Eunemopsidae fam. nov. by folds on the inner lip and
   Sabrinellidae fam. nov. with Sabrinella and Microcheilus by the varix of
   the aperture of the last whorl. Lanascala with Lanascalidae belongs
   here. Neoeunema gen. nov. represents a Triassic member of Eucyclidae,
   which contains numerous Jurassic genera and species. Pseudoturcicidae
   fam. nov. differs by the ornament of the early teleoconch. The
   Chilodontidae form a characteristic Cretaceous group with teeth on the
   inner side of their outer lip. Three families of modern genera can be
   distinguished by the arrangement of teeth in the radula: four pairs in
   Pagodatrochidae fam. nov. and Turcicidae fam. nov., and three pairs in
   Calliotropidae, documented with Euchelus. The Seguenzioidea represents a
   related group having a distinctive radula with two lateral pairs of
   teeth and a variety of shell shapes and ornament. The early teleoconch
   of Seguenziidae (with slit in the aperture) and Ancistrobasidae fam.
   nov. (without such a slit) resembles that of the Eucycloscalidae, but
   has a strong spiral rib in addition to the axial ribs. The new species
   Microcheilus maxwelli sp. nov., Eucycloidea madagascariensis sp. nov.,
   new genera Pseudoturcica and Heterodiscohelix, and new families
   Sabrinellidae fam. nov., Euemopsidae fam. nov., Pseudoturcidae fam.
   nov., Pagodatrochidae fam. nov. Turcicidae fam. nov., and
   Ancistrobasidae fam. nov. are introduced. The fossil record confirms
   existence of two independent branches of Vetigastropoda since more than
   220 Ma, and within one of these branches parallel to the Eucycloidea the
   Seguenzioidea since Mesozoic times.
C1 Bandel, Klaus; Univ Hamburg, Inst Geol Palaontol, Bundesstr 55, Hamburg,
   Germany, Germany.
EM klausbandel@yahoo.com
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1214-1119
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Type species;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Skeletal and supporting
   structures; Shell; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa; Geological
   time periods; Mesozoic

   species for new genus, Neoeunema, p. 452; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14703025883
DT Article
TI GENERIC REVISION OF THE PROCIRRINA (COLEOPTERA: STAPHYLINIDAE:
   PAEDERINAE: PINOPHILINI).
AU Herman, Lee (herman@amnh.org) 
SO Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History
VL 347
PS 1-78
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The paederine subtribe Procirrina is redescribed, the morphology,
   phylogenetic relationships, and distribution are discussed, and a key to
   the eight genera is presented. In the section on morphology, the female
   genital sclerites are discussed and terms are proposed for the fused
   sclerites. Neoprocirrus, Oedichirus, Oedodactylus, Palaminus,
   Paraprocirrus, Procirrus, and Pseudoprocirrus are redescribed and a list
   of the included species and examined species is included for each.
   Stylokyrtus, new genus, is described for Oedodactylus errans Sharp,
   1876, new combination. Parapalaminus Bierig, 1943, Procirrinus Koch,
   1934, and Oedichiranus Reiner, 1906, described as subgenera, are new
   synonyms of Palaminus, Procirrus, and Oedichirus respectively. The
   sister group of Procirrina is Pinophilina. The basal genus of the
   Procirrina is Oedodactylus; Pseudoprocirrus is the sister group to the
   remainder of the genera, which are clustered in two clades. Palaminus +
   Oedichirus comprise one of the two clades with Paraprocirrus and
   Procirrus + Neoprocirrus as its sister. As Stylokyrtus is known by only
   one specimen, most of the characters important to phylogenetic placement
   of the genus were unavailable for study and its position within the
   subtribe is ambiguous.
C1 Herman, Lee; Amer Museum Nat Hist, Div Invertebrate Zool, New York, NY,
   USA, USA.
EM herman@amnh.org

DT Article
TI SPECIES LIMITS AND PHYLOGENETIC RELATIONSHIPS IN THE DIDELPHID MARSUPIAL
   GENUS THYLAMYS BASED ON MITOCHONDRIAL DNA SEQUENCES AND MORPHOLOGY.
AU Giarla, Thomas C.
   Voss, Robert S.
   Jansa, Sharon A.
SO Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History
VL 346
PS 3-67
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Species of the didelphid marsupial genus Thylamys, commonly known as
   fat-tailed mouse opossums, are broadly distributed in the open habitats
   of central and southern South America. In this report we examine species
   limits in the genus and infer phylogenetic relationships among Thylamys
   species using both molecular phylogenetic and morphological methods. We
   assessed species limits using a broad geographic sample of DNA sequences
   from the mitochondrial gene cytochrome b in conjunction with
   morphological character analysis, and we inferred phylogenetic
   relationships among species using the cytochrome-b dataset in addition
   to sequences from the mitochondrial genes cytochrome c oxidase subunit
   11 and NADH dehydrogenase 2 for a representative subset of individuals.
   Based on the results of these analyses, we recognize Xerodelphys (new
   subgenus) for T. karimii and T velutinus, and we recognize seven valid
   species in the nominotypical subgenus. The latter includes T. macrurus,
   T pusillus, and two monophyletic species groups: the Elegans Group (T.
   elegans, T T tatei) and the Venustus Group (T. sponsorius, T venustus).
   Analysis of cytochrome-h sequences additionally reveals deep
   phylogeographic structuring in three species (T. pallidior, T. T
   venustus), each of which contains two or three robustly supported
   allopatric haplogroups. The existence of undescribed Peruvian forms of
   the Elegans Group is also plausibly indicated. We provide morphological
   diagnoses of all species recognized as valid in this report, summarize
   information about geographic distributions, comment on previous
   misidentifications, and briefly consider historical-biogeographic
   scenarios with a focus on dispersal events across the Andes.
C1 Giarla, Thomas C.; Univ Minnesota, Dept Ecol Evolut & Behav, 1987 Upper
   Buford Circle, St Paul, MN, USA, USA.
RI Giarla, Thomas/J-8209-2019
OI Giarla, Thomas/0000-0001-7162-7925
