DT Article
TI The taxonomy and paleobiology of the Late Triassic (Carnian-Norian:
   Adamanian-Apachean) drepanosaurs (Diapsida: Archosauromorpha:
   Drepanosauromorpha).
AU Renesto, Silvio
   Spielmann, Justin A.
   Lucas, Spencer G.
   Tarditi Spagnoli, Giorgio
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 46
PS i-ii, 1-81
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Late Triassic (Adamanian-Apachean) drepanosaurs are a group of
   highly specialized, arboreal reptiles with a paleogeographic range
   throughout North America and Western Europe. The seven taxa of
   drepanosaurs we recognize are: Hypuronector limnaios, Dolabrosaurus
   aquatilis, Drepanosaurus unguicaudatus, Megalancosaurus preonensis, M.
   endennae n. sp., Vallesaurus cenensis and V. zorzinensis n. sp. Here we
   review previous studies of drepanosaurs, including recognition that
   Vallesaurus was originally used as a Women nudum by Wild, and correctly
   named by Renesto and Binelli in 2006. Each of the drepanosaur taxa are
   anatomically described, illustrated and taxonomically revised. Previous
   phylogcnetic taxonomies of drepanosaurs are rejected, specifically the
   Glade Avicephala. A new phylogenetic analysis demonstrates numerous
   monophyletic Glades within drepanosaurs and provides nomenclature for
   this taxonomy: Drepanosauromorpha (new Glade): Hypuronector limnaios +
   Elyurosauria; Elyurosauria (new Glade): Vallesaurus (V. cenensis and V.
   zorzinensis n. sp.) + Drepanosauridae; Drepanosauridae: Dolabrosaurus
   aquatilis + Megalancosaurinae; Megalancosaurinae (new dale):
   Drepanosaurus unguicaudatus + Megalancosaurus (M. preonensis and M.
   endennae n. sp.). The stratigraphic distribution of drepanosaurs is from
   late Carnian (Adamanian) in North America to latest Norian/Rhaetian
   (Apachean) in North America and the United Kingdom, with the most
   complete specimens recovered from the Norian (Revueltian) of Northern
   Italy. Analysis of functional morphology confirms the adaptation to
   scansorial, especially arboreal. locomotion in all drepanosaurs,
   including the supposed aquatic taxon Hvpuronector limnaios. Drepanosaurs
   are interpreted as insectivorous, and the notarium-like structure of
   some drepanosaurs, made up of supraneural ossifications, may have been
   related to head projection in prey capture.
C1 Renesto, Silvio; Dipartimento di Biologia Strutturale e Funzionale,
   Universita degli Studi dell'Insubria, via Dunant 3, 21100 Varese, Italy,
   Italy.
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Unavailable
   name; Skeletal and supporting structures; Evolution; Ecology; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Drepanosauridae [Skeleton / Skeletal descriptions & functional
   morphology / taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic
   relationships / ] [Life habit / Mode of life / ] [Triassic / Late
   Triassic / ]. 
   Megalancosaurus endennae; Vallesaurus zorzinensis [Italy /  / new
   species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Thecodontia
OR Dolabrosaurus aquatilis - Berman & Reisz 1992 (Reptilia): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 21; Redescription, P. 21; Fossil]. 
   Drepanosauridae - Berman & Reisz 1992 (Reptilia): [Systematic
   relationships, P. 58; Fossil]. 
   Drepanosauromorpha (Reptilia): [New PhyloCode name, New clade, p. 59;
   Fossil].

   P. 4; Fossil]. 
   Elyurosauria (Reptilia): [New PhyloCode name, New clade, p. 59; Fossil].

   diagnosis, P. 38; Fossil]. 
   Megalancosaurinae (Reptilia): [New PhyloCode name, New clade, p. 59;
   Fossil]. 
   Vallesaurus - Renesto & Binelli 2006 (Reptilia): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   29; Authorship, P. 30; Fossil]. 
   Vallesaurus - Wild 1991 (Reptilia): [Nomen nudum, P. 30; Fossil]. 
   Vallesaurus cenensis - Renesto & Binelli 2006 (Reptilia): [Authorship,
   P. 30; Fossil].

   Fossil].

   diagnosis, P. 9; Fossil]. 
   Megalancosaurus endennae (Thecodontia): [Sp nov, Italy, Triassic, P. 11;
   Fossil]. 
   Megalancosaurus preonensis - Calzavara, Muscio & Wild 1980
   (Thecodontia): [Emended diagnosis, P. 9; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14603024802

DT Article
TI The Stag Beetles of Southern South America (Coleoptera: Lucanidae).
AU Paulsen, M.J. (mpaulsen@unlserve.unl.edu) 
SO Bulletin of the University of Nebraska State Museum
VL 24
PS 1-147
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This monograph is a compilation of original and recent research on
   southern South American stag beetles (Coleoptera: Scarabaeoidea:
   Lucanidae). In the study area, the wholly endemic stag beetle fauna
   includes 31 species in three subfamilies. A key to genera of southern
   South American Lucanidae is provided. Updated information on genera that
   have been recently revised is included. All species are redescribed and
   keys are provided in English and Spanish when appropriate. In the study
   area, the subfamilies Aesalinae and Lampriminae are represented by three
   species of Hilophyllus Paulsen and Mondaca (Ceratognathini) and one
   species of Streptocerus Fairmaire (Lamprimini), respectively. The
   monogeneric tribe Streptocerini Kikuta is placed into synonymy with
   Lamprimini, new synonymy. In the Lucaninae, species from two tribes are
   distributed in southern South America, the Chiasognathini and
   Sclerostomini. The Chiasognathini of the region includes seven species
   of Chiasognathus Stephens. The Sclerostomini of the Lucaninae are
   treated in the following genera: Apterodorcus Arrow (two species),
   Caenolethrus Grossi and Paulsen (one species), Chileistomus Weinreich
   (one species), and Sclerostomulus Weinreich (two species). In addition,
   the genus Pycnosiphorus Solier of the Sclerostomini is revised, and
   morphological and molecular phylogenetic data indicate that two distinct
   groups are present that are here treated as two genera: Pycnosiphorus
   that are fully winged, and Erichius Maes that are flightless
   (brachypterous). The genus Pycnosiphorus now contains two species, P.
   lessonii (Buquet) and P. philippi (Westwood), the former with five
   subspecies, one of which is proposed as new (P. lessonii ugartei, n.
   ssp.). New combinations include: P. lessonii elongatus (Deyrolle) and P.
   lessonii mandibularis (Solier). A neotype is designated for Sclerostomus
   elongatus. Lectotypes are designated for Dorcus lessonii, D.
   mandibularis, Sclerostomus marginipennis Deyrolle, and S. philippi. New
   synonymies include: P. germaini Numhauser is synonymized with P.
   lessonii mandibularis and P. westwoodi Numhauser is synonymized with P.
   philippi. The subgenus Erichius is elevated to generic status and
   contains 12 species, including one new species, E. zabulostictus. One
   species, E. darwinii Hope, n.comb., is valid and is removed from
   synonymy with E. femoralis (Guerin-Meneville), n..comb. Other new
   combinations include: E. brevicollis (Benesh), E. caelatus (Blanchard),
   E. calverti (Nagel), E. costatus (Benesh), E. fairmairii (Parry), E.
   fasciatus (Germain), E. franzae (Weinreich), E. virgatus (Nagel), and E.
   vittatus (Eschscholtz). Two new combinations result from the reduction
   to subspecific status of E. fairmairii arriguttii (Weinreich) and E.
   vittatus magnificus (Benesh). The identities of E. fairmairii (Parry)
   and E. vittatus (Eschscholtz) had been confused with other taxa in the
   literature and are corrected. Neotypes are designated for Dorcus
   leiocephalus Solier, D. pallidocinctus Fairmaire and Germain, D. rouleti
   Solier, D. rufipes Solier, D. rufifemoralis Curtis, Lucanus vittatus
   Eschscholtz, and Sclerostomus calverti Nagel. Lectotypes are designated
   for D. femoralis Guerin-Meneville, D. spinolae Solier, L. caelatus
   Blanchard, L. rubrovittatus Blanchard, L. variolosus Hope, Sclerostomus
   fairmairii Parry, and S. virgatus Nagel. New synonymies include: D.
   rufipes, D. leiocephalus, D. spinolae, and D. modestus Philippi (all
   synonyms of E. darwinii); D. pallidocinctus (synonymized with E.
   femoralis); and D. rouleti (synonymized with E. vittatus). The following
   subgeneric names are synonyms of Erichius: Epipedus Solier, Calvertius
   Maes, and Neoepipedus Ozdikmen and Turgut.

DT Article
TI Faunal composition of subtidal bivalves of the Far Eastern Marine
   Reserve (Peter the Great Bay, Sea of Japan).
AU Lebedev, E.B. (ev-lebedev@mail.ru) 
SO Byulleten' Dal'nevostochnogo Malakologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 14
PS 67-97
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The bivalve molluscan fauna on soft bottom of eastern and southern areas
   of the Far Eastern Marine Biosphere State Natural Reserve (Peter the
   Great Bay, Sea of Japan) has been studied during 2005-2007. Bivalve
   fauna includes 54 species belonging to 22 families and 6 orders. Four
   species, Borniopsis sp., Macoma golikovi Scarlato et Kafanov, 1988, Mya
   japonica Jay, 1856 and Thracia cf. septentrionalis Jeffreys, 1872, are
   recorded in the study area for the first time. Two bivalves, Borniopsis
   sp.and T. cf. septentrionalis are new findings for the fauna of Peter
   the Great Bay. An annotated list of 54 species is presented. The data on
   ecology and distribution and some nomenclatural notes are given.
C1 Lebedev, E.B.; Far Eastern Marine Biosphere State Natural Reserve, Far
   East Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok 690041, Russia,
   Russia.
EM ev-lebedev@mail.ru
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1560-8425

   Reserve / biology; distribution]. 
   Borniopsis; Macoma golikovi; Mya japonica; Thracia [North Pacific /
   Russia, Sea of Japan, Peter the Great Bay / New record].

TI Two new free-living marine nematode species of the genus Vasostoma
   (Comesomatidae) from the Yellow Sea, China.
AU Huang, Yong (huangy@lcu.edu.cn) 
   Wu, Xiuqin
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 1
PS 19-27
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of free-living marine nematodes, Vasostoma longispicula
   sp. nov. and Vasostoma articulata sp. nov. from the Yellow Sea, China,
   are described. Vasostoma longispicula sp. nov. is characterized by its
   large size (2763 x 87 [mu]m, body length x maximum body diameter),
   amphideal fovea with two and a half turns, slender and bent spicules,
   and the number and the arrangement of precloacal supplements. Vasostoma
   articulata sp. nov. is characterized by the slender body and articulated
   spicules.

   China, China.

PT J
AN ZOOR14610065695
DT Article
TI Temporal variability of density and diverse shell occupancy of Diogenes
   pugilator on a sandy bottom of the Levantine Sea and their biometrical
   relationships.
AU Mutlu, Erhan (erhan.mutlu@deu.edu.tr) 
   Ergev, Mehmet Betil
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 1
PS 55-67
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Populations of Diogenes pugilator on the sand bottom of the Eastern
   Mediterranean showed annual density peaks in winter and summer. In a
   two-year period, monthly biomass and abundance did not vary
   statistically. Biomass and abundance ranged from up to 3000 g ha-1 and
   20000 ind ha-1 to almost absence of specimens in autumn. Densities were
   negatively correlated with silt content of the sediment, but not with
   physical parameters of water or other sedimentary characters. Most
   individuals occupied shells of three nassarid gastropod species
   (Nassarius gibbosulus, N. circumcinctus and N. mutabilis) but shells
   from 27 species were found to be utilized. Diversity of the shells was
   variable throughout the year. Total length of the hermit crab accounted
   for 73% of the total variance in the discrimination of shell partition.
   Total lengths spanned to be shorter for the crabs occupying Phorcus
   nuaabilis and Muricopsis cristata than those inside the shells of
   Astraea sp. The shells of some species (Nassarius cuvierii, Ocinebrina
   aciculata, Strombus persicus and Nassarius wolffi) hosted light-weighed
   crabs with low statistical variation on the second component of the
   discriminant distance.
C1 Mutlu, Erhan; Dokuz Eylul Univ, Inst Marine Sci & Technol, Izmir,
   Turkey, Turkey.
EM erhan.mutlu@deu.edu.tr
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0007-9723
BD Ecology; Habitat; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Diogenes pugilator [Population dynamics /  / ] [Marine habitat / Sandy
   marine sediment / ] [Animal remains as habitat / Molluscan shell
   utilization / ] [Mediterranean Sea / Turkey, Mersin Bay / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura

DT Article
TI Molecular data confirm synonymy of Roscovite molgulid ascidians.
AU Shenkar, Noa (nshenkar@u.washington.edu) 
   Swalla, Billie J.
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 1
PS 85-87
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We used molecular data to compare Molgula echinosiphonica
   Lacaze-Duthiers, 1877 from Roscoff, France and Molgula citrina Alder &
   Hancock, 1848 from the eastern coast of the United States and northern
   French Atlantic coast in order to confirm that these described molgulids
   are two populations of the same species, Molgula citrina. First, we
   compared sequences of two nuclear genes, 18S rDNA and 28S rDNA, from
   these species and found that they were 100% identical, indicating a
   single species. Then we reviewed the available literature describing
   their differences and compared them to our recent observations and
   suggest that the described differences may be due to developmental
   plasticity in the species. Molgula citrina (1848) has precedence over M.
   echinosiphonica (1877), so we retained M. citrina for this species. We
   encourage professional taxonomists to consider collaborations using
   molecular markers to solve cases of synonymy in the literature caused by
   phenotypic plasticity and/or doubtful morphological descriptions.
C1 Shenkar, Noa; Univ Washington, Dept Biol, Seattle, WA, USA, USA.
EM nshenkar@u.washington.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0007-9723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Protochordates; Tunicates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Urochordata, Ascidiacea
OR Molgula citrina - Alder & Hancock 1848 (Ascidiacea): [Syn nov, Molgula
   echinosiphonica Lacaze-Duthiers 1877, p. 86]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610065698

TI A new species of Lysianassa Milne Edwards, 1830 (Crustacea: Amphipoda:
   Lysianassidae) from the southwestern Atlantic, with an updated key to
   Brazilian lysianassoid species.
AU Senna, Andre R. (ar.senna@hotmail.com) 
   Souza-Filho, Jesser F.
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 2
PS 129-145
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new lysianassoid amphipod species, Lysianassa temimino sp. nov., is
   described in detail from lower tidal calcareous algae, in Camburi Beach,
   coast of the Brazilian state of Espirito Santo. This species is defined
   by the palm obtuse on gnathopod 2; basis of pereopod 6 with posterior
   margin concave; dorsal margin of body continuously setulose; and telson
   with apical margin slightly concave in male and straight in female.
   Previously, from Brazilian waters, two species of Lysianassa were
   described from Rio de Janeiro coast during the 19th Century - currently
   its type material is considered lost - and one more species was recently
   described from Bahia State coast. A discussion on the relationships
   among the genus and its close related genera, besides the interspecific
   relations in Lysianassa, is included. An identification key for the
   species of the superfamily Lysianassoidea recorded from Brazilian waters
   is also provided.
C1 Senna, Andre R.; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Museu Nacl, Quinta Boa Vista
   S-N, Rio De Janeiro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ar.senna@hotmail.com

TI The genus Amathia Lamouroux (Bryozoa: Ctenostomata) in Iberian waters.
AU Souto, Javier (javiersouto@usc.es) 
   Fernandez-Pulpeiro, Eugenio
   Reverter-Gil, Oscar
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 2
PS 179-195
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Previous records of Amathia in Iberian waters are revised, taking into
   account both existing literature and material held in different
   collections. Two new species are introduced (Amathia delicatula sp. nov.
   and Amathia minoricensis sp. nov.), both originate from the
   Mediterranean. The re-discovery of the original material of Amathia
   semiconvoluta, described by Lamouroux (1824), permitted designation of a
   lectotype and re-description of the species. Finally, our previous
   record of Amathia distans Busk, 1886, is here considered to belong to
   Bowerbankia pustulosa (Ellis & Solander, 1786).

   Compostela, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI A new species of Phyllochaetopterus (Annelida: Chaetopteridae) from
   deep-sea hydrothermal Ashadze-1 vent field, Mid-Atlantic Ridge:
   taxonomical description and partial COI DNA sequence.
AU Morineaux, Marie (marie.morineaux@ifremer.fr) 
   Nishi, Eijiroh
   Ormos, Andrea
   Mouchel, Olivier
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 3
PS 239-248
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Phyllochaetopterus polus, a new species of the polychaete family
   Chaetopteridae is described. Specimens were collected at the Ashadze-1
   vent field (Mid-Atlantic Ridge), from 4100-4200 m depth. P polus is the
   first chaetopterid reported from the Atlantic hydrothermal vents. Three
   chaetopterid species have been recorded from deep-sea hydrothermal vents
   belonging to two genera, Spiochaetopterus and Phyllochaetopterus. P
   polus sp. nov. is a medium-sized chaetopterid, characterized by 9
   chaetigers in region A and 2 in region B; region C is usually incomplete
   in the specimens examined, but has at least 40-70 chaetigers. This
   polychaete has one pair of modified chaetae in chaetiger 4 with a
   pear-shaped obliquely truncated head, triangular uncini and a branched
   annulated tube. The species resembles P lauensis Nishi & Rouse, 2007 in
   most characters but differs by the colour of the ventral shield and tube
   structure. Blast results of a 655 bp fragment of the mitochondrial DNA
   COI gene of this new species revealed Phyllochaetopterids as the closest
   available sequences in Genbank. A phylogenetic tree has been further
   built using all other COI chaetopterid polychaete sequences found in
   Genbank to infer phylogenetic position of the new species. It adds to
   the previous observations of close proximity of communities associated
   to whale falls and hydrothermal vents communities as the
   phylogenetically closest species is an undescribed Phyllochaetopterus
   found around whale fall in Monterey Bay (California).
C1 Morineaux, Marie; IFREMER, Ctr Brest, BP70, Plouzane, France, France.
EM marie.morineaux@ifremer.fr
OI Nishi, Eijiroh/0000-0002-7608-2263
SC Zoology
SN 0007-9723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Phyllochaetopterus polus [North Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Phyllochaetopterus polus (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, North Atlantic, P. 242].
   
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14702010420
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14711081517
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Discovery and description of a new species of Abyssoanthus (Zoantharia:
   Hexacorallia) at the Japan Trench: the world's deepest known zoanthid.
AU Reimer, James D. (jreimer@sci.u-ryukyu.ac.jp) 
   Sinniger, Frederic
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 4
PS 451-457
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Until recently, very little was known about zoanthids (Cnidaria:
   Hexacorallia) from deep-sea environments, with all known specimens
   assigned to the family Epizoanthidae. However, in June 2005 a small
   number of unusual samples of a zoanthid-like species were sampled during
   deep-sea submersible dives (Shinkai 6500 dive # 884) at a methane cold
   seep at 3259 m in the Nankai Trench off Muroto, Japan
   (32[degree]34.945[minute]N-134[degree]41.545[minute]E). Specimens were
   highly divergent in ecology, morphology and molecular phylogeny from all
   known families of zoanthids, and were thus classified as the new species
   Abyssoanthus nankaiensis Reimer & Fujiwara, 2007 belonging to the new
   family Abyssoanthidae. A. nankaiensis is distinguished by its unitary
   polyps, presence at methane cold seeps at extreme depths, and divergent
   phylogenetic status from other zoanthids. Unfortunately, due to
   difficulties in histology and the very small number of specimens, many
   questions remain on the ecology and morphology of A. nankaiensis. From
   images taken during Shinkai 6500 dive # 959 it was hypothesized that
   there were other potential Abyssoanthidae populations at a non-methane
   seep site at the Japan Trench
   (39[degree]06.50[minute]N-143[degree]53.4[minute]E). In October 2007,
   JAMSTEC cruise YK07-15 and the Shinkai 6500 dove to a depth of 5347-5360
   m (dives # 1038 & 1041) at this site to confirm the presence of
   zoanthids. Our molecular (mitochondrial 16S ribosomal DNA) and
   morphological (dimensions, cnidome) findings show a large population of
   a new species, Abyssoanthus convallis, living on mudstone in an
   "ecological hotspot" characterized by large amounts of marine snowfall.
   Specimen polyps in situ were approximately 15-25 mm in height, 5-15 mm
   in diametre, and had 20-30 tentacles. This species of zoanthids
   represents the deepest recorded zoanthid population, and further
   investigations at other hadal sites will increase our knowledge of these
   understudied benthic cnidarians.
C1 Reimer, James D.; Rising Star Program, Transdisciplinary Organization
   for Subtropical Island Sciences, University of the Ryukyus, Senbaru 1,
   Nishihara, Okinawa 901-0213, Japan, Japan.
EM jreimer@sci.u-ryukyu.ac.jp

PT J
AN ZOOR14711081520
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Presence of Abyssoanthus sp. (Anthozoa: Zoantharia) in the Mediterranean
   Sea: an indication of non-dependence of Abyssoanthus to
   chemosynthetic-based ecosystems?
AU Sinniger, Frederic (fredsinniger@hotmail.com) 
   Zelnio, Kevin A.
   Taviani, Marco
   Reimer, James Davis
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 51
IS 4
PS 475-478
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Zoanthids are present in most marine environments, especially where
   there are hard substrates available. A new species, genus and family
   (Abyssoanthus nankainensis Reimer and Fujiwara 2007, family
   Abyssoanthidae) have been recently described from a cold seep setting at
   a depth > 3000 m in the Nankai Trench, Pacific Ocean off Japan. A
   molecularly and morphologically similar zoanthid was also found in the
   Japan Trench and morphologically similar zoanthids were found associated
   with cold seep environments in the Gulf of Mexico (Atlantic Ocean). Some
   minute zoanthid polyps and tissues fragments were collected in 2004 in
   the bathyal plain of the western Mediterranean Sea, in an environment
   not known to be chemosynthetically active. Their minute size (< 2 mm in
   diameter) and sand coating made it impossible to identify these
   specimens morphologically so they were submitted to biomolecular
   analyses. DNA was extracted and the large mitochondrial ribosomal
   subunit gene (mt 16S rDNA) was amplified and sequenced. Surprisingly,
   the sequences obtained showed clear similarities between the deep
   Mediterranean sea zoanthid and the putative cold-seep zoanthid A.
   nankaiensis. Beside documenting an almost cosmopolitan distribution of
   Abyssoanthus these results could indicate (1) the previously uncharted
   presence of a bathyal cold seep site in the western Mediterranean Sea or
   (2) alternatively that this genus is not strictly dependent upon
   chemosynthetic environments. We favour the second hypothesis because the
   possibility of a cold seep setting at this specific Mediterranean site
   does not seem substantiated by any morphological, physical or biological
   evidence.
C1 Sinniger, Frederic; Department of Marine Science, University of the
   Ryukyus, 1 Senbaru, Nishihara, 903-0213 Okinawa, Japan, Japan.
EM fredsinniger@hotmail.com
RI Reimer, James Davis/AAP-1331-2020; Taviani, Marco/AAF-2168-2020; CNR,
   Ismar/P-1247-2014
OI Taviani, Marco/0000-0003-0414-4274; CNR, Ismar/0000-0001-5351-1486;
   Sinniger, Frederic/0000-0002-4175-5931
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0007-9723
BD Habitat; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Abyssoanthus [Marine habitat / Deep sea habitat / Non chemosynthetic
   environment; distribution] [Mediterranean Sea /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Zoanthiniaria
OR Abyssoanthus (Zoanthiniaria). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14711081520
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Elateridae species of Mulsant et al. study, lectotypes designations and
   change of status and combination (Coleoptera: Elateridae).
FT Etude des especes d'Elaterides decrites par Mulsant et al., designation
   des lectotypes, changements de statut et de combinaison (Coleoptera:
   Elateridae).
AU Leseigneur, Lucien (lucien.leseigneur@free.fr) 
SO Cahiers du Musee des Confluences Etudes Scientifiques
VL 1
PS 65-79
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The research of type specimens of the Elateridae family described by E.
   Mulsant et al. permitted to design lectotypes and paralectotypes of all
   species found in several collections in which they were dispersed. Those
   of the Museum d'Histoire naturelle, in Paris are now arranged in-group
   in two easily accessible boxes: one, initially arranged by Renaud
   Paulian in 1943, and another newly composed. Those of the Centre de
   Conservation et d'Etude des Collections, in Lyon remained in their
   original collection (de Freminville-Guillebeau, Foudras and Rey). This
   work made enable some synonyms rectifications and four status
   modification. However, a number of syntypes described species have not
   been found.
C1 Leseigneur, Lucien; 10, rue des Aiguinards, 38240 Meylan, France,
   France.

DT Article
TI [Contribution on the knowledge of Mauesini Lane, 1956 from French Guiana
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).]
FT Contribution a la connaissance des Mauesini Lane, 1956 de Guyane
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Dalens, Pierre-Henri (ph.dalens@laposte.net) 
   Giuglaris, Jean-Louis
   Tavakilian, Gerard Luc
SO Cahiers Magellanes
VL 113
PS 1-10
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus of Mauesini Lane, 1956 is described from French Guiana :
   Trichomauesia n. gen. This genus is characterised by its enlarged and
   hairy first antennal segments, its elytra enlarged apically and its
   narrow tarsi. The type-species, Trichomauesia touroulti n. gen. n. sp.,
   is described and illustrated. The key to the Mauesini genera is updated.
   Datas for Mauesia cornuta Lane, 1956 from French Guiana are gathered,
   the species is illustrated.
C1 Dalens, Pierre-Henri; SEAG, 18 Lotissement Amaryllis, F-97354 Remire
   Montjoly, France, France.
EM ph.dalens@laposte.net

   Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI THE GENUS PSORTHASPIS (HYMENOPTERA: POMPILIDAE) IN COLOMBIA.
AU Rodriguez, Juanita (juanitarodrigueza@gmail.com) 
   von Dohlen, Carol D.
   Pitts, James P.
SO Caldasia
VL 32
IS 2
PS 435-441
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The biodiversity of spider wasps in Psorthapsis occurring in Colombia
   was examined in this study. Three species of this genus were found in
   northern and western Colombia, of which two represent new distributional
   records: Psorthaspis variegata and Psorthaspis connexa are recorded from
   Choco and Magdalena, respectively. A neotype is established for
   Psorthapsis colombiae. The morphological variation, coupled with
   geographic distribution, precludes the division of P. variegata and P.
   connexa into subspecies. A discussion on the status of these subspecies
   is provided. A key to the members of the genus in Colombia also is
   presented.

PT J

DT Article
TI Three new species of Hyphessobrycon group heterorhabdus (Teleostei:
   Characiformes: Characidae) and key to species from the Orinoco river
   basin.
FT TRES NUEVAS ESPECIES DE Hyphessobrycon GRUPO heterorhabdus (TELEOSTEI:
   CHARACIFORMES: CHARACIDAE), Y CLAVE PARA ESPECIES DE LA CUENCA DEL RIO
   ORINOCO.
AU Garcia-Alzate, Carlos A. (cagarcia@uniquindio.edu.co) 
   Roman-Valencia, Cesar
   Prada-Pedreros, Saul
SO Caldasia
VL 32
IS 2
PS 443-461
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the Hyphessobrycon heterorhabdus species group from
   the upper Orinoco River basin, from the Orinoquia region of Colombia,
   are described. Hyphessobrycon mavro sp. n. is distinguished from other
   known Orinoco basin Hyphessobrycon by the following combination of
   characters: four to six teeth in the maxilla, 17 teeth in the dentary,
   snout length 9.9-15.2% of head length and the absence of bony hooks on
   the fins of the males. Hyphessobrycon niger n. sp. can be distinguished
   by the nine teeth in the dentary, five scales with pores in the lateral
   line, 25 to 26 lateral scales, three scales between the lateral line and
   pelvic fins, two scales between the lateral line and the anal fin, and a
   dark lateral line that fuses with a conspicuous peduncular spot.
   Hyphessobrycon acaciae sp. n. can be distinguished by the 14 teeth on
   the dentary, four simple anal-fin rays, and the absence of bony hooks on
   the fins of the mature males. A key to the Orinoco river basin species
   of the Hyphessobrycon heterorhabdus group is included.

   Armenia, Quindio, Colombia, Colombia.

PT J
AN ZOOR14701001838
DT Article
TI RECOVERY POTENTIAL ASSESSMENT FOR SPRING CISCO (COREGONUS SP.).
GP Department of Fisheries and Oceans
SO Canadian Science Advisory Secretariat Science Advisory Report
VL 009
PS 1-9
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In Canada, the only known spring cisco population has been observed at
   Lac des Ecorces (46[degree]31[minute]48[second]N,
   75[degree]25[minute]03[second]W) in the Laurentians (Quebec). Its
   survival and recovery depend on its sustained production within this
   habitat. Reproductive isolation of cisco spring, compared to lake
   herring (C. artedi), and the morphological differences observed support
   its genetic specificity. Despite the uncertainty related to the data,
   the trend over the last fifteen years, between 1994 and 2008, reflect a
   significant decline in the population. A recovery target representing
   40% of the average abundance indices (number of catches per unit effort)
   before the decline during 1990s, or a target of around 5 individuals per
   hour per net, is proposed. The absence of key parameter estimates of
   population dynamics prevents making projections on the development of
   the spring cisco population. Lac des Ecorces, as a unique habitat for
   spring cisco, is essential to the survival and recovery of the species.
   Knowledge about the habitat use by different life stages is still
   incomplete but nothing indicates that some parts of the lake are not
   used. Damage or loss of any and all parts should therefore be avoided.
   The introduction of competing and predatory species, especially rainbow
   smelt, caused changes in the fish community. Predation by rainbow smelt
   on spring cisco larvae in the deeper parts of Lac des Ecorces, raises
   some concern. Controlling the rainbow smelt population could contribute
   to the recovery of spring cisco. Lac des Ecorces has been subject to
   many disturbances due to urban and agricultural development over the
   last 50 years, which has significantly deteriorated the lake and could
   have caused loss of habitat. Although it is difficult to quantify the
   impact, salmonid sensitivity to the degradation of the biophysical
   environment is well known. Measures to mitigate threats to the habitat
   could contribute to the survival and recovery of the species. According
   to current available knowledge and information, the recovery of spring
   cisco remains uncertain, but possible.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation;
   Marine &Freshwater Biology
BD Conservation; Ecology; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lentic water; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America; Canada
DE Coregonus [Conservation measures / Endangered species recovery potential
   assessment / ] [Endangered status /  / ] [Population dynamics /  / ]
   [Lake /  / ] [Quebec / Laurentians, Lac des Ecorces / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Salmoniformes, Salmonidae
OR Coregonus (Salmonidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701001838
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15203015412
DT Article
TI Revision of three large species of Barrettia from Jamaica.
AU Mitchell, Simon (simon.mitchell@uwimona.edu.jm) 
SO Caribbean Journal of Earth Science
VL 41
PS 1-16
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper represents a revision of three multiple-fold hippuritid
   rudist bivalves (Barrettia monilifera Woodward, B. multilirata Whitfield
   and B. gigas Chubb) from the Campanian (late Cretaceous) of Jamaica. The
   differences between the species are investigated using differences in
   the construction of the outer shell layer of the RV, the myocardinal
   arrangement, the size and spacing of the beads in the rays of the RV,
   and the pore system in the LV. Two genera are recognised: Barrettia
   Woodward, type species B. monilifera; and Whitfieldiella gen. nov., type
   species B. gigas. Barrettia is characterised by a small (70-150[degree])
   P2-P1-PM angle, a large (100-200[degree]) P1-PMPT angle, and a
   reticulate pore system; whereas Whitfieldiella is characterised by large
   (170-220[degree]) P2-P1-PM angle, a small (60-90[degree]) P1-PM-PT
   angle, and irregular to denticulate pore clusters on pustules with
   imperforate bands around. The size and spacing of the beads is
   demonstrated to be an important means of distinguishing between species.
   Two species of Barrettia, Barrettia monilifera Woodward and Barrettia
   multilirata Whitfield, and one species of Whitfieldiella, Whitfieldiella
   gigas (Chubb), are recognised. An analysis of the shell microstructure
   of the Caribbean Hippuritidae indicates that this has no value in
   delineating subfamilies; thus Barrettinae Chubb, as revised by Grubic,
   and the recently erected genus Caribbea Grubic (which is synonymised
   with Hippuritella Douville because both have similar pore systems) are
   not recognised. Gloria Grubic is invalid, since the generic name is
   preoccupied by Gloria Barrande; the lack of knowledge of the morphology
   of the myocardinal features and the pore systems in its type species
   Gloria vermunti Grubic (= Pironaea cf. peruviana Vermunt), means that
   this species cannot be placed in a valid genus at the present time.
C1 Mitchell, Simon; Department of Geography and Geology, The University of
   the West Indies, Mona, Kingston 7, Jamaica, Jamaica.
EM simon.mitchell@uwimona.edu.jm
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0799-0901
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Skeletal and supporting
   structures; Shell; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West
   Indies; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Barrettia gigas; Barrettia monilifera; Barrettia multilirata [Shell
   morphology / Shell microstructure / Taxonomic revision] [Jamaica /  / ]
   [Cretaceous / Campanian / ]. 
   Hippuritidae [Shell morphology / Shell microstructure / Systematics;
   American multiple-fold taxa]. 
   Whitfieldiella [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Hippuritoida, Hippuritoidea
OR Barrettia gigas - Chubb 1955 (Hippuritoidea): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Whitfieldiella, p. 13; Fossil]. 
   Barrettia monilifera - Woodward 1862 (Hippuritoidea): [Fossil]. 
   Barrettia multilirata - Whitfield 1897 (Hippuritoidea): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 11; Fossil]. 
   Barrettinae (Hippuritoidea): [Status, P. 3]. 
   Gloria - Grubic 2004 (Hippuritoidea): [Unavailable name, P. 5]. 
   Hippuritella - Douville (Hippuritoidea): [Syn nov, Caribbea Grubic 2004,
   p. 3]. 
   Hippuritidae - Gray 1848 (Hippuritoidea): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, American multiple-fold taxa, p. 10]. 
   Whitfieldiella (Hippuritoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Hippuritidae, Type
   species Barrettia gigas Chubb 1955, p. 13, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Whitfieldiella gigas - (Chubb 1955) (Hippuritoidea): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Barrettia, p. 13]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15203015412

PT J
AN ZOOR14609062878
DT Article
TI Problems in the identity of "Crioceras" barremense Kilian, 1895
   (Ancyloceratida, Late Barremian), and their proposed resolution.
AU Bert, Didier (paleo-db@orange.fr) 
   Busnardo, Robert
   Delanoy, Gerard
   Bersac, Stephane
SO Carnets de Geologie
SU Article 1
PS 1-17
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2010_A01/CG2010_A01.pdf
AW http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2010_A01/CG2010_A01.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of "Crioceras" barremense KILIAN was undertaken as a part of
   the revision of the Hemihoplitidae. This species was considered
   "classic" and has been used as the index of an Upper Barremian subzone;
   this usage raises a number of problems. The type specimen from Tyrol was
   a fragment described and illustrated by UHLIG as Crioceras sp. ind. aff.
   roemeri. This specimen could not be retrieved, and a topotype could not
   be collected. Our study revealed that there is both a biostratigraphic
   hiatus and important differences between conceptions of this species:
   (1) that ascribed UHLIG's type specimen (Upper Barremian, Tyrol), (2)
   KILIAN's concept of the specimen he found and named "Crioceras"
   barremense (probably a Camereiceras from the uppermost levels of the
   Vandenheckei Subzone or from the basal Sartousiana subzone of the Nauvin
   site, southeastern France) and (3) current interpretations of authors,
   who often synonymize the type specimen with Gassendiceras alpinum
   (d'ORBIGNY), which occurs in the middle of the Vandenheckei Subzone. So
   there is a real confusion concerning the synonymy of "Crioceras"
   barremense. The age of UHLIG's type specimen is too imprecise and its
   preservation too fragmentary to be reliably identifiable, because the
   same morphology and ornamentation exist in several species of other
   genera. Therefore, we recommend the use of the species "Crioceras"
   barremense KILIAN be avoided, in particular as an index, along with that
   of the genus Barrancyloceras VERMEULEN for which "C." barremense is used
   as reference. Some species formerly assigned to this genus have been
   referred to the genus Gassendiceras BERT et alii. Consequently, we also
   recommend the Barremense auctorum Subzone be renamed the Alpinum Subzone
   (new) [index-species: Gassendiceras alpinum (d'ORBIGNY)], without
   changing its limits as currently defined. The lower limit of this
   subzone is indicated by the first occurrence of Gassendiceras alpinum (a
   new biohorizon, introduced here), a common, easily identifiable species
   with a well-defined stratigraphic range.
C1 Bert, Didier; Place de l'Eglise, F-04170 La Mure-Argens, France, France.
EM paleo-db@orange.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1634-0744
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Crioceras barremense [France / Alpes-de-Haute Provence, Gorges du Verdon
   / stratigraphical distribution; systematics; taxonomic identity
   clarification] [Cretaceous / Late Barremian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Lytoceratida
OR Leroyceras mascarelli - (Vermeulen 2005) (Ammonoidea): [Junior synonym,
   Of Gassendiceras alpinum (d'Orbigny 1850), p. 5; Fossil]. 
   Barrancyloceras - Vermeulen 2000 (Lytoceratida): [Status, Recommended
   avoidance of usage, p. 7; Fossil]. 
   Crioceras barremense - Kilian in Kilian & Leenhardt 1895 (Lytoceratida):
   [Type material, Type material status assessment, p. 3; Status,
   Recommended avoidance of usage, p. 7; Fossil]. 
   Gassendiceras alpinum - (d'Orbigny 1850) (Lytoceratida): [Senior
   synonym, Of Leroyceras mascarelli (Vermeulen 2005), p. 5; Taxonomic
   position, P. 8; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14609062878
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14704033784
DT Article
TI Systematics, phylogeny and homeomorphy of the Engonoceratidae HYATT,
   1900 (Ammonoidea, Cretaceous) and revision of Engonoceras duboisi LATIL,
   1989.
AU Bujtor, Laszlo (zittelina@t-online.hu) 
SO Carnets de Geologie
SU Article 8
PS 1-31
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2010_A08/CG2010_A08.pdf
AW http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2010_A08/CG2010_A08.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The Engonoceratidae may well have originated on the shallow marine
   carbonate platforms of the southern margin of the Mediterranean Province
   of the Tethyan Realm during the earliest Albian (?latest Aptian). In the
   entire Tethyan Realm and beyond adaptive radiation of the group was
   rapid and successful during the early Albian as indicated by endemic
   centres in the Peruvian Basin and the Western Interior Sea (USA). Later
   the group successfully enlarged its distribution, and invaded some
   provinces (Mowry Sea, Canada) of the Boreal Realm. The mode of life of
   engonoceratids seems to have been nektoplanktonic, epipelagic, and
   stenohaline, restricted to shallow water and platform or in some cases
   extremely shallow (littoral and lagoonal) facies which may have helped
   their radiation. The group is distinctive and consists of nine genera
   and up to a hundred species, although its origin is still obscure. Their
   appearance may have been triggered by the oceanic anoxic event (OAE 1b)
   and their rapid rise may have been helped by their shallow water mode of
   life and the global mid-Cretaceous warming and rise in sea level. The
   fall of the engonoceratids coincides with the end-Cenomanian rapid
   transgression, which may have changed their shallow water habitats.
   Today the group is considered to have been a successful colonizer, a
   reliable stratigraphical indicator for shallow marine environments and a
   pioneer taxon for recognition of transgressive phases. Based on new
   material and sutural analysis, Engonoceras duboisi is revised and
   assigned to Parengo- noceras. A set of features consisting of a
   simplified ceratitid suture, lanceolate and compressed oxycone shell
   together comprising a shallow marine ecotype is pointed out as a
   successful and repeated morphotype among Mesozoic Ammonoidea, for it was
   repeated three times during ammonoid evolution.
C1 Bujtor, Laszlo; 63 Fenyofa Street, H-2030 Erd, Hungary, Hungary.
EM zittelina@t-online.hu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1634-0744
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Evolution; Ecology;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Engonoceratidae [Shell morphology / Homeomorphy / systematics] [Homology
   /  / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Ecology /  / ] [Zoogeography / 
   / ] [Land zones /  / distribution; stratigraphical distribution]
   [Cretaceous / Albian - Cenomanian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Ammonitida
OR Engonoceras duboisi - Latil 1989 (Ammonitida): [Revision, P. 19;
   Referred to, Parengonoceras, p. 21; Fossil]. 
   Engonoceratidae - Hyatt 1900 (Ammonitida): [Fossil]. 
   Parengonoceras duboisi - (Latil 1989) (Ammonitida): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Engonoceras, p. 21; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704033784
OA DOAJ Gold

TI Review of the genus Blitopertha Reitter, 1903 (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae:
   Rutelinae) of the Caucasus and Turkey.
AU Shokhin, I.V. (ishohin@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 6
IS 1
PS 39-43
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Blitopertha Reitter, 1903 is presented in eastern part of its
   geographic areal by two species. Distribution of Blitopertha nigripennis
   (Reitter, 1888) is bordered by the Asian part (from Asia Minor to
   Kopetdagh, including the Caucasus). B. lineolata (Fischer von Waldheim,
   1824) is presented by two subspecies. Distribution of nominative
   subspecies is bordered by South-Eastern Europe from Italy to Lower Don.
   A new subspecies Blitopertha lineolata vanensis ssp. n. is described
   from . Turkey. Diagnostic character of new subspecies is double
   punctuation of pronotum: distance between large punctures is covered by
   dense punctation of small not deep points.

TI A new species and additional records of Carpelimus Leach, 1819 from
   Ukraine (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Oxytelinae).

   Gontarenko, A.V.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 6
IS 1
PS 45-49
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Carpelimus impicus sp. n. from Odessa and Kherson Regions (Ukraine) is
   described and illustrated. Additional records of 17 species of
   Carpelimus Leach, 1819 from Ukraine are presented. Six of them [long
   dash] C. lindrothi lindrothi (Palm, 1943) (Kiev and Chernigov Regions),
   C. ganglbaueri (Bernhauer, 1901) (Kiev Region), C. heidenreichi (L.
   Benick, 1934) (Odessa and Chernigov Regions), C. manchuricus
   subtilicornis (Roubal, 1946) (Transcarpathian Region), C. simplicicollis
   simplicicollis (Wollaston, 1857) (Odessa Region), C. despectus (Baudi,
   1869) (Kiev, Transcarpathian and Lvov Regions) [long dash] are new for
   the country. Moreover, C. ganglbaueri and C. simplicicollis are reported
   from Eastern Europe and the whole of Europe, respectively, for the first
   time.

   Nalassus Mulsant, 1854 of Iran is given in this paper. 6 species of this
   subgenus are known from Iran: N. kabakovi sp. n., N. cambyses (Seidlitz,

   distributed in northern part of Iran (Elburs, Kopet-Dagh). Lectotypes of
   Cylindrinotus heres and Stenomax vexator Reitter, 1887 are designated.

TI To the knowledge of Lepidoptera fauna in the Republic of Mordovia.
AU Bolshakov, L.V. (grigory61@mail.ru) 
   Ruchin, A.B.
   Kurmaeva, D.K.
   Semishin, G.B.
   Polumordvinov, O.A.

VL 6
IS 1
PS 71-84
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The analysis of faunistic study of Lepidoptera in the Republic of
   Mordovia is provided, with 397 species from 41 families taken into
   account from published sources, omitting misidentifications and dubious
   records. A list of 163 species is given, 148 of which are reported as
   new for the republic, while others are interesting from faunistic and
   nature conservation point of view. New synonymy is established in
   Tortricidae: Philedone gerningana gerningana ((Denis et
   Schiffermiiller), 1775) = Ph. gerningana dimitrievi Lastukhin, 2001,
   syn. n.; Endothenia marginana (Haworth, (1811)) = E. attilana Lastukhin,
   2001, syn. n.

DT Article
TI The Rhaphium crassipes species group in the Palearctic Region with the
   description of a new species from Uzbekistan (Diptera: Dolichopodidae).
AU Negrobov, O.P. (ins285@bio.vsu.ru) 
   Grichanov, I.Ya.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 6
IS 1
PS 117-122
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Rhaphium crassipes species group in the Palearctic Region is defined
   and reviewed. It comprises 13 species including one new species. The
   species group is differentiated from other Rhaphium by the male mid
   tarsomeres 4 and 5, which are black, dilated and flattened
   dorsoventrally. New species Rh. samarkandiense Negrobov et Grichanov,
   sp. n. from Uzbekistan is described. Rh. johnrichardi Negrobov et
   Grichanov, nom. nov. (new name for Rh. vockerothi Negrobov, 1979 nec
   Robinson, 1964) is firstly described and illustrated. Rh. viklundi
   Grichanov, 2004 is placed in synonymy to Systenus bipartitus (Loew,
   1850) (syn. n.). A key to the species group is provided, as well as new
   records for known species.
C1 Negrobov, O.P.; Department of Ecology and Systematics of Invertebrate
   Animals, Biological-Soil Sciences Faculty, Voronezh State University,
   Universitetskaya sq. 1, Voronezh 394006, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Achalcus Low, 1857 (Diptera: Dolichopodidae)
   from Far East region of Russia.

DT Article
TI New and little-known taxa of palaearctic soldier-beetles, with taxonomic
   notes (Cantharidae: Coleoptera).
AU Kazantsev, S.V. (kazantss@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 6
IS 2
PS 153-159
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nine new species are described, Ancistronycha antaliensis sp. n. (from
   Turkey), Cantharis gansosichuana sp. n., C. huaemontensis sp. n., C.
   alexandrae sp. n., C. potanini sp. n. (all from China), Podistra
   (Pseudoabsidia) iugosa sp. n. (from Northern Caucasus), P. (Ps.)
   belousovi sp. n. (from Georgia), Rhagonycha bzybiensis sp. n. and Rh.
   prosvirovi sp. n. (both from Abkhasia). Cantharis s. str. faetida
   Menetries, 1832, syn. n. is synonymized with C. rufa Linnaeus, 1758, and
   Rhagonycha anapensis Dahlgren, 1985, syn. n. [long dash] with Rh.
   abchasica Pic, 1900. Cantharis s. str. beckeri (Pic, 1902) is
   transferred to the subgenus Cyrtomoptila Motschulsky, 1860 as Cantharis
   (Cyrtomoptila) beckeri (Pic, 1902), comb. n. Pakabsidia olexai Svihla,
   1983 and Malthodes pseudobesucheti Wittmer, 1970 are reported for the
   ?rst time from Abkhasia, Rhagonycha bernhaueri Wittmer, 1972 [long dash]
   from Abkhasia and Georgia and Rh. rosti Pic, 1900 [long dash] from
   Ukraine (Crimea).
C1 Kazantsev, S.V.; Donetskaya Str., 13-326, Moscow 109651, Russia, Russia.

TI Chalepoxenus hyrcanus - a new ant species (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from
   Azerbaijan.
AU Dubovikoff, D.A. (dubovikoff@gmail.com) 
   Radchenko, A.G.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 6
IS 2
PS 207-208
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new ant species, Chalepoxenus hyrcanus sp. n., is described based on a
   queen from Azerbaijan (Talysh Mts.). This is the ninth known species of
   socially- parasitic genus Chalepoxenus Menozzi, 1923. In Appendix
   measurements of the holotype Ch. zabelini Radchenko, 1989 are given.

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027304
DT Article
TI A new genus of Medeterinae (Diptera: Dolichopodidae) from Baltic amber.
AU Grichanov, I. Ya. (grichanov@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 6
IS 2
PS 209-212
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus, Medeterites gen. n. (Diptera: Dolichopodidae: Medeterinae)
   is described from Baltic amber with one included species, Medeterites
   molestus (Meunier, 1907) (hrypticus), comb. n. he genus is similar to
   the genera of the subfamily Medeterinae, but having such plesiomorphic
   characters as big palpus, lack of acrostichals, legs devoid of long
   bristles, wing with long R1 and straight and subparallel R4+5 and M1+2,
   globular epandrium, big and rounded circus, etc. A key is compiled to
   all dolichopodid genera from Baltic amber with apical arista-like
   stylus.
C1 Grichanov, I. Ya.; All-Russian Institute of Plant Protection, Podbelskiy
   roadway, 3, St. Petersburg, Pushkin 196608, Russia, Russia.
EM grichanov@mail.ru
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Key; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary
DE Dolichopodidae [Palaeogene /  / Key to genera]. 
   Medeterites [Palaeogene /  / New genus]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Dolichopodidae
OR Dolichopodidae (Orthorrhapha): [Key to genera, Palaeogene, From Balitc
   Amber, p. 211; Fossil]. 
   Medeterites (Dolichopodidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Medeterinae, Type
   species Thrypticus molestus Meunier 1907, p. 209, Palaeogene; Fossil]. 
   Medeterites molestus - (Meunier 1907) (Dolichopodidae): [Redescription,
   P. 210; Comb nov, Transferred from Thrypticus, p. 210]. 
   Thrypticus molestus - Meunier 1907 (Dolichopodidae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Medeterites, p. 209].

TI [Contribution to the knowledge on the genus Leucocelis Burmeister
   (Coleoptera, Cetoniidae, Cetoniinae).]
FT Contribution a la connaissance du genre Leucocelis Burmeister
   (Coleoptera, Cetoniidae, Cetoniinae).
AU Antoine, Philippe (ph.m.antoine@club-internet.fr) 
SO Cetoniimania
VL 1
PS 14-20
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The type locality of Leucocelis lucidicollis (Gerstaecker) is precised;
   Leucocelis haemorrhoidalis kolbei Ruter is synonymized with this taxon
   which is recognized as a good species, not a subspecies of Leucocelis
   haemorrhoidalis (Fabricius). A new species, Leucocelis
   (Amauroleucocelis) leonardi, is described from Burundi and a new
   subspecies, Leucocelis niansana giannatelli, is described from Eritrea.

   species is recorded for the first time from this country.

PT J
AN ZOOR14702016268
DT Article
TI Distinctiveness of termite assemblages in two fragmented forest types in
   Hantane hills in the Kandy district of Sri Lanka.
AU Hemachandra, I.I. (iindujinah@yahoo.com) 
   Edirisinghe, J.P.
   Karunaratne, W.A.I.P.
   Gunatilleke, C.V.S.
SO Ceylon Journal of Science Biological Sciences
VL 39
IS 1
PS 11-19
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study compares the termite assemblages in a natural and a secondary
   forest located at two different elevations in the Hantane hills, a
   tropical evergreen forest in mid country Sri Lanka, with a view to
   identify their distinctiveness. To sample the termites in the two forest
   types the belt transect method was used supplemented by random
   collections. A total of 11 species of termites in four genera belonging
   to three subfamilies and one family, Termitidae were recorded; nine
   species from the secondary forest and two species from the natural
   forest. The two species, Ceylonitermellus hantanae and Dicuspiditermes
   incola showed a distinct distribution in being confined only to the
   natural forest at high elevation. Termites recorded were put into
   feeding groups based on their taxonomic identity. Termites of the
   natural forest were found to be exclusively true soil feeders. Those of
   the secondary forest were wood feeders; either fungus growing (8 spp.)
   or non-fungus growing wood feeders (1 sp.). The high abundance and low
   diversity of the natural forest termite species in comparison to
   secondary forest species also make them distinct. Elevation, climate,
   vegetation, ground cover and the degree of human interference appear to
   contribute to the distinctiveness of termite assemblages in the two
   forests types reported here.
C1 Hemachandra, I.I.; Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, University
   of Peradeniya, Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka.
EM iindujinah@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 0069-2379
BD Ecology; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Nasutitermes fletcheri [Sri Lanka /  / New record]. 
   Termitidae [Community structure /  / ] [Forest and woodland / Natural &
   secondary forest fragment / ] [Sri Lanka / Kandy, Hantane / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Isoptera
OR Nasutitermes fletcheri (Isoptera): [New record]. 
   Termitidae (Isoptera).

PT J
AN ZOOR14707053280
DT Article
TI Taruga (Anura: Rhacophoridae), a new genus of foam-nesting tree frogs
   endemic to Sri Lanka.
AU Meegaskumbura, Madhava (madhava_m@mac.com) 
   Meegaskumbura, Suyama
   Bowatte, Gayan
   Manamendra-Arachchi, Kelum
   Pethiyagoda, Rohan
   Hanken, James
   Schneider, Christopher J.
SO Ceylon Journal of Science Biological Sciences
VL 39
IS 2
PS 75-94
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Phylogenetic relationships among foam-nesting clades of Old World tree
   frogs are analyzed using both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA data, with
   particular focus on Sri Lankan members of the genus Polypedates. A
   distinctive, highly supported endemic Sri Lankan clade is identified,
   and recognized as a new genus, Taruga. This clade, which had previously
   been assigned to the genus Polypedates, includes P. eques, P. fastigo
   and P. longinasus. A combination of characters distinguishes adult
   Taruga from Polypedates: Taruga possess a dorsolateral glandular fold
   that extends from the posterior margin of the upper eyelid to the
   mid-flank (vs. a supratympanic fold that curves over the dorsal margin
   of the tympanic membrane in Polypedates); a prominent calcar at the
   distal end of the tibia (absent in most Polypedates); a more acutely
   pointed snout; and 6[long dash]10 prominent conical tubercles
   surrounding the cloaca (absent in Polypedates). Tadpoles of Taruga eques
   and Polypedates cruciger are distinguished by several characters,
   including features of the buccal cavity and the form of the vent tube.
   Taruga is the sister group of the remaining Polypedates sensu stricto.
C1 Meegaskumbura, Madhava; Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science,
   University of Peradeniya, Sri Lanka, Sri Lanka.
EM madhava_m@mac.com

PT J
AN ZOOR14702010314
DT Article
TI Mesozooplankton and Ichthyoplankton composition in two tropical
   estuaries of Bahia, Brazil.
AU Marcolin, Catarina da Rocha (crmarcolin@yahoo.com.br) 
   da Conceicao, Barbara Luciana
   Nogueira, Marcos Moura
   Mafaldason-Junior, Paulo
   Johnsson, Rodrigo
SO Check List
VL 6
IS 2
PS 210-216
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.checklist.org.br/archive?vol=6&num=2
AW http://www.checklist.org.br/getpdf?SL062-09
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The objective of this study was to describe the composition of two
   mesozooplankton and ichthyoplankton estuarine communities in Jandaira,
   Bahia (Tabatinga River), impacted by a shrimp farm; and in Conde, Bahia
   (Itapicuru River), a pristine estuary. Samples were collected through
   horizontal hauls using a net (200 [mu]m mesh size), coupled to a
   flowmeter, during the ebbing and flooding tides in April, August and
   December, 2007. In the Tabatinga and Itapicuru Rivers 76 and 92 taxa
   were registered. The most abundant groups were Pseudodiaptomus richardii
   and Disco sp. Acartia lilljeborgi was also dominant at Tabatinga, while
   Temora sp. and decapod larvae were predominant in Itapicuru River, which
   also presented higher densities for most planktonic taxa, particularly
   fish larvae. A descriptive analysis of the main taxa's spatial
   distribution and new geographical records of Disco sp., P. richardi,
   Pontellopsis villosa, Macrosetella gracilis, Microsetella rosea,
   Gonyiopsillus hrasiliensis, Agetusflaccus and Frgasilus
   earaguatatuhensis were presented.
C1 Marcolin, Catarina da Rocha; Universidade Federal de Bahia, Campus de
   Ondina, Instituto de Biologia, Departamento de Zoologia, LABIMAR
   (Crustacea, Cnidaria e Fauna Associada), CEP 40170-110, Salvador, BA,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM crmarcolin@yahoo.com.br

SN 1809-127X

    / ] [Brazil / Bahia, Jandaira & Conde / ]. 
   Crustacea [Community structure /  / New record; records; plankton]
   [Estuary /  / ] [Brazil / Bahia, Jandaira & Conde / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Crustaceans; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates

   Crustacea (Arthropoda): [New record]. 
   Pisces (Vertebrata).

DT Article
TI Crustacea, Isopoda, Oniscidea Latreille, 1802: new continent record and
   distribution extension in Brazil.
AU Magrini, Mariana Juventina (muprado@yahoo.com) 
   Araujo, Paula Beatriz
   Uehara-Prado, Marcio
SO Check List
VL 6
IS 2
PS 217-219
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.checklist.org.br/archive?vol=6&num=2
AW http://www.checklist.org.br/getpdf?NGD093-09
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Terrestrial Isopods were sampled in four protected Atlantic Forest areas
   located in Serra do Mar, state of Sao Paulo, southeastern Brazil. A
   total of 2,217 individuals of six species (Atlantoscia sp., Benthana
   werneri, Pseudodiploexochus tabularis, Pudeoniscus obscurus, Styloniscus
   spinosus and Trichorhina sp.) were captured in pitfall traps. The exotic
   species S. spinosus is recorded for the first time for the Americas.
   Another introduced species, P. tabularis, previously recorded only from
   the state of Rio Grande do Sul, had its geographic distribution extended
   to the state of Sao Paulo. The most abundant isopods in this study
   belong to an undescribed species of Atlantoscia.
C1 Magrini, Mariana Juventina; Universidad Estadual de Campinas, Instituto
   de Biologia, Departamento de Zoologia, CP 6109, CEP 13084-971, Campinas,
   SP, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea Carus, 1863: distribution extension
   in Argentina and new Anura and Ophidia hosts.
AU Lunaschi, Lia Ines (lunaschi@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Drago, Fabiana Beatriz
SO Check List
VL 6
IS 3
PS 447-450
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.checklist.org.br/archive
AW http://www.checklist.org.br/getpdf?NGD062-10
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The aim of this paper is to increase the knowledge on the diversity of
   digenean parasites in ophidians and anurans from northeastern Argentina.
   Specimens of the snakes Eunectes notaeus, Hydrodynastes gigas, Micrurus
   corallinus, Philodryas sp. and Sibynomorphus sp., and the anurans
   Rhinella schneideri, Phyllomedusa azurea and Leptodactylus latrans were
   examined. Twelve digenean species were identified: Catadiscus corderoi
   Mane-Garzen, 1958, Catadiscus dolichocotyle (Cohn, 1903), Catadiscus
   uruguayensis Freitas & Lent, 1939, Choledocystus elegans (Travassos,
   1926), Gorgoderina parvicava Travassos, 1922, Haplometroides buccicola
   Odhner, 1911, Heterodiplostomum lanceolatum Dubois, 1936, Infidum
   similis Travassos, 1916, Mesocoelium monas (Rudolphi, 1819), Plagiorchis
   luehei (Travassos, 1927), Telorchis clava (Diesing, 1850) and. T-
   avtrema stenocotvle (Cohn. 1902). New host species and/or new locality
   records from Argentina are presented.
C1 Lunaschi, Lia Ines; Museo de La Plata, Laboratorio de Helmintologia,
   Paseo del Bosque s/no, 1900 La Plata, Buenos Aires, Argentina,
   Argentina.

   nigrilimbata Jing 1986, p. 80].

PT J
AN ZOOR14803026709
DT Article
TI Chytridiomycosis - a mortal danger for amphibians.
FT Chytridiomikoza - smiertelne zagroienie dla plazow.
AU Sura, Piotr (psura@cm-uj.krakow.pl) 
   Janulis, Ewelina
   Profus, Piotr
SO Chronmy Przyrode Ojczysta
VL 66
IS 6
PS 406-421
PD listopad-grudzien 2010
PY 2010
LA Polish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) named in 1999, is a chytrid fungus
   that causes chytridiomycosis in amphibians and is a proximate driver of
   declines in global amphibian biodiversity. Its life cycle starts within
   the host epidermal cells where a zoospore forms a spherical thallus,
   which matures and produces new zoospores by dividing asexually. Then
   zoospores are released to the skin surface renewing the cycle of
   infection. It is believed that Bd may cause hyperkeratosis, thereby
   impeding respiration or water balance, or hosts might be poisoned'by a
   fungal toxin. Bd infects an extraordinarily broad diversity of host
   species of both larval, juvenile, and adult stages, and appears to have
   the widest host range of any known pathogen being found on all
   continents except Antarctica. This observation is consistent with the
   argument that Bd is a recently evolved generalist emerging pathogen. Bd
   is diploid and highly heterozygous suggesting that the globalized
   lineage is the product of a mating between two nonidentical but closely
   related, heterothallic, parental strains. Bd infection was present in
   Xenopus spp. across sub-Saharan Africa by the 1930s, providing
   additional support for the 'out of Africa' hypothesis. Current evidence
   suggests that the world trade in amphibians, especially Xenopus leavis
   and Litho bates castesbeianus, has been a cause of a dynamic spread of
   the disease to new areas. Some species may serve as disease reservoirs
   because they can carry Bd infections without morbidity. This year this
   invasive fungus was for the first time identified in Poland. The
   German-Swiss research team examined 161 samples, of which 29 green frogs
   Pelophylax sp. collected in 5 sampling sites in Poland were infested (T.
   Ohst - pers. comm).
C1 Sura, Piotr; Zaktad Biologii Rozwoju Cztowieka Collegium Medicum,
   Uniwersytet lagielloriski, ul. 31[long dash]034 Krakow, ul. Kopernika 7,
   Poland, Poland.
EM psura@cm-uj.krakow.pl
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Infectious Diseases; Mycology
SN 0009-6172
BD Animals and man; Disturbance by man; Commercial activities; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Diseases and disorders; Microbial diseases; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Amphibia [Trade in animals /  / pathology; prevalence] [Fungal diseases
   / Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis / ]. 
   Pelophylax [Fungal diseases / Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis / New
   record] [Poland /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Amphibia (Vertebrata). 
   Pelophylax (Ranidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI New species of New World Tambiniini from palms (Hemiptera: Fulgoroidea,
   Tropiduchidae).
AU O'Brien, Lois B. (lbobrien@cox.net) 
SO Cicadina
VL 11
PS 3-12
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new genus and species, Diambon remanei nov gen. nov. spec. from
   Trinidad and two new species of Athestia Melichar, 1914, A. excelsa nov.
   spec. from Mexico and A. aschei nov. spec. from Argentina, are described
   and illustrated. Biruga Fennah, 1944 is resurrected with its
   type-species B. chapadae. The genus Athestia is redescribed, and the
   genera and species of New World Tambiniini are keyed. All of the new
   species were collected from palms.

AN ZOOR14702016469
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI SNAKE FOSSIL REMAINS FROM THE MIDDLE MIOCENE STRATIGRAPHIC SERIES OF
   ABOCADOR DE CAN MATA (ELS HOSTALETS DE PIEROLA, CATALONIA, SPAIN).
AU Carmona, Raul (raul.carmona@fossilia.com) 
   Alba, David M.
   Delfino, Massimo
   Robles, Josep M.
   Rotgers, Cheyenn
   Mengual, Juan V. Berto
   Balaguer, Jordi
   Galindo, Jordi
   Moya-Sola, Salvador
SO Cidaris
VL 30
PS 77-83
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Very few studies have been devoted to the Miocene snakes from Catalonia.
   Here we report the preliminary taxonomic attribution of ophidian
   vertebral remains from several middle Miocene (MN 7 and MN 8) localities
   of the stratigraphic series of Abocador de Can Mata (els Hostalets de
   Pierola, Spain): C2-B3, C3-A7, C3-B3, BCV1, C4-A1, C5-C3. Two taxa are
   identi? ed: Naja sp. and "Colubrinae" indet. This constitutes the first
   citation of cobras from the Valles-Penedes Basin, being indicative of a
   warm climate. A more precise taxonomic attribution is hampered by the
   fragmentary preservation of the available remains and the small size of
   the sample. We hope that this contribution will constitute a starting
   point for a renewed interest on the study of Miocene snakes from
   Catalonia.
C1 Carmona, Raul; FOSSILIA Serveis Paleontologics i Geologics, S.L. c/
   Jaume I 87, 1er 5a Sant Celoni, Barcelona, Spain, Spain.
EM raul.carmona@fossilia.com

   Paleontology
SN 1134-5179

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene

   new record; systematics] [Environmental indicators / Palaeoenvironmental
   indicators / ] [Spain / Catalonia, Valles-Penedes basin / distribution;
   stratigraphical distribution] [Miocene / Middle Miocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

TI MAB-5: A NEW FIELD OF FOSSILS MAMMALS FROM THE MN4 OF THE
   RIBESALBES-ALCORA (CASTELLON) BASIN.
FT MAB-5: UN NUEVO YACIMIENTO DE MICROMAMIFEROS FOSILES DE LA MN4 EN LA
   CUENCA DE RIBESALBES-ALCORA (CASTELLON).
AU Ruiz-Sanchez, Francisco Javier (francisco.ruiz@uv.es) 
   Crespo-Roures, Vicente Daniel
   Furio, Marc
   Mansino, Samuel
   Freudenthal, Matthijs
   Montoya, Plinio
SO Cidaris
VL 30
PS 279-282
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report a preliminary study of fossil rodents fauna from the locality
   MAB-5 (Ribesalbes-Alcora Basin, Castellon). The preliminary faunal list
   contains Democricetodon/Fahlbuschia sp., Megacricetodon cf. primitivus,
   Glirudinus cf. modes- tus, Microdyromys sp., Pseudodryomys cf. julii,
   Myomiminae indet., Ligerimys ellipticus and Sciuridae indet. As well as
   rodents, MAB-5 has yielded fossil remains of two different
   insectivorous. The age of MAB-5 is lower Aragonian (zone C, MN4).

DT Article
TI [Revision of the genus Conognatha Eschscholtz, 1829.]
FT Revision du genre Conognatha Eschscholtz, 1829.
AU Moore, Tomas
   Lander, Tieri
SO Collection Systematique
VL 24
PS 1-170
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Conognatha Eschscholtz (s. str. ) and subgenus Pithiscus Solier are
   revised. 25 species and one subspecie of Conognatha (Conognatha) are
   recognized. 54 species and four subspecies of Conognatha (Pithiscus) are
   recognized. Two species are new : C. (C.) surinamensis n. sp. and C.
   (P.) celineae n. sp. 14 new synonymies are proposed for the Conognatha
   (Conognatha) : C. abdominalis Waterhouse = C. rufiventris weyrauchi
   Cobos; C. amoena (Kirby) = C. gracilis (Gory & Laporte), C. biocularis
   Thomson, C. cornitessa Thomson, C. amphititres Cobos; C. haemorrhoidalis
   (Olivier) = C, jucunda (Kirby); C. impressipennis Saunders = C.
   proserpina Thomson; C. interrupta Waterhouse = C. kerremansis Nonfried;
   C. iris iris (Olivier) = C. iris cayennensis Cobos; C. iris vargasi
   (Rojas) = C. iris variabilis Hoscheck; C. magnifica (Gory & Laporte) =
   C. ampliata Hoscheck; C. splendens Water-house = C. prosternalis
   Hoscheck, C. blairi Hoscheck, C. neutra Hoschek. Six new synonymes are
   proposed for the Conognatha (Pithiscus) : C. (P.) elongata (Kerremans) =
   C. gibbula Rothkirch; C. (P.) excellens (Klug) = C. schreiberti
   (Rothkirch); C. (P.) fasciata (Gory & Laporte) = C. fascipennis
   Kerremans; C. (P.) macleayi (Donovan) = C. vulnerata (Perty); C. (P.)
   militaris Saunders = C. nigrocoerulea Kerremans; C. (P.) viridiventris
   viridiventris (Solier) = C. rubini Kogan. Three species are revalided :
   C. (C.) batesi Saunders, C. (P.) elongata Kerremans and C. (P.) thoreyi
   (Chevrolat). 8 Lectotypes are designated for : C. buqueti (Gory &
   Laporte); C. ovatula Hoscheck; C. pretiosissima (Chevrolat); C.
   splendens Waterhouse; C. (P.) errata (Fairmaire); C. (P.) excellens
   (Klug); C. (P) quadrizonata Nonfried (syn. de C. (P.) sellovii (Klug));
   C. (P.) nigrocoerulea (Kerremans) (syn. nov. de C. (P.; sellovii
   (Klug)). Five Paralectotypes are designated for : C. buqueti (Gory &
   Laporte); C. ovatula Hoscheck; C. (P. ) errata (Fairmaire); C. (P.)
   nigrocoerulea (Kerremans) (syn. nov. of C. (P.) sellovii (Klug)).C.
   buqueti (Gory & Laporte). Diagnoses is provided for all species. Male
   genitalia are illustrated. Colour pictures of dorsal view are given,
   with a representative range of infraspecific variety. An identification
   key is provided.
C1 Moore, Tomas; el Vergel 2245, Depto 28-D, Santiago, Chile, Chile.
SC Zoology

   nov, Conognatha (Conognatha) iris variabilis Hoscheck 1934, p. 74]. 
   Conognatha (Conognatha) magnifica - (Gory & Laporte 1838) (Buprestidae):
   [Syn nov, Conognatha ampliata Hoscheck 1934, p. 76].

DT Article
TI [Revision of the genus Zonopterus Hope and related genera (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Callichromatini).]
FT Revision du genre Zonopterus Hope et des genres voisins (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae, Callichromatini).
AU Bentanachs, Joan (jentanachs@hotmail.com) 
   Morato, Jeannine
   Vives, Eduard
SO Collection Systematique
VL 23
PS 1-51
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genera Zonopterus Hope, Huedepohliana Heffern and Thompsoniana
   Podany are revised. Zonopteroides Podany is considered as a genus to
   include Zonopterus diversus Gahan. Two new genus are described :
   Pseudoeuchitonia nov. gen to include Zonopterus grandis Thomson,
   Thompsoniana triochreofasciata Hayashi and Psuedoeuchitonia barbarae
   nov. sp., and Moratichroma nov. gen. to includ Zonopterus magnificus
   Bates. Some species are considered as synonyms : Zonopterus perversus
   Ritsema, 1914 with Z. corbetti Gahan, 1906, Euchitonia constanzae
   Hudepolh, 1983 with Pseudoeuchitonia triochreofasciata (Hayashi, 1979),
   Zonopterus pukher Podan, 1968 with Pseudoeuchitonia grandis Thomson,
   1878) and Zonopterus bosschae Ritsema, 1894 with Moratichroma magnifica
   (Bates, 1889).

   s/n, 08003 Barcelona, Spain, Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR14705040728
DT Article
TI Boreonectes gen. n., a new genus for the Stictotarsus griseostriatus (De
   Geer) group of sibling species (Coleoptera: Dytiscidae), with additional
   karyosystematic data on the group.
AU Angus, R.B. (r.angus@rhul.ac.uk) 
SO Comparative Cytogenetics
VL 4
IS 2
PS 123-131
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new genus, Boreonectes gen. n., is erected for the seven S.
   griseostriatus-group species as well as eight other American ones listed
   by Nilsson and Angus (1992) as comprising the Stictotarsus
   griseostriatus-group as DNA work by Ribera (2003) shows this arrangement
   to be untenable, and no other genus-group name has been found to be
   available. Chromosomal investigations have shown that B. griseostriatus
   (De Geer, 1774) occurs as far west as the Little St Bernard Pass in the
   Alps, with B. alpestris (Dutton et Angus, 2007) in the Italian Gran
   Paradiso National Park to the south of this. B. multilineatus
   (Falkenstrom, 1922) is recorded from the Pyrenees for the first time,
   and B. ibericus (Dutton et Angus, 2007) is shown to be present in the
   Moyen Atlas of Morocco.
C1 Angus, R.B.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Entomol, Cromwell Rd, London, United
   Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM r.angus@rhul.ac.uk
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 1993-0771; 1993-078X

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Genetics; Cytogenetics; Chromosomes; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Boreonectes alpestris; Boreonectes griseostriatus [Europe / Alps / New
   record].

   [Europe /  / distribution]. 
   Boreonectes multilineatus [Europe / Pyrenees / New record].

AN ZOOR14605034330
DT Article
TI A new species of Lissorchis (Trematoda: Lissorchiidae) from Creek
   chubsuckers (Erimyzon oblongus) in the Big Thicket National Preserve,
   Texas, USA.
AU Barger, Michael A. (mbarger@peru.edu) 
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 1-5
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Lissorchis amniculensis n. sp. is described from the small intestine of
   creek chubsuckers collected from a small tributary stream of Big Sandy
   Creek in the Big Sandy Creek Unit of the Big Thicket National Preserve,
   Polk County, Texas, U.S.A. Members of the new species possess a distinct
   trilobed ovary, a feature found in individuals of 9 other species of
   Lissorchis. The new species is distinguished from these species by
   possessing a bipartite seminal vesicle with the distal portion larger
   than the proximal portion, vitelline follicles that extend beyond the
   posterior extent of the testes, a small posttesticular space, and a
   single dextral uterine loop that originates from the posttesticular
   space.
C1 Barger, Michael A.; Peru State Coll, Dept Nat Sci, Peru, NE, USA, USA.
EM mbarger@peru.edu
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1525-2647

   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Erimyzon oblongus [Digenean parasites / Lissorchis amniculensis / New
   parasite species] [Texas /  / New platyhelminth parasite species]. 
   Lissorchis amniculensis [Piscean hosts / Erimyzon oblongus / New
   parasite species] [Texas /  / New species from piscean host]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates

   Cypriniformes, Catostomidae, Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea

   oblongus (Pisces), p. 1; Parasite].

DT Article
TI A new species of Caecincola (Trematoda: Cryptogonimidae) from spotted
   bass (Micropterus punctulatus) in the Big Thicket National Preserve,
   Texas, USA.
AU Barger, Michael A. (mbarger@peru.edu) 
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 6-8
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Caecincola autumnae n. sp. is described from the pyloric ceca of spotted
   bass (Micropterus punctulatus) collected from Big Sandy Creek in the Big
   Sandy Creek Unit of the Big Thicket National Preserve, Polk County,
   Texas, U.S.A. It can be distinguished from all other species of
   Caecincola by the presence of an ovary with 4 lobes and a narrowly
   obpanduriform to narrowly obpyriform body.

DT Article
TI Three new species of Syphacia (Syphacia) (Oxyurida: Oxyuridae) from
   Queensland, Australia, and a key to the species present in the
   Australian bioregion.
AU Weaver, Haylee J. (haylee.weaver@anu.edu.au) 
   Smales, Lesley R.
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 9-19
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Three new species of Syphacia Seurat 1916 (Oxyurida: Oxyuridae) are
   described from rodents (Rodentia: Muridae) in Queensland, Australia.
   Syphacia (Syphacia) helidonensis n. sp. from Pseudomys gracilicaudatus
   (Gould 1845) can be distinguished from all other species by a suite of
   characters including an oval-shaped cephalic plate, elongated laterally
   with dorso-ventral constriction at the level of laterally placed amphids
   and cephalic papillae, lateral but not cervical alae, and a single pair
   of postanal papillae. Syphacia (Syphacia) boodjamullaensis n. sp. from
   Zyzomys argurus (Thomas, 1889) also has an oval-shaped cephalic plate,
   elongated laterally with dorso-ventral constriction at the level of
   laterally placed amphids and cephalic papillae, a single pair of
   postanal papillae, neither cervical nor lateral alae, and spicule 77
   [mu]m long. Syphacia (Syphacia) carnarvonensis n. sp. from Pseudomys
   delicatulus (Gould, 1842) with an oval-shaped cephalic plate, elongated
   laterally with dorso-ventral constriction at level of laterally placed
   amphids and cephalic papillae and a single pair of postanal papillae,
   also has both cervical and lateral alae, small body size, males 690-865
   [mu]m, and eggs 77-86 [mu]m long, 24-29 [mu]m wide. A key to the species
   of Syphacia from the Australian Bioregion is given, and the potential
   for as yet undiscovered species in the region is discussed.
C1 Weaver, Haylee J.; Australian Natl Univ, Natl Ctr Epidemiol & Populat
   Hlth, GPO Box 4, Canberra, ACT, Australia, Australia.
EM haylee.weaver@anu.edu.au
RI Weaver, Haylee/A-1467-2012

   and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
