PT J
AN ZOOR14605034333
DT Article
TI Pseudocapillaria (Ichthyocapillaria) nannupensis n. sp (Nematoda:
   Capillariidae) from the Intestine of the Freshwater Cobbler Tandanus
   bostocki (Plotosidae) from southwestern Australia.
AU Hobbs, Russell P. (russ.hobbs@murdoch.edu.au) 
   Hassan, Marina
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 20-24
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Pseudocapillaria nannupensis n. sp. (Nematoda: Capillariidae) is
   described from the intestine of the freshwater cobbler, Tandanus
   bostocki (Plotosidae) from the Blackwood River in the southwest of
   Australia. Although there have been 7 species of capillariids described
   from teleost fishes in Australia, this is the first species belonging to
   the genus Pseudocapillaria. The presence of a dorsal cuticular membrane
   in the mate places this species in the subgenus Ichthyocapillaria.
   However, the dorsal cuticular membrane is only very small, so there are
   also some similarities with members of the subgenus Pseudocapillaria. It
   resembles Pseudocapillaria indica but differs by the larger size of the
   eggs, by the reticulated surface structure of the eggs, and by the
   larger spicule. It differs from Pseudocapillaria tomentosa by the
   structure of the proximal spicule rim and in having a vulval opening
   closer to the esophago-intestinal junction. It differs from
   Pseudocapillaria salvelini by the structure of the proximal spicule rim,
   in having a vulval opening closer to the esophago-intestinal junction,
   and by having a much shorter dorsal cuticular membrane.
C1 Hobbs, Russell P.; Murdoch Univ, Sch Vet & Biomed Sci, Murdoch, WA,
   Australia, Australia.
EM russ.hobbs@murdoch.edu.au
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1525-2647
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Pseudocapillaria (Ichthyocapillaria) nannupensis [Piscean hosts /
   Tandanus bostocki / New parasite species] [Western Australia /  / New
   species from piscean host]. 
   Tandanus bostocki [Nematode parasites / Pseudocapillaria
   (Ichthyocapillaria) nannupensis / New parasite species] [Western
   Australia /  / New nematode parasite species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Plotosidae, Nematoda
OR Tandanus bostocki (Plotosidae): [Host]. 
   Pseudocapillaria (Ichthyocapillaria) nannupensis (Nematoda): [Sp nov,
   Western Australia, Parasite of Tandanus bostocki (Pisces), p. 21;
   Parasite].

PT J
AN ZOOR14605034336
DT Article
TI Gastrointestinal helminths in two allopatric sibling species of swamp
   skink, Lissolepis coventryi and Lissolepis luctuosus (Reptilia:
   Scincidae) from southeastern and southwestern Australia, with
   descriptions of three new species of nematode.
AU Jones, Hugh I. (hjones@cyllene.uwa.edu.au) 
   Watharow, Simon
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 37-51
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two closely related species of swamp skink (Lissolepis coventryi and
   Lissolepis luctaosus) occur in Australia, one in the extreme southeast
   and the other in the southwest of the country. They are separated by
   more than 2,000 km of and country, and they have been isolated from one
   another for a considerable period of time, possibly more than 20 million
   years. We investigated the gastrointestinal nematode fauna of each using
   preserved museum lizards. More than 80% of each species of lizard was
   infected with nematodes. Three new species of nematode are described;
   Spinicauda victoriae n. sp. occurs only in L. coventryi in the southeast
   and Spinicauda similis n. sp. only in L. luctuosus in the southwest,
   each occurring at a similar prevalence and intensity. Moaciria
   paucipapillata n. sp. occurs in both populations. Abbreviata antarctica
   also occurs in both populations, though infrequently in L. coventryi.
   Pseudorictularia disparilis was present in 14% of L. coventryi,
   attesting to the aquatic habitat this lizard. The close similarity of
   the two species of Spinicauda, which differ only in the form of the
   eggs, indicate a common ancestry. The presence of A. antarctica adults
   in these semi-aquatic hosts supports the suggestion that this
   morphologically variable species originated in a cool, damp environment
   anti has adapted to a wider range of hosts and to a less-humid
   environment. The cestode Oockoristica vacuolata was recovered primarily
   from L. coventryi.
C1 Jones, Hugh I.; Univ Western Australia, Discipline Microbiol, M502,
   Nedlands, WA, Australia, Australia.
EM hjones@cyllene.uwa.edu.au
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1525-2647
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia

   New nematode parasite species].

    / ].

   parasite species] [Victoria /  / New species from reptilian host].

   Sauria, Scincidae, Nematoda

DT Article
TI Helminths from seven species of lizards (Reptilia: Squamata) at the
   Cerrado of Mato Grosso do Sul State, Brazil.
AU Avila, Robson W. (robsonavila@gmail.com) 
   Souza, Franco L.
   da Silva, Reinaldo J.
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 67-71
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Sixteen specimens representing 7 species of lizards (Hoplocercus
   spinosus, Ophiodes striatus, Polychrus acutirostris, Stenocercus
   caducus, Tropidurus Guarani, Tropidurus itambere, and Tupinambis
   merianae) collected in the Cerrado biome at the Brazilian state Mato
   Grosso do Sul were examined for helminths. Nine species of nematodes
   were recovered from lizard hosts (Cruzia travassosi, Cyrtosomum sp.,
   Diaphanocephalus galeatus, Gynaecometra bahiensis, Pharyngodon
   cesarpintoi, Physaloptera sp., Skrjabinellazia intermedia, Strongyluris
   oscari, and an unidentified species of nematode). Five new host records
   and 3 new locality records were reported.
C1 Avila, Robson W.; UNESP, Dept Parasitol, Distrito Rubiao Jr S-N,
   Botucatu, SP, Brazil, Brazil.
EM robsonavila@gmail.com
RI Avila, Robson W/B-3523-2013; Souza, Franco L/K-3406-2012; da Silva,
   Reinaldo Jose/C-1384-2019; da Silva, Reinaldo Jose/G-6159-2012
OI da Silva, Reinaldo Jose/0000-0002-3426-6873; da Silva, Reinaldo
   Jose/0000-0002-3426-6873

PT J
AN ZOOR14605034341
DT Article
TI Helminth parasites of sculpins, Cottus spp. (Teleostei, Cottidae) from
   three Maryland creeks, USA.
AU Muzzall, Patrick M. (muzzall@msu.edu) 
   Koslosky, Laura
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 87-90
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A total of 5 helminth species (3 Nematoda: Rhahdochona cotti,
   Freitascapillaria laticauda, Cystidicoloides ephenteridarum; 2
   Trematoda: Phyllodistomum undulans, Crepidostomum sp.) infected
   sculpins, Coitus spp., from 3 Maryland creeks in November 2005 and May
   2006. Gravid individuals of R. cotti and P. undulans occurred in
   blue-ridge sculpin, Cottus caerideomentuni, from Little Fishing Creek;
   gravid individuals of F. laticauda and R. cotti occurred in C.
   caeruleomentum and in Potomac sculpin, Coitus girardi, from Blue Lick
   Run, respectively; and gravid R. cotti occurred in mottled sculpin,
   Cottus bairdii, from Little Bear Creek. One immature female
   capillariid-like nematode occurred in C. girardi from Blue Lick Run.
   Rhabdochona cotti in C. caeruleomentum from Little Fishing Creek and in
   C. bairdii from Little Bear Creek had the highest prevalence, mean
   intensity, and mean abundance, followed by P. undulans in C.
   caeruleomentum from Little Fishing Creek. The mean parasite species
   richness values were low and ranged from 0.39 to 1.27 in the Coitus spp.
   This is the first report of parasites from C. girardi, and the second
   report of parasites from C. caeruleomentum in North America.
C1 Muzzall, Patrick M.; Michigan State Univ, Dept Zool, Nat Sci Bldg, E
   Lansing, MI, USA, USA.
EM muzzall@msu.edu
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1525-2647

   Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   North America; USA

DT Article
TI Helminths from four species of Phyllodactylus (Squamata: Gekkonidae)
   from Peru.
AU Goldberg, Stephen R. (cxb13@psu.edu) 
   Bursey, Charles R.
SO Comparative Parasitology
VL 77
IS 1
PS 91-93
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four species of Phyllodactylus from Peru were examined for helminths: P.
   inaequalis, P. johnwrighti, P. lepidopygus, and P. microphyllus. One
   species of Cestoda, Oochoristica travassosi, and 3 species of Nematoda,
   Parapharyngodon scleratus, Spauligodon orkutzcabiensis, and Acuariidae
   gen sp. were found. Six new host records are reported.

TI The disrupted pattern of distribution of the genus Hadrurochactas
   Pocock; evidence of past connections between Amazon and the Brazilian
   Atlantic forest.
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
SO Comptes Rendus Biologies
VL 333
IS 1
PS 41-47
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A new species, Hadrurochactas araripe sp. n. (Chactidae) is described
   from 'Chapada do Araripe', a 'Brejo type' formation located in the State
   of Pernambuco, Brazil. The description of the new species confirms a
   disrupted pattern of distribution presented by the genus Hadrurochactas.
   This includes species present both in Guiano-Amazon forests and forest
   islands within the 'Caatingas'. These are xerophytic formations in
   northeastern Brazil. This new species brings further evidence of a past
   connection between the Amazonian and Atlantic forests, as already
   suggested by palaeobotanists. [copyright] 2009 Academie des sciences.
   Published by Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.

PT J

DT Article
TI Molecular phylogeny, morphology and bioacoustics reveal five additional
   species of arboreal microhylid frogs of the genus Anodonthyla from
   Madagascar.
AU Vences, Miguel (m.vences@tu-bs.de) 
   Glaw, Frank
   Koehler, Joern
   Wollenberg, Katharina C.
SO Contributions to Zoology
VL 79
IS 1
PS 1-32
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 38
AB We provide a partial revision of the microhylid frogs of the genus
   Anodonthyla, endemic to Madagascar, based on comprehensive molecular,
   bioacoustic and morphological data sets that include newly collected
   specimens from multiple localities. The molecular trees provide strong
   evidence for the polyphyly of several nominal species as they were
   previously defined, especially of Anodonthyla boulengeri and A.
   nigrigularis. As a consequence, we here resurrect the nomen Mantella
   pollicaris Boettger as Anodonthyla pollicaris from the synonymy of A.
   boulengeri, and we describe four new species, all with strong genetic
   divergences to other nominal species: Anodonthyla emilei from Ranomafana
   National Park, a comparatively medium-sized species characterized by a
   multi-note advertisement call with high note repetition rate; A. theoi
   from Manombo Special Reserve, a small species characterized by low note
   repetition rate, long note duration and high spectral call frequency; A.
   vallani, a medium-sized species from Ambohitantely Special Reserve,
   characterized by low note repetition rate, long note duration and low
   spectral call frequency; and A. jeanbai, a small species from Andohahela
   National Park, characterized by a long and narrow head, presence of
   short dorsolateral folds, a very short first finger, and a yellowish
   ventral colour. A further candidate species comprises populations
   previously assigned to A. boulengeri from the Ranomafana region, which
   we do not describe because the corresponding data set is too
   fragmentary, and we refer to it as A. sp. aff. boulengeri 'Ranomafana'.
   The molecular phylogeny indicates recurrent shifts between high and low
   note repetition rates in calls, based mainly on three strongly supported
   sister groups: A. moramora with low repetition rate and A. nigrigularis
   with moderately low repetition rate; A. theoi with low repetition rate
   and A. pollicaris with high repetition rate; and A. vallani with low
   repetition rate and A. sp. aff. boulengeri 'Ranomafana' with high
   repetition rate. The two species with the northernmost ranges, A.
   hutchisoni and A. boulengeri, are phylogenetically nested within clades
   of species occurring further south, confirming that the center of origin
   of the genus Anodonthyla was most likely in the South East of
   Madagascar.
C1 Vences, Miguel; Tech Univ Braunschweig, Inst Zool, Spielmannstr 8,
   Braunschweig, Germany, Germany.
EM m.vences@tu-bs.de
RI Wollenberg, Katharina/F-6795-2010

   Katharina/0000-0001-8858-1804

DT Article
TI The discovery of Scutovertex ianus sp. nov. (Acari, Oribatida) - a
   combined approach of comparative morphology, morphometry and molecular
   data.
AU Pfingstl, Tobias (tobias.pfingstl@uni-graz.at) 
   Schaeffer, Sylvia
   Ebermann, Ernst
   Krisper, Guenther
SO Contributions to Zoology
VL 79
IS 1
PS 39-55
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Based on morphological, morphometric and genetic data Scutovertex ianus
   sp. nov. is described as a new oribatid mite species. The traditional
   comparison with the morphologically most similar congeneric S. minutus
   and S. sculptus demonstrated that the new species shares certain
   characters with both species, but can be clearly identified by
   indistinct cuticular notogastral foveae in combination with short
   spiniform notogastral setae. Furthermore the eggs of S. ianus exhibit a
   different fine structure of the exochorion. The morphometric analysis of
   16 continuous morphological variables separated the three species, S.
   minutus, S. sculptus and S. ianus with a certain overlap indicating
   minor size and shape differences in overall morphology. The molecular
   phylogenetic analysis of mitochondrial COI gene sequences supported the
   monophyly of all three investigated species and confirmed S. ianus as
   separate species with high bootstrap values. Each performed analysis
   approves the discreteness of S. ianus and the results contradict the
   formerly supposed large intraspecific variability of the representatives
   of the genus Scutovertex. The records of S. ianus are as yet restricted
   to the Eastern part of Austria and to one location in Germany, but
   findings of intermediary Scutovertex specimens from other European
   countries may refer to this new species.

DT Article
TI Zoanthids of the Cape Verde Islands and their symbionts: previously
   unexamined diversity in the Northeastern Atlantic.
AU Reimer, James D. (jreimer@sci.u-ryukyu.ac.jp) 
   Hirose, Mamiko
   Wirtz, Peter
SO Contributions to Zoology
VL 79
IS 4
PS 147-163
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The marine invertebrate fauna of the Cape Verde Islands contains many
   endemic species due to their isolated location in the eastern Atlantic,
   yet research has not been conducted on most taxa here. One such group
   are the zoanthids or mat anemones, an order of benthic cnidarians
   (Hexacorallia: Zoantharia) common in many marine environments. In this
   study, the diversity of zoanthids in the Cape Verde Islands is
   specifically examined for the first time. Field images and sampling are
   combined with molecular phylogenetic analyses utilizing two
   mitochondrial DNA markers (cytochrome oxidase subunit I and 16S
   ribosomal DNA) to determine the number of species present. Specimens
   from eight species (Palythoa caribaeorum, Palythoa sp. 265. Zoanthus
   aff. pulchellus. Isaurus tuberculatus, Parazoanthus sp. 269.
   Parazoanthus sp. 1401, Antipathozoanthus macaronesicus, Terrazoanthus
   sp. 276) were identified, including two to four species that are likely
   new to science. Additional examinations of Symbiodinium endosymbionts in
   zooxanthellate species showed that chides A, B, and C were present; this
   is the first report of clade B associating with a zoanthid species. An
   appendix describing the eight zoanthid species found in the Cape Verde
   Islands is included to provide a base for future zoanthid research in
   this region.
C1 Reimer, James D.; Univ Ryukyus, TRO SIS, Senbaru 1, Okinawa 9030213,
   Japan, Japan.
EM jreimer@sci.u-ryukyu.ac.jp
RI Reimer, James Davis/AAP-1331-2020
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular
   Biology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1383-4517

   Ocean
DE Symbiodinium [Mutualism / Zoantharia (Cnidaria) / ] [North Atlantic /
   Cape Verde / Cnidarian mutualists]. 
   Zoantharia [Nucleic acids / mtDNA markers / Protozoan mutualists]
   [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Mutualism / Symbiodinium
   (Protozoa) / ] [North Atlantic / Cape Verde / distribution; faunal
   list]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates; Protozoans

   Phytomastigophorea, Dinoflagellida

TI A revision of the genus Mycale (Poecilosclerida: Mycalidae) from the
   Mexican Pacific Ocean.
AU Carballo, Jose L. (jlcarballo@ola.icmyl.unam.mx) 
   Cruz-Barraza, Jose A.
SO Contributions to Zoology
VL 79
IS 4
PS 165-191
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Knowledge about the sponge fauna from the Mexican Pacific Ocean has
   increased substantially in recent years, but most of these modern
   taxonomic studies have been focused on hadromerids. The aim of this
   study was to contribute to the knowledge of the order Poecilosclerida.
   At present, seven species of Mycale have been described or recorded from
   the Pacific coast of Mexico. but only three of them are considered
   valid: M. contax, M. cecilia and M. aff. magnirhaphidifera. After a
   revision of the material collected during the last eight years
   throughout the East Pacific coast of Mexico. along with the type
   material, and the literature available, eight species of Mycale are
   considered valid, three of them: M. magnitoxa sp. nov., M. dickinsoni
   sp. nov., and M. ramulosa sp. nov., are proposed as new to science. In
   addition, M. adhaerens is reported for the first time from the Mexican
   Pacific Ocean. Another Mycale-species that was identified was M. psila,
   which constitutes its seconLamberd record for the Mexican Pacific Ocean.
   The systematic, distribution and detailed species descriptions are based
   on newly collected material and previous descriptions from the
   literature.

   82000, Mexico, Mexico.

TI AN EMPIRICAL SYNTHETIC PATTERN STUDY OF GARS (LEPISOSTEIFORMES) AND
   CLOSELY RELATED SPECIES, BASED MOSTLY ON SKELETAL ANATOMY. THE
   RESURRECTION OF HOLOSTEI.
AU Grande, Lance
SO Copeia
VL 10
IS 2A
SU (Supplement)
PS 1-863
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The comparative osteology, phylogenetic relationships and historical
   biogeography of all known fossil and living gars (Ginglymodi
   Lepisosteiformes) are investigated in detail. Clearly documented
   comparative data on the skeletons of lepisosteiforms and closely related
   taxa are examined with regard to phylogeny, ontogeny historical
   biogeography stratigraphic paleontology and paleoecology. This study of
   lepisosteiform fishes is also used as a platform to explore several
   fundamental methodological and philisophical concepts important to
   phylogenetic/evolutionary investigations (pp. 819-828). The seven extant
   species of gars are the sole surviving members of a formerly diverse
   division of fishes Ginglymodi (here including Lepisosteiformes
   [dagger]Semionotiformes and [dagger]Macroseminformes). Even
   Lepisosteiformes (the ginglymodin subgroup that is the focus of this
   study) was much more diverse taxonomically and morphologically during
   Mesozoic and Paleogene times than it is today. It was also much mole
   geographically widespread Lepisosteiformes, as defined here, are those
   neopterygian fishes with opisthocoelous vertebral centra, 'tongue bones"
   (a basihyal tooth plate consisting of bony plates or entoglossals)
   dorsal fin set far posterior on body (predorsal length of 75-88% of
   standard length) and several other uniquely derived morphological
   characters. To set the style and terminology for description of the
   fossil taxa and to present a fresh look at the osteology and development
   of living gars the skeletal anatomy of Lepisosteus osseus and
   Atractostcus spatula is redescribed in great detail and the other five
   extant gars in somewhat less but still significant detail, all using
   modern methods of preparation and illustration. Such detailed study of
   the extant species was necessary to adequately interpret probable
   intraspecific variation and ontogenic variation in fossil taxa.
   Individual variation of both bone morphology and developmental timing in
   Lepisosteus osseus is also examined. The order Lepisosteiformes (gars)
   is classified into two families here Lepisosteidae (including
   Lepisosteus Atractosteus, [dagger]Cuneatus gen nov, and
   [dagger]Masillosteus) and [dagger]Obarchthyidae fam. nov. (including
   [dagger]Obatchthys and [dagger]Dentileptsosteus gen. nov.). The genera
   [dagger]Cuneatus gen. nov. and [dagger]Masillosteus show a diversity of
   extinct very short-snouted lepisosteid gars that lived in the Eocene.
   One group ([dagger] Masillosteus) had very few sharply pointed teeth but
   the coronoids and upper jaw bones were covered with large flat tipped
   (styliform) teeth suitable for crushing snails or other shelled
   organisms [dagger]Obaichthyidae fam. nov. represents a family of South
   American/African gars that unlike Lepisosteidae have a well-developed
   interopercle, an intercalar fused to the exoccipital, and other features
   showing basal lepisosteiform morphology to be quite different than was
   previously thought. Acid transfer preparations of [dagger]obaichthyids
   from the Upper Cretaceous Santana Formation of Brazil show many
   previously undescribed morphological details of those taxa that are key
   to basal neopterygian phylogenetic studies. One of the results of new
   information on basal lepisosteiform morphology is that Holostei (rather
   than Halecostomi) appears to be a monophyletic group based on
   morphological data (reported briefly in Grande 2005). Previous
   phylogenetic studies regarding the classic gar Amta-teleost problem are
   reviewed (i e the 'Halecostomi vs Holostei controversy) and the
   characters used to support Halecostomi in those studies are evaluated.
   With the morphological evidence now pointing to Holostei morphological
   and molecular evidence are now in agreement on the issue. The
   Superdivision Holostei (as used here) includes the Divisions
   Halecomorphi and Ginglymodi Ginglymodi here includes at least the orders
   Lepisosteiformes [dagger]Semionotiformes ([dagger]Sennonotuv elegans as
   used here for outgroup comparison) and [dagger]Macrosemiflormes
   ([dagger]Macrosemndae sensu Bartiam 1977). The order
   [dagger]Semionotifoimes is still in need of rigorous review and revision
   to determine which taxa can be included with the type genus without
   making the order nonmonophyletic. Accurate resolution of the Holostei vs
   Halecostomi problem helps calibrate the basal interrelationships of
   Neopterygii, a taxon containing nearly half of all living vertebrate
   species. Establishing this pattern of relationship will have
   ramifications for the general phylogenetic studies within Neopterygii
   and for studies that use Neopterygn for outgroup comparison. This study
   also demonstrates the power of a fossil taxon to help overturn a
   phylogenetic pattern derived from the morphology of extant species. Much
   of what tipped the scale away from a monophyletic Halecostomi and toward
   a monophyletic Holostei in this study is the morphological evidence
   described here for the Cretaceous [dagger]Obaichthyidae (fam. nov.)
   [dagger]Obaichthyids are clearly lepisosteiforms based on numerous
   characters, but they have a well-developed interopercle and other
   features that falsify previously proposed synapomorphies for the
   monophyly of Halecostomi. These critical characters were missed in
   previous descriptions of [dagger]Obatchthys because of a lack of
   adequately prepared specimens [dagger]Obaichthyids represent a
   phylogenetic "missing link in the truest sense of the term. Numerous
   general methodological, philosophical and theoretical concepts are
   discussed in this paper (which can be located using either the Subject
   Index or the Table of Contents), including the concept of the "effective
   type" specimen, the concept of the "effective type" genus for taxonomic
   names above family level rank the use of quotation marks to indicate
   uncertain taxonomic designation, philisophical roots of the comparative
   technique, the importance of stages of disarticulation in interpreting
   the morphology of fossil taxa, anatomical terminology as a tool,
   relative empiricism, missing data, data partitioning, and the meaning of
   cladograms. Once again I apply what was previously (Grande and Bemis,
   1998) termed an empirical synthetic pattern approach" to an
   investigation of a basal neopterygian group (Lepisosteiformes) although
   in the end, that approach is nothing more than a fancy name for good
   comparative biology.
C1 Grande, Lance; Field Museum Nat Hist, Div Collect & Res, Chicago, IL,
   USA, USA.
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0045-8511

   Clastes cuneatus - Cope 1878 (Lepisosteidae): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Cuneatus, p. 570; Fossil]. 
   Cuneatini (Lepisosteidae): [Tribe nov, Of family Lepisosteinae, Type

DT Article
TI Description of Caridina alba, a new species of blind atyid shrimp from
   Tenglongdong cave, Hubei province, China (Decapoda, Atyidae).
AU Li, Jingchun (lisq@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Li, Shuqiang
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 1
PS 17-27
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 6
AB A new species of atyid shrimp, Caridina alba sp. nov., is described and
   illustrated based on specimens collected from Tenglongdong cave, Hubei
   Province, China. This new species is characterized by a short rostrum
   with a small number of teeth, highly reduced eyes, the shape and
   relative lengths of the pereiopodal segments, the spination of the
   posterior telsonic margin, and the uropodal diaeresis. The morphology of
   the species in relation to other species is discussed.
C1 Li, Jingchun; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Beichen W Rd, Beijing, China,
   China.

TI Hastatus faviae n. gen., n. sp., a xarifiid copepod parasitic in the
   honeycomb coral of Taiwan.
AU Ho, Ju-Shey (jsho@csulb.edu) 
   Cheng, Yu-Rong
   Dai, Chang-Feng
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 1
PS 89-99
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Hastatus faviae n. gen., n. sp., is described based on specimens
   obtained from colonies of the honeycomb coral, Favia favus (Forskal,
   1775), collected at Wanlitong, Pingtung in southern Taiwan. The new
   species belongs to the family Xarifiidae of the copepod order
   Poecilostomatoida. It is characterized by having a spear-shaped mandible
   carrying a bent tip covered with denticles, biramous legs 1 and 2,
   uniramous legs 3 and 4, and the absence of leg 5 together with the fifth
   pediger.

TI A new species and a new record of the genus Uroptychodes Baba, 2004
   (Decapoda, Chirostylidae) from the east China Sea.
AU Dong, Chao (lixzh@ms.qdio.ac.cn) 
   Li, Xinzheng
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 2
PS 207-213
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Uroptychodes babai n. sp., a new species of squat lobster of the family
   Chirostylidae, and Uroptychodes barunae Baba, 2004, which is for the
   first time recorded from the East China Sea, are reported in the present
   paper. The new species is characterized by the lateral margins of the
   rostrum being almost entire, the carapace with the posterior two-thirds
   equipped with medium-sized spines, and the antennal scale overreaching
   the penultimate segment but failing to reach halfway the length of the
   ultimate segment of the antennal peduncle.

DT Article
TI A new species of Paraxantharus (Copepoda, Calanoida) from deep waters of
   the south Atlantic.
AU Markhaseva, Elena L. (copepoda@zin.ru) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 3
PS 267-276
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The hitherto unknown female sex of the genus Paraxantharus (Copepoda,
   Calanoida) is described from the South Atlantic, based on the female of
   a new species of the genus that is described herein. The specimen was
   collected from abyssal depths close to the sea bed during the German
   expedition ANDEEP II in 2002. Paraxantharus victorbergeri sp. nov.
   differs from its only congener in details of the setation of the oral
   parts; by the oblique shape of the four teeth of the gnathobase of the
   mandible; by the poorly sclerotized, worm-like sensory seta of the
   distal praecoxal endite of the synocoxa of the maxilliped; and by the
   lateral spine on segment 2 of the P1 exopod, which is the shortest when
   compared with the lateral spines of exopodal segments 1 and 3. This new
   species of Paraxantharus as described below, brings the number of
   species in the genus to two. The present collection of P. victorbergeri
   constitutes only the second, and also the most northern record of the
   genus that is so far only known from the southern hemisphere.
C1 Markhaseva, Elena L.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Nab 1, St
   Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM copepoda@zin.ru
RI Markhaseva, Elena L/R-1832-2017
SC Zoology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean
DE Paraxantharus victorbergeri [South Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Calanoida

TI A new species of Tritodynamia Ortmann, 1894 (Decapoda, Brachyura,
   Macrophthalmidae) from Singapore.
AU Naruse, Tohru (naruse@lab.u-ryukyu.ac.jp) 
   Ng, Peter K.L.
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 3
PS 291-298
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Tritodynamia Ortmann, 1894 sensu stricto is described
   from Singapore. The new species is morphologically similar to three
   Chinese species, namely T. dilatata Yang & Sun, 1996, T. longipropoda
   Dai, Feng, Song & Cheng, 1980, and T. hainanensis Dai, Feng, Song &
   Cheng, 1980. The new species is, however, distinguished from these three
   species by characters of the carapace, ambulatory legs, male abdominal
   somites, and telson. This record also represents the southernmost record
   of the genus.

DT Article
TI Asterocheres faroensis, a new species (Copepoda, Siphonostomatoida,
   Asterocheridae) associated with Hymeniacidon perlevis (Montagu, 1812)
   (Porifera) from Lake Faro, Mediterranean Sea.
AU Crescenti, Nunzio (nunzio.crescenti@unime.it) 
   Baviera, Cosimo
   Zaccone, Daniele
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 3
PS 299-311
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new siphonostomatoid copepod belonging to the family Asterocheridae,
   Asterocheres faroensis, is described. It was found in washings of
   Hymeniacidon perlevis (Montagu, 1812), a sponge inhabiting Lake Faro at
   Messina (north-eastern Sicily). The new species belongs to the cluster
   of species with 21 antennular segments in the female but only 17 in the
   male, and resembles those species carrying a 1-segmented mandibular
   palp. However, it differs from the latter in the length to width ratio
   of the P5. The males have a particular aesthetasc on the tenth
   antennular segment, a character that has never been found in other
   species of the family Asterocheridae.
C1 Crescenti, Nunzio; Univ Messina, Dipartimento Biol Anim & Ecol Marina,
   Salita Sperone 31, Messina, Italy, Italy.
EM nunzio.crescenti@unime.it
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0011-216X

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Italy

   / New associate species] [Sicily /  / New species; poriferan associate].
   
   Hymeniacidon perlevis [Associations / Asterocheres faroensis (Crustacea)
   / New associate species] [Sicily /  / New associated crustacean
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Siphonostomatoida, Porifera,
   Demospongiae

   with Hymeniacidon perlevis (Porifera), p. 300].

DT Article
TI High-level phylogenetic relationships within Parastenocarididae
   (Copepoda, Harpacticoida).
AU Schminke, Horst Kurt (schminke@uni-oldenburg.de) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 3
PS 343-367
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB There are two sub-groups ("subfamilies") within Parastenocarididae
   called Parastenocaridinae nov. and Fontinalicaridinae nov. as revealed
   by an analysis of the descriptions of all 258 species known at present.
   Of these species, 170 (= 67%) belong to Parastenocaridinae nov., 82 (=
   33%) to Fontinalicaridinae nov. Six species could not be grouped because
   of incomplete descriptions. Currently there are 27 valid genera of which
   17 (= 63%) belong to Parastenocaridinae nov., and 10 (= 37%) to
   Fontinalicaridinae nov. The two new taxa can be distinguished mainly by
   the male antennules, the endopod of female leg 3, spinules on the basis
   of male leg 4, the female genital field, and the setation of the caudal
   rami. Other distinguishing characters are legs 5, as well as male leg 1
   and leg 3. Fontinalicaridinae nov. can be shown to be monophyletic by
   the endopod of female leg 3 lacking a terminal seta and by the form of
   the female genital field; possible autapomorphies of Parastenocaridinae
   nov. are a spinule row on the basis of male leg 4, either medially or at
   the base of the endopod, and the arrangement of the furcal setae. A list
   of genera and species of the new taxa is added.
C1 Schminke, Horst Kurt; Univ Oldenburg, Fak 5, Postfach 2503, Oldenburg,
   Germany, Germany.
EM schminke@uni-oldenburg.de
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Diagnosis; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; General morphology; Evolution

   [Phylogeny /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14608056084
DT Article
TI METACYCLOPS (COPEPODA, CYCLOPIDAE) FROM AYYALON CAVE, ISRAEL.
AU Defaye, Danielle (ddefaye@mnhn.fr) 
   Por, Francis Dov
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 4
PS 399-423
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Cyclopidae (Copepoda, Cyclopoida) is described from
   Ayyalon Cave, Israel, as Metacyclops longimaxillis n. sp. The
   description is based on specimens collected in a small, brackish, warm
   and sulfidic water pool, recently described from this cave that belongs
   to the Yarqon-Tanninim aquifer. The new taxon is distinguished by
   specific morphological traits, but in particular by the remarkable
   maxillae, the large size of which may be related to the specific
   environmental conditions in which these crustaceans are living. Its
   closest similar congener is M. stammeri Kiefer, 1938, with which it
   mainly shares the terminal seta and spine on endopodal segment 2 of P4
   in both male and female, the armature of two setae and the strong
   exopodal seta on the basipodite of the antenna, the spine formula of the
   exopodites of the swimming legs (3.4.4.3), the general shape and
   setation of the furca with the inner median seta enlarged at its base;
   the 11-segmented female antennule, and the segmentation pattern of the
   antennule. They principally differ by their body size, the shape of the
   seminal receptacle, the setation of the antenna, the structure of the
   male antennule, the ornamentation of the intercoxal plates of the
   swimming legs, and the structure of the male P6. Some information and a
   description of the only other cyclopid found at this site, attributed to
   Metacyclops subdolus Kiefer, 1938, is given in addition.
C1 Defaye, Danielle; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Milieux & Peuplements
   Aquat, CP 53,61 Rue Buffon, Paris, France, France.
EM ddefaye@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Metacyclops longimaxillis [Israel /  / New species]. 
   Metacyclops subdolus [Israel / Ramla area, Ayyalon Cave / New record;
   systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI A NEW ERGASILID COPEPOD PARASITIC ON THE FRESHWATER SPINY EEL,
   MASTACEMBELUS ARMATUS LACEPEDE, 1800 FROM THE RIVER GODAVARI, INDIA.
AU Vankara, Anu Prasanna (annuprasanna@gmail.com) 
   Chikkam, Vijayalakshmi
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 4
PS 425-434
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new ergasilid copepod of the genus Neoergasilus Yin, 1956 (Copepoda,
   Ergasilidae) parasitic on the freshwater spiny eel, Mastacembelus
   armatus Lacepede, 1800 from the river Godavari, India, is described.
   Neoergasilus indicus sp. nov. is characterized by an ergasilidiform body
   and can be differentiated from other species of its genus in having a
   blunt, knob-like extension on the inner distal corner of the basal
   segment of the exopod of leg 1; the leg armature; a deep incision in the
   caudal lamina; and the host.
C1 Vankara, Anu Prasanna; Andhra Univ, Dept Zool, Visakhapatnam, Andhra
   Pradesh, India, India.
EM annuprasanna@gmail.com

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   India

   parasite species] [Andhra Pradesh /  / New crustacean parasite species].
   
   Neoergasilus indicus [Piscean hosts / Mastacembelus armatus / New
   parasite species] [Andhra Pradesh /  / New species from piscean host].

AN ZOOR14608056088
DT Article
TI CALIGUS MUSAICUS N. SP (COPEPODA, CALIGIDAE) PARASITIC ON THE EUROPEAN
   FLOUNDER, PLATICHTHYS FLESUS (LINNAEUS) OFF PORTUGAL.
AU Cavaleiro, Francisca I. (fcavaleiro@fc.up.pt) 
   Santos, Maria J.
   Ho, Ju-Shey
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 4
PS 457-464
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of caligid copepod, Caligus musaicus n. sp., is described
   from the European flounder, Platichthys flesus (Linnaeus, 1758), caught
   off the northern coast of Portugal. The new species is distinguished
   from its congeners by the combination of the following character states:
   (1) equipped with a short abdomen (about 1/3 the length of the thoracic
   zone of the cephalothoracic shield); (2) armed with a pair of parallel
   pointed tines on the box of the sternal furca; (3) bearing a long
   element IV (about 3 times as long as the next longest element) at the
   tip of leg 1 exopod; and (4) with a slender leg 4 exopod bearing a long
   outer seta (about 3 times as long as the next longest seta) at the tip
   of this ramus.
C1 Cavaleiro, Francisca I.; Univ Porto, Dept Zool Antropol, Rua Campo
   Alegre S-N Edificio FC4, Porto, Portugal, Portugal.
EM fcavaleiro@fc.up.pt

PT J
AN ZOOR14608056093
DT Article
TI CYMBASOMA JANETAE N. SP., A NEW MONSTRILLOID (COPEPODA, MONSTRILLOIDA)
   FROM THE GULF OF AQABA (RED SEA, EGYPT).
AU Mageed, Adel Ali A. (adel_abdelmageed@yahoo.co.nz) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 83
IS 5
PS 513-523
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Cymbasoma janetae n. sp. is described from three adult females collected
   from the Gulf of Aqaba (Red Sea, Egypt). The new species is closely
   similar to C. longispinosum (Bourne, 1890), C. morii Sekiguchi, 1982, C.
   chelemense Suarez-Morales & Escamilla, 1997, and C. californiense
   Suarez-Morales & Palomares-Garcia, 1999. The new species can be
   distinguished by the body proportions, the absence of the seta on the
   first segment of the P1-P4 exopods, the structure of the fifth legs, the
   relative length of the ovigerous spines, and the presence of eight
   shallow cuticular wrinkles on the lateral margin and dorsal surface of
   the genital double somite.
C1 Mageed, Adel Ali A.; Natl Inst Oceanog & Fisheries, 101 Kasr Al Ainy,
   Cairo, Egypt, Egypt.
EM adel_abdelmageed@yahoo.co.nz
RI abdelmageed, adel/K-5569-2019
OI abdelmageed, adel/0000-0003-3724-6509

PT J
AN ZOOR15206039368
DT Article
TI THREE NEW SPECIES OF THE LIOLAEMUS ELONGATUS GROUP (IGUANIA:
   LIOLAEMIDAE) FROM ARGENTINA.
AU Abdala, Cristian Simon (samiryjazmin@gmail.com) 
   Quinteros, Andres Sebastian
   Scrocchi, Gustavo Jose
   Stazzonelli, Juan Carlos
SO Cuadernos de Herpetologia
VL 24
IS 2
PS 93-109
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe three new species of Liolaemus from Southern Argentina.
   These new species belong to the monophyletic Liolaemus elongatus group,
   included within the subgenus Liolaemus sensu stricto. Two of the new
   species inhabits in southern Mendoza Province and the other one inhabits
   in central west Ro Negro Province. The new species exhibit character
   states that distinguish they from all other members of the L. elongatus
   group. Those character states include color pattern, number of scales in
   dorsum, shape of temporal scales, and size (among others). Although with
   those new species we clarify the taxonomic status of several populations
   which belongs to the L. elongatus group, many remain unknown.
C1 Abdala, Cristian Simon; Facultad de Ciencias Naturales e IML, Miguel
   Lillo 251, (4000) Tucuman, Argentina, Argentina.
EM samiryjazmin@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0326-551X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Liolaemus choique; Liolaemus shitan; Liolaemus smaug [Argentina /  / New
   species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Liolaemus choique (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 103]. 
   Liolaemus elongatus group (Iguanidae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 95]. 
   Liolaemus shitan (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 100]. 
   Liolaemus smaug (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 94].

FT Igdeli (Gemerek, Sivas) Lokalitesi Erken Pliyosen Fauna Istifinin
   Rodentia ve Lagomorpha (Mammalia) Fosilleri: Biyokronolojik ve
   Paleobiyocografik Anlamlari.
AU Alpaslan, Fadime Suata (falpaslan@cumhuriyet.edu.tr) 
   Unay, Engin
   Ay, Faruk
SO Cumhuriyet Universitesi Fen Edebiyat Fakultesi Fen Bilimleri Dergisi
VL 31
IS 1
PS 1-29
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Turkish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomy of the Rodentia and Lagomorpha from the Early Pliocene
   localities of Igdeli isinterpreted in terms of biostratigraphy and
   paleogeography.The relative age of the fauna assemblages are inferred on
   the basis of the rodent and lagomorph dentitions. In Igdeli rodent and
   lagomorph faunas are dominated by European and Asiatic species. Endemic
   species are rare and the few that show African affinities are restricted
   to the assemblages of Latest Miocene-Earliest Pliocene age.
C1 Alpaslan, Fadime Suata; Cumhuriyet Universitesi, Fen-Edebiyat Fakultesi,
   Antropoloji Bolumu, 58140, Sivas, Turkey, Turkey.
EM falpaslan@cumhuriyet.edu.tr

DT Article
TI A new species of Megophrys (Amphibia: Anura: Megophryidae) from the
   northwestern Hunan Province, China.
AU Mo, Xiaoyang
   Shen, Youhui (bioyhs@163.com) 
   Li, Honghui
   Wu, Xiushan
SO Current Zoology
VL 56
IS 4
PS 432-436
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Megophrys (Amphibia: Anura: Megophryidae), Megophrys
   tuberogranulatus Shen, Mo et Li, sp. nov. (Holotype HNUL 03080902, adult
   male, SVL: 38.2 mm), from Sangzhi County, Hunan Province, is described.
   Megophrys tuberogranulatus is closely related to both Megophrys
   kuatunensis and Megophrys minor. Characters of the new species that
   differentiate this species from close relatives are skin granulated with
   big tubercles on the dorsal sides of both thigh and tibia, the bigger
   inner metacarpal tubercle, upper eyelid wider than the interorbital
   space, hind limbs longer, overlapping of the left and right calcaneal
   parts. The type specimens are deposited in the Animal Museum of Life
   Sciences College of Hunan Normal University (Current Zoology 56 (4):
   432-436, 2010).
C1 Shen, Youhui; Hunan Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Changsha, Hunan, China,
   China.
EM bioyhs@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1674-5507
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Megophrys tuberogranulatus [Hunan /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Pelobatidae
OR Megophrys tuberogranulatus - Shen, Mo & Li 2010 (Pelobatidae): [Sp nov,
   Hunan, P. 433]. 
DI 10.1093/czoolo/56.4.432

DT Article
TI A new dolphin (Cetacea, Delphinidae) from the Plio-Pleistocene of the
   North Sea.
AU Post, Klaas (klaaspost@fishcon.nl) 
   Kompanje, Erwin J.O.
SO Deinsea
VL 14
PS 1-13
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hoekman's blunt-snouted dolphin Platalearostrum hoekmani gen. et sp.
   nov. is described from Plio- Pleistocene sediments of the North Sea (The
   Netherlands). It shows unique and bizarre features of the premaxilla
   that extends over the maxilla way beyond the lateral border of the
   rostrum. Platalearostrum hoekmani is compared to fossil and extant
   Delphinidae and similarities with extant Globicephala as well as
   functional implications of its strange morphology are discussed.
C1 Post, Klaas; Natuurhistorisch Museum Rotterdam, P.O. Box 23452, 3001 KL
   Rotterdam, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM klaaspost@fishcon.nl
SC Zoology
SN 0923-9308
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic; Geological time periods

   Platalearostrum hoekmani [North Sea / Netherlands / new species]
   [Caenozoic /  / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Cetacea, Delphinidae
OR Platalearostrum (Delphinidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Orcininae, Type
   species Platalearostrum hoekmani, p. 2, Caenozoic; Fossil]. 
   Platalearostrum hoekmani (Delphinidae): [Sp nov, Netherlands (marine),
   Caenozoic, P. 2; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A survey of the emesine assassin bugs of the tribes Collartidini,
   Leistarchini, Emesini, and Metapterini of Taiwan (Hemiptera,
   Heteroptera, Reduviidae).
AU Redei, David (redei@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu) 
   Tsai, Jing-Fu
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 11-36
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Thread-legged assassin bugs (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae:
   Emesinae) belonging to the tribes Collartidini, Leistarchini, Emesini,
   and Metapterini of Taiwan are surveyed. Eight genera and thirteen
   species are recognized, four species are described as new. Collartidini
   (represented by the genus Collartida Villers, 1949) is recorded for the
   first time not only from Taiwan but from Southeast Asia as well. Malaria
   ryukyuana Ishikawa & Tomokuni, 2002, Gardena albiannulata Ishikawa,
   2005, and Stenolemus crassirostris Stal, 1871 are recorded for the first
   time from Taiwan. The species Collartida peregrina sp. n.. Bagauda
   zigzag sp. n.. Ploiaria huangorum sp. n., and Stenolemus alikakay sp. n.
   are described as new Identification keys to the species of the above
   tribes occurring in Taiwan are presented, and their zoogeography is
   briefly discussed.
C1 Redei, David; Hungarian Natl Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross U 13,
   Budapest, Hungary, Hungary.
EM redei@zoo.zoo.nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 0012-0073
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   alikakay [Taiwan /  / New species].

   Southeast Asia / ] [Taiwan /  / ] [ /  / distribution].

   Reduvoidea, Reduviidae

   Bagauda zigzag (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 17]. 
   Collartida peregrina (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Taiwan, P. 13]. 
   Collartidini (Reduviidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Chrysis tripotini sp. n., a new cuckoo wasp (Hymenoptera, Chrysididae)
   from South Korea.
AU Soon, Villu (villu.soon@ut.ee) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 37-41
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Chrysis tripotini sp. n., a new cuckoo wasp from South Korea is
   described and illustrated. It belongs to the C. ignita species group and
   can be separated from all other species in the group by the following
   combination of characters: mandible with additional subapical tooth;
   shortened mid and hind tarsi; vertex and dorsal thorax mostly lusterless
   black. C. tripotini sp. n. is morphologically closest to C. brevitarsis
   Thomson.
C1 Soon, Villu; Univ Tartu, Dept Zool, Vanemuise 46, Tartu, Estonia,
   Estonia.
EM villu.soon@ut.ee
OI Soon, Villu/0000-0001-5368-0319

SN 0012-0073
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Chrysis tripotini [South Korea /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Chrysidoidea, Chrysididae
OR Chrysis brevitarsis - Thomson 1870 (Chrysididae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 38]. 
   Chrysis tripotini (Chrysididae): [Sp nov, South Korea, Host unknown, p.
   38].

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Germaria Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera, Tachinidae)
   from Greece, with descriptions of two new species.
AU Ziegler, Joachim (joachim.ziegler@mfn-berlin.de) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 43-57
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Greek species of the genus Germaria are revised. Two species are
   described as new to science: Germaria credo sp. n. (Greek mainland) and
   G. neglecta sp. n. (Greek mainland and the island of Kefalonia). A
   lectotype is designated for Atractochaeta graeca Brauer & Bergenstamm,
   1889. Germaria ruficeps (Fallen, 1820) is deleted from the list of Greek
   species. The presence of Germaria graeca (Brauer & Bergenstamm, 1889) is
   confirmed for Greece and this species is also recorded from Turkey and
   Iran for the first time. A key to the reviewed species is provided and
   their distribution data are given.
C1 Ziegler, Joachim; Museum Nat Kunde Berlin, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin,
   Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Two new species, taxonomic notes and a checklist of bagworm moths from
   Madagascar (Lepidoptera, Psychidae).
AU Sobczyk, Thomas (ThomasSobczyk@aol.com) 
   Schuette, Kai
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 59-68
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of Psychidae Saphenewis pulehella sp. n. and Tphonia
   bimaculata sp. n., and the unknown [female] of Tphonia vadonella
   (Viette, 1955) and Typhonic.' (Viette, 1956) are described from
   Madagascar. Sapheneutis pulchella sp" n. is characterized by a distinct
   white ground colour with several black spots. 76p/Ionia banaculata sp.
   n. is described from a [female] and has a brownish ground colour with
   two distinct dark spots on the fore wings. The two species are compared
   with all the known species of Naryciinae and Typhoniinae of Madagascar.
   Typhonia seyrigiella (Viette, 1954) comb. n., Typhonia alluaudiella
   (Viette, 1954) comb. n., Typhonia decaryella (Viette, 1955) comb. n. and
   liphonia fibriculatella (Viette, 1956) comb. n. are transferred from the
   genus Melasina Boisduval, 1840 to Tphonia Boisduval, 1834. A checklist
   or all Psychidae known from Madagascar is provided.
C1 Sobczyk, Thomas; Diesterwegstr 28, Hoyerswerda, Germany, Germany.

TI The cicadas of Iran with the description of two new species (Hemiptera,
   Cicadidae).
AU Mozaffarian, Fariba
   Sanborn, Allen F. (asanborn@mail.barry.edu) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 69-84
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A list of the species of cicadas known to date to occur in Iran is
   catalogued. Cicadatra bistunensis sp.n. and Tettigetto dlabolai sp.n.
   are described and compared to their close relatives. Thirty-eight
   species in 14 genera from 7 tribes of the 3 subfamilies of the family
   Cicadidae constitute the recorded cicada fauna of Iran. Endemic species
   (13 taxa) represent 34.2% of the total fauna.

TI Revision of the snakefly genus Mongoloraphidia (Raphidioptera,
   Raphidiidae) from mainland China.
AU Liu, Xingyue (liu_xingyue@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Aspoeck, Horst
   Yang, Ding
   Aspoeck, Ulrike
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 89-98
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A review of the snakefly genus Mongoloraphidia from mainland China is
   presented. Five species of the genus are recorded from this area, three
   of which are described as new to science, Mongoloraphidia abnormis sp.
   n., Mongoloraphidia liupanshanica sp. n., and Mongoloraphidia yangi sp.
   n. The species Mongoloraphidia choui H. Aspoeck, U. Aspoeck & Yang is
   herein allocated to a junior synonym of Mongoloraphidia duomilia (Yang).

DT Article
TI Notes on weevil species described by Herbst (Erirhinidae, Coleoptera,
   Curculionoidea).
AU Caldara, Roberto (roberto.caldara@gmail.com) 
   Winkelmann, Herbert
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 99-103
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In accordance with the Code, actions are taken to preserve nomenclatural
   stability of 6 taxa currently belonging to Erirhinidae. Having met the
   conditions or ICZN Article 75.3 the neotypes of the following taxa are
   designated: Curculio festucae Herbst, 1795, C. holomelanus Herbst, 1795,
   C. inspectatus Herbst, 1795 and C. rhamni Herbst, 1784. Lectotypes of
   Cumuli inquisitor Herbst, 1797 and. C. obliteratus Herbst, 1795 are also
   designated. Cumuli() inquisitor Herbst, 1797 is newly synonymized with
   Thryogenes festucae (Herbst, 1795). The following synonymies are
   confirmed: Notaris aethiops (Fabricius, 1793) = Curculio holomelanus
   Herbst, 1795, Tanysphyrus lemnae (Fabricius, 1793) = Cumuli inspectatus
   Herbst, 1795, Grypus brunnirostris (Fabricius, 1793) = Curculio
   obliteratus Herbst, 1795, Notaris scirpi (Fabricius, 1792) = Curculio
   rhamni Herbst, 1784. Following the provisions of ICZN Article 23.9.3 the
   reversal of precedence of Notaris scirpi (Fabricius, 1792) (formerly
   Curculio) over Curculio rhamni Herbst, 1784 will be requested to the
   ICZN Commission.

TI Taxonomy of the genus Bisnius Stephens (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Philonthina) from China.
AU Li, Liang
   Zhou, Hong-Zhang (zhouhz@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 105-115
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In this paper, two new species of the genus Bisnius Stephens, 1829
   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina) from China are described and
   illustrated: Bisnius gutianshanus sp. n. from Zhejiang and Bisnius xuae
   sp. n. from Ningxia, Shaanxi and Sichuan. Bisnius fimetarius
   (Gravenhorst, 1802) from Ningxia is reported for the first time from
   China. Thus, seven species of the genus Bisnius are known in total from
   China. An identification key to the Chinese species of the genus Bisnius
   is provided and species geographical distributions are mapped. The type
   specimens of the new species are deposited in Institute of Zoology,
   Chinese Academy of Sciences (IZ-CAS).
C1 Zhou, Hong-Zhang; Chinese Acad Sci, Grad Sch, 19 Yuquan Rd, Beijing,
   China, China.

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Luzea (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Paederinae).
AU Assing, Volker (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 1
PS 117-135
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Luzea Blackwelder, 1912 of the subtribe Medonina is revised.
   Eight species are recognised, among them L. shavrini sp. n. from Iran
   and L. schuelkei sp. n. from Yemen. The distribution of the genus is
   confined to the Western Palaearctic region and Middle Asia.
   (Re-)descriptions or diagnoses and illustrations of the external and
   male sexual characters of all species are provided. The following
   synonymies are proposed: Luzea nigraula (Erichson, 1840) = L. marocana
   Coiffait 1985, syn. it L. infirtna (Erichson, 1840) = L. caucasica
   (Luze, 1912), syn. n., = L. vulpina (Koch, 1938), syn. n., = L.
   deserticola Coiffait, 1984, syn. n. Lauzea rossica (Bernhauer, 1908) and
   L. graeca (Kraatz, 1857) are revalidated. Lectotypes are designated for
   Lithocharis nigritula Erichson, 1840 and Medon vulpinus Koch, 1938. A
   key to species and a catalogue are provided. The distributions of the
   genus as a whole and of the individual species are mapped. Numerous new
   country records are reported.
C1 Assing, Volker; Gabelsbergerstr 2, Hannover, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de

DT Article
TI On the taxonomy and biogeography of West Palaearctic Scopaeina Mulsant &
   Rey (Staphylinidae, Paederinae) with emphasis on the Middle East.
AU Frisch, Johannes (johannes.frisch@mfn-berlin.de) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 2
PS 159-202
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB This contribution supplements the taxonomic and biogeographic knowledge
   of West Palaearctic species of the paederine subtribe Scopaeina Mulsant
   & Rey, 1878. Species descriptions and taxonomic changes concern the
   speciose East Mediterranean - Middle Eastern S. elegans species group.
   Scopaeus alborzensis sp. n. (Iran), S. anlasi sp. n. (Turkey), S.
   assingi sp. n. (Turkey), S. borumandi sp. n. (Iran), S. kermanensis sp.
   n. (Iran), and S. ulughdaghensis sp. n. (Iran) are described and
   compared to related species. Scopaeus armeniacus Coiffait, 1968 and S.
   illyricus Frisch, 1997 are synonymized with S. cameroni Coiffait, 1968.
   Scopaeus heinzi Korge, 1971 is revalidated from synonymy with S.
   bilaminulatus Scheerpeltz, 1957. The diagnostic characters of the Middle
   Eastern species of the S. laevigatus species group (S. azerbaidzhanus
   Gusarov, S. ebneri Scheerpeltz, S. laevigatus (Gyllenhal)) are
   reconsidered owing to the significant clinal variability of the aedeagus
   and the abdominal sternite VIII of the males of S. ebneri. Male and - if
   available - female diagnostic characters are illustrated for the above
   species as well as for S. kurdistanicoides Frisch, S. kurdistanus Korge,
   and S. serriae Frisch. Biogeographic data are presented and discussed
   for Micranops pilicornis (Baudi) and 44 species of Scopaeus. New country
   records are published for Albania (S. cameroni), Armenia (S. cameroni),
   Bulgaria (S. ryei), Greece (S. gladifer), Iran (M. pilicornis, S.
   cameroni, S. mariae, S. minimus), Iraq (S. filiformis), Jordan (S.
   debilis), Kyrgyzstan (S. debilis), Moldavia (S. debilis, S. minutus),
   Oman (S. filiformis), Slovenia (S. ryei), and Syria (S. kurdistanus, S.
   schillhammeri). Records for Central African Republic (S. minimus), "East
   Africa" (S. minimus), Ethiopia (S. laevigatus), Hungary (M. pilicornis),
   Iran (S. alaniensis Coiffait, S. laevigatus, S. minutoides), Oman (S.
   debilis), Saudi Arabia (S. debilis), Sudan (S. minimus), and Ukraine (S.
   cameroni) are implausible and rejected. The distribution is mapped for
   the S. elegans species group (S. bilaminulatus, S. cameroni, and S.
   femursetosus subgroups, S. mariae, S. persicus), S. chalcodactylus, S.
   farsensis, and the Middle Eastern species of the S. laevigatus species
   group. The phylogeography of the S. elegans species group is discussed.
C1 Frisch, Johannes; Humboldt Univ, Museum Nat Kunde, Invalidenstr 43,
   Berlin, Germany, Germany.
EM johannes.frisch@mfn-berlin.de
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0012-0073
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Evolution; Zoogeography;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe; Spain

   distribution record refuted].

   Scopaeus assingi (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 163]. 
   Scopaeus bilaminulatus - Scheerpeltz 1957 (Staphylinidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Scopaeus heinzi Korge 1971, p. 173]. 
   Scopaeus borumandi (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 172]. 
   Scopaeus cameroni - Coiffait, 1968 (Staphylinidae): [Syn nov, Scopaeus
   armeniacus Coiffait, 1968, p. 180; Syn nov, Scopaeus illyricus Frisch

DT Article
TI Species of the Inocellia fulvostigmata group (Raphidioptera,
   Inocelliidae) from China.
AU Liu, Xingyue (liu_xingyue@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Aspoeck, Horst
   Yang, Ding
   Aspoeck, Ulrike
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 2
PS 223-232
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The snakefly genus Inocellia Schneider is the major representative of
   the family Inocelliidae in Asia. It is separated into two species
   groups, namely Inocellia crassicornis group and the Inocellia
   fulvostigmata group. In the present paper, three new species are
   described: Inocellia cheni sp. n., Inocellia hamata sp. n., and
   Inocellia obtusangularis sp. n., as well as Inocellia sinensis Navas,
   1936. Together these four species constitute the I. fulvostigmata group
   of China. Inocellia aspouckorum Yang, 1999 is synonymized with I.
   sinensis. A key to the males of all the members of the I. fulvostigmata
   group is given.
C1 Liu, Xingyue; China Agr Univ, Dept Entomol, Beijing, China, China.
EM liu_xingyue@yahoo.com.cn
RI Liu, Xingyue/A-3019-2013; Aspock, Horst/O-1990-2017
OI Liu, Xingyue/0000-0002-9168-0659; Aspock, Horst/0000-0001-9407-3566
SC Zoology
SN 0012-0073

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Inocellia hamata [Hubei /  / New species]. 
   Inocellia obtusangularis [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

   Inocellia fulvostigmata group (Raphidioptera): [Revision, P. 224; Key to
   species, Males, p. 224]. 
   Inocellia hamata (Raphidioptera): [Sp nov, Hubei, P. 226]. 
   Inocellia obtusangularis (Raphidioptera): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P. 228].

   aspouckorum, p. 228].

DT Article
TI On Ctenolepisma ciliata and a new related species, Ctenolepisma
   armeniaca sp n. (Zygentoma, Lepismatidae).
AU Molero-Baltanas, Rafael (ba1mobar@uco.es) 
   Gaju-Ricart, Miquel
   Bach de Roca, Carmen
   Mendes, Luis F.
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 2
PS 243-252
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB On the basis of specimens from the type locality in Valencia (Spain)
   Ctenolepisma ciliata (Dufour, 1831) is redescribed and its variability
   is studied examining some other specimens from Spain as well as
   Western-Mediterranean countries. With this study as reference, some
   other specimens determined previously as Ctenolepisma ciliata can be
   compared. In this light, it is possible to conclude that some of them do
   not belong to the species described by Dufour. This is the case of some
   specimens from the Canary Islands identified as C. vieirai Mendes 1981,
   and specially one specimen from Armenia studied by Mendes (1982). This
   specimen is bigger than C. ciliata and shows a different setation,
   specially in the thoracic sternites: in the mesosternum and the
   metasternum, macrosetae are arranged in one single row in Ctenolepisma
   ciliata and in two parallel rows in the Armenian insect; in the
   prosternum, the first species shows 12 irregular lines of macrosetae and
   the Armenian specimen shows 2-3 lines. The validity of this character
   has been demonstrated recently to separate C. lineata (Fabricius, 1775)
   from C. almeriensis Molero-Baltanas et al., 2005. This characteristic
   and some others allow us to create the new species Ctenolepisma
   armeniaca sp. n.
C1 Molero-Baltanas, Rafael; Univ Cordoba, Dept Zool C1, Campus Rabanales,
   Cordoba, Spain, Spain.
EM ba1mobar@uco.es
RI Mendes, Luis/N-3140-2013
OI Mendes, Luis/0000-0002-2873-6066
SC Zoology
SN 0012-0073
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Ctenolepisma armeniaca [Armenia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Thysanura
OR Ctenolepisma armeniaca (Thysanura): [Sp nov, Armenia, P. 248]. 
   Ctenolepisma ciliata - (Dufour 1831) (Thysanura): [Redescription, P.
   244]. 
DI 10.1002/mmnd.201000021
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704027572
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14704027573
DT Article
TI Carinosella maasaiorum, new genus and new species of Adelostomini from
   Maasai land in Africa (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae).
AU Purchart, Lubos (lubos.purchart@post.cz) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 2
PS 253-257
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Carinosella gen. n. is described (by monotypy) from Maasai land in
   Africa with one new species Carinosella maasaiorum sp. n. The genus
   belongs to stridulating eurychoroid Adelostomini and is related to the
   genus Symphochora Koch, 1952.

TI Revision of the African genus Acroprivesa Schmidt, 1912 (Hemiptera,
   Fulgoromorpha, Ricaniidae).
AU Stroinski, Adam (adam@miiz.waw.pl) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 2
PS 259-270
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The African genus Acroprivesa Schmidt, 1912 (type-species Acroprivesa
   suturalis Schmidt, 1912) is reviewed and re-interpreted based on two
   recent and one fossil species. Lectopype and paralectotypes are
   designated for A. suturalis Schmidt, 1912. A. bifurcata sp. n. is
   described. The distribution of the genus suggests an East Africa origin
   and the present distribution as the result of post-glacial expansion and
   evolution. Environmental data for extinct and recent species suggest
   also a probable connection with trees and bushes of family Fabaceae
   (subfamily Caesalpinioideae).

TI An enigmatic new leafhopper genus, Protochiasmus (Hemiptera,
   Cicadellidae, Deltocephalinae), from Brazil.
AU Zahniser, James N. (zahniser@illinois.edu) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 57
IS 2
PS 271-274
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new brachypterous leafhopper genus and species of Deltocephalinae,
   Protochiasmus mysticus gen. n., sp. n. from Brazil, are described. The
   genus is not easily placed to tribe partly due to the lack of known
   females which may provide characters that are diagnostic to the tribal
   level and also due to the unique combination of morphological characters
   in the male. Based on these morphological characters and on recent
   molecular and morphological phylogenetic analyses of Deltocephalinae,
   Protochiasmus is tentatively placed in Chiasmini.

DT Article
TI [New and little known taxa of the Scutelluinae, Proetinae and
   Otarioninae (Trilobita) from the Middle Devonian of the Blankenheim
   Syncline, the Hillesheim Syncline and the Prum Syncline (Eifel
   synclines).]
FT Neue und wenig bekannte Taxa der Scutelluinae, Proetinae und Otarioninae
   (Trilobita) aus dem Mitteldevon der Blankenheim-, Hillesheim- und
   Pruem-Mulde (Eifel).
AU Basse, Martin (martin.basse@senckenberg.de) 
SO Dortmunder Beitraege zur Landeskunde
VL 42
PS 75-119
PD 2009-2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 2
AB This contribution is dealing with aspects of systematics of the
   following taxa: Scutelluinae: New data are provided on Goldius of the
   Nohn Formation and the Cur-ten Formation. Proetinae: New diagnoses are
   performed for the three dominating proetine genera in the Middle
   Devonian of the Ardenno-Rhenish Mountains, which are Gerastos, Dohmiella
   and Rhenocynproetus. Gerastos leunisseni n. sp. comes from the Eilenberg
   Member of the Freilingen Formation (late Eifelian). Otarioninae:
   Cyphaspis sp. Z (Ahbach Formation, earliest Givetian) has eleven
   thoracic segments. Therefore, the new species is important for the
   discussion of both Cyphaspis and the insufficiently known Otarionella.
   Chamaeleoaspis novum genus includes Cyphaspis chamaeleo and Otarionella
   Ikomalii, the holaspids of which having ten thoracic segments and a
   spiny cephalon. Otarionella is restricted to its type species. Basic
   information is provided about the formerly largely unknown trilobites of
   the Zerberus Member of the Mullert Subformation (Ahbach Formation,
   earliest Givetian).

   genus and the related species Virgodinium asymmetricum n. sp.,

   Virgodinium. Another result is the relocation of the taxon Gonyaulax

DT Article
TI Cranial anatomy of a new genus of hyperodapedontine rhynchosaur
   (Diapsida, Archosauromorpha) from the Upper Triassic of southern Brazil.
AU Montefeltro, Felipe Chinaglia (felipecm@pg.ffclrp.usp.br) 
   Langer, Max Cardoso
   Schultz, Cesar Leandro
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 101
IS 1
PS 27-52
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Detailed description of the cranial anatomy of the rhynchosaur
   previously known as Scaphonyx sulcognathus allows its assignment to a
   new genus Teyumbaita. Two nearly complete skulls and a partial skull
   have been referred to the taxon, all of which come from the lower part
   of the Caturrita Formation, Upper Triassic of Rio Grande do Sul,
   southern Brazil. Cranial autapomorphies of Teyumbaita sulcognathus
   include anterior margin of nasal concave at midline, prefrontal
   separated from the ascending process of the maxilla, palatal ramus of
   pterygoid expanded laterally within palatines, dorsal surface of
   exoccipital markedly depressed, a single tooth lingually displaced from
   the main medial tooth-bearing area of the maxilla, and a number of other
   characters (such as skull broader than long; a protruding orbital
   anterior margin; anguli oris extending to anterior ramus of the jugal;
   bar between the orbit and the lower temporal fenestra wider than
   0[center dot]4 of the total orbital opening; mandibular depth reaching
   more than 25 of the total length) support its inclusion in
   Hyperodapedontinae. T. sulcognathus is the only potential Norian
   rhynchosaur, suggesting that the group survived the end-Carnian
   extinction event.
C1 Montefeltro, Felipe Chinaglia; Laboratorio de Paleontologia,
   Departamento de Biologia, Faculdade de Filosofia, Ciencias e Letras de
   Ribeirao Preto, Universidade de Sao Paulo, Av. Bandeirantes 3900,
   14040-901, Ribeirao Preto, SP, Brazil, Brazil.
EM felipecm@pg.ffclrp.usp.br

DT Article
TI Late Ordovician (Katian) brachiopods from the Southern Uplands of
   Scotland: biogeographic patterns on the edge of Laurentia.
AU Candela, Yves (y.candela@nms.ac.uk) 
   Harper, David A.T.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 100
IS 3
PS 253-274
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Some 40 brachiopod species are known from the localities of Kilbucho and
   Wallace's Cast in the Kirkcolm Formation in the Northern Belt of the
   Southern Uplands of Scotland. The fauna is diverse despite the
   relatively small numbers of brachiopod specimens (c. 180) available for
   study. Much of the fauna was transported downslope and is locally
   preserved in obtrution deposits. It represents a broad census of outer
   shelf and upper slope palaeocommunities around this part of the
   Laurentian margin during the early Katian, and is dominated by
   relatively small plectambonitoid brachiopods. When compared with other
   circum-lapetus assemblages, the brachiopods from the Southern Uplands
   compare most closely with those from the Bardahessiagh Formation,
   Pomeroy, Northern Ireland, rather than with adjacent, well-known faunas
   from the Girvan district, SW Scotland. These new data suggest that this
   part of the Southern Uplands was located in closer proximity to Pomeroy
   than Girvan, and located in deep-water environments similar to those in
   the upper parts of the Bardahessiagh Formation.
C1 Candela, Yves; Natl Museums Collect Ctr, 242 W Granton Rd, Edinburgh,
   Midlothian, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM y.candela@nms.ac.uk
RI Harper, David/AAX-7473-2020; Harper, David A.T./C-6888-2012
OI Harper, David/0000-0003-1315-9494; Harper, David
   A.T./0000-0003-1315-9494

   &Freshwater Biology

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom;

AN ZOOR14704029474
DT Article
TI [dagger]Henningsmoenicaris scutula, [dagger]Sandtorpia vestrogothiensis
   gen. et sp nov and heterochronic events in early crustacean evolution.
AU Haug, Joachim T.
   Maas, Andreas
   Waloszek, Dieter
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 100
IS 3
PS 311-350
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A detailed account of the morphology and ontogeny of the late Middle
   Cambrian crustacean [dagger]Henningsmoenicaris scutula is presented. Ten
   successive ontogenetic stages could be recognised in the material
   collected from various localities in Sweden. Morphogenetic changes
   include the development of a pair of stalked lateral eyes and the
   increase in the number and size of appendages and their setal armature.
   Notably, early stages lack 'proximal endites' on all post-antennular
   appendages; such a spine-bearing endite has previously been thought to
   appear simultaneously on these limbs. In [dagger]H. scutula a single
   functional endite appears on the third limb in an advanced stage; an
   additional endite appears on the second limb and, subsequently, further
   endites appear on more posterior limbs. Furthermore, a single specimen
   of [dagger]Sandtorpia vestrogothiensis gen. et sp. nov. is described.
   Based on this new information and data of other 'Orsten' taxa,
   particularly those assigned already to the early evolutionary lineage of
   Crustacea, a small-scale computer-based phylogenetic analysis was
   performed. This resolved the basal branchings of Crustacea s. I. as
   follows: Oelandocarididae (=[dagger]Oelandocaris oelandica+[dagger]H.
   scutula+[dagger]S. vestrogothienss)+([dagger]Cambropachycopidae
   (=[dagger]Goticaris longispinosa+[dagger]Cambropachycope clarksoni) +
   ([dagger]Martinssonia elongata+Labrophora
   (=[dagger]Phosphatocopina+Eucrustacea))). Plotting ontogenetic data on
   the phylogram and comparing the ground pattern at every node led to the
   detection of three peramorphic heterochronic events in the evolutionary
   lineage towards Eucrustacea.
C1 Haug, Joachim T.; Univ Ulm, Helmholtzstr 20, Ulm, Germany, Germany.
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary Biology; Anatomy
   &Morphology; Paleontology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Techniques; Life cycle and development; Evolution; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Crustacea [Development / Heterochronic events in early evolution / ]
   [Evolutionary adaptation /  / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic analysis / ]. 
   Henningsmoenicaris scutula [Biometrical techniques / 4D modelling / ]
   [Palaeontological techniques /  / ] [Development / Ontogenetic series /
   ] [Evolution /  / ] [Sweden /  / ] [Cambrian / Middle Cambrian / ]. 
   Oelandocarididae [Cambrian /  / New clade]. 
   Sandtorpia [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Sandtorpia vestrogothiensis [Sweden /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea
OR Crustacea (Arthropoda). 
   Henningsmoenia - Walossek & Muller 1990 (Crustacea): [Referred to, New
   clade Oelandocarididae, p. 314; Fossil]. 
   Henningsmoenicaris scutula - Walossek & Mueller 1990 (Crustacea):
   [Redescription, P. 315; Fossil]. 
   Oelandocarididae (Crustacea): [Taxon nov, New clade, For Henningsmoenia
   Walossek & Muller 1990, Oelandocaris Muller 1983 & Sandtorpia (new), p.
   314, Cambrian; Fossil].

DT Article
TI A new spreite trace fossil from Lower Cretaceous limestone (Western
   Carpathians, Slovakia).
AU Michalik, Jozef (vladosimo@yahoo.com) 
   Simo, Vladimir
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 100
IS 4
PS 417-427
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Zavitokichnus fusiformis n. igen. et n. isp. occurs in Lower Cretaceous
   (Valanginian to Hauterivian) limestones of the Fatric Superunit in the
   Western Carpathians. Typical cross sections of this more or less spiral
   trace fossil are sometimes U[long dash]O[long dash]C[long dash]S-shaped.
   In cross-section the trace fossil passes from a simple linear form, and
   spreads to a wider rolled-up or rolled-out form and then it returns to a
   linear trace. Spreite-like lamellae are distinguishable on several
   cross-section examples. The trace fossil was produced by a deposit
   feeder and it might be classified as a fodinichnion. Z. fusiformis
   co-occurs with trace fossil associations of Zoophycos, Chondrites,
   Planolites, Hormosiroidea and Palaeophycus in carbonate sediments of a
   deep-seated ramp along the margin of the Fatric intrashelf basin.
C1 Michalik, Jozef; Dubravska cesta 9, P.O. Box 106, 840 05, Bratislava,
   Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM vladosimo@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Zavitokichnus [Fossil traces / New genus, Cretaceous / ] [Cretaceous / 
   / New genus described from fossil trace]. 
   Zavitokichnus fusiformis [Fossil traces / New species, Cretaceous,
   Slovakia / ] [Slovakia /  / new species; Described from fossil trace]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Zavitokichnus (Animalia): [Gen nov, Type species Zavitokichnus
   fusiformis, p. 419, Cretaceous, Described from fossil trace; Fossil]. 
   Zavitokichnus fusiformis (Animalia): [Sp nov, Slovakia, Cretaceous, P.
   420, Described from fossil trace; Fossil].

DT Article
TI First Report of the Late Pleistocene Fossil Lizards from Narmada Basin,
   Central India.
AU Joshi, Moulishree
   Kotlia, B.S. (bahadur.kotlia@gmail.com) 
SO Earth Science India
VL 3
IS 1
PS 1-8
PD 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.earthscienceindia.info/archiv.php?year=2010&month=January
AW http://www.earthscienceindia.info/archiv.php?year=2010&month=January
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The fossil agamid lizards are reported from a Late Pleistocene locality
   (ca 0.74 ka in age) in the Narmada valley, central India. Although the
   fossil materia is scanty, it is described keeping in view that, the
   fossil lizards are barely studied from south Asia, and secondly, this is
   the only report of fossil lizards from the Narmada valley. With the help
   of the jaw fragments and isolated teeth, the material is assigned to a
   new species, Agama schleichi sp.nov. The presence o lizards indicates
   dry/arid to semi-arid oscillations within otherwise warm/humid climatic
   conditions in the Narmada basin around the time of the Homo erectus the
   only known Homo from India.
C1 Kotlia, B.S.; Department of Geology, Kumaun University, Nainital, 263
   002, India, India.
EM bahadur.kotlia@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Agama schleichi [Madhya Pradesh /  / new species] [Pleistocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Agamidae
OR Agama schleichi (Agamidae): [Sp nov, Madhya Pradesh, Pleistocene, P. 3;
   Fossil].
