DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Description of a new phytoseiid mite species (Acari: Phytoseiidae) from
   Egypt with a special reference to its biology.
AU Romeih, Amal H.M. (Rehamaboshnaf@yahoo.com) 
   Abo-Shnaf, Reham I.A.
   Hassan, M.F.
   Rizk, Marguerite A.
SO Egyptian Academic Journal of Biological Sciences A Entomology
VL 3
IS 2
PS 27-36
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The adult female and male of the phytoesiid mite, Euseius plumerii
   Abo-Shanf & Romeih sp. n. were collected from leaves of both White
   Frangipani (Plumeria alba) and Rose (Rosa hybrida cv. Huddly) at Giza
   Governorate, Egypt, then identified and described. Furthermore, the
   description of immature stages was also presented. The life history of
   this new species were documented on the two spotted- spider mite,
   Tetranychus urticae Koch movable stages which infested leaves of rose at
   three temperature degrees (20, 25 and 30[plus or minus]2 [degree]C) and
   relative humidity of 70[plus or minus]5%. The results proved that,
   30[degree]C was the most suitable temperature degree which accelerated
   the life cycle, gave highly egg production and greatly prey consumption.
C1 Romeih, Amal H.M.; Vegetable and Ornamental Acarology Department, Plant
   Protection Research Institute, Agricultural Research Centre, Giza,
   Egypt, Egypt.
EM Rehamaboshnaf@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1687-8809; 2090-0813
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Africa
DE Euseius plumerii [Egypt /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Euseius plumerii - Abo-Shanf & Romeih 2010 (Acari): [Sp nov, Egypt, P.
   28]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14712082484

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Monomorium moathi sp. n., a new ant species from Yemen (Hymenoptera:
   Formicidae) related to the salomonis-group.
AU Aldawood, Abdulrahman S.
   Sharaf, Mostafa R. (antsharaf@yahoo.com) 
   Collingwood, Cedric A.
SO Egyptian Academic Journal of Biological Sciences A Entomology
VL 3
IS 2
PS 37-42
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Monomorium moathi sp. n. is described and illustrated from Yemen based
   on the worker caste. This species belongs to the Monomorium
   salomonis-group, with closest resemblance to M. areniphilum Santschi,
   1911. It is distinguished from the latter species by the following
   characters: Eyes oval, relatively large with eleven ommatidia in the
   longest row; Petiole node high and pointed in profile; Head, mesosoma
   and waist distinctly shagreenate granulate. Gaster finely shagreenate.
   Head dorsum, mesosoma, petiole, postpetiole and gastral tergites without
   hairs.
C1 Sharaf, Mostafa R.; Plant Protection Department, College of Food and
   Agriculture Sciences, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, PO Box 2460,
   Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabia.
EM antsharaf@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1687-8809; 2090-0813

   Eurasia; Asia

   Formicoidea, Formicidae

   Yemen, P. 38].

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A new predatory mite species of the genus Eustigmaeus (Stigmaeidae:
   Acari) from Punjab, Pakistan.
AU Khan, Bilal Saeed (bsk_1703@yahoo.com) 
   Afzal, Muhammad
   Bashir, Muhammad Hamid
SO Egyptian Academic Journal of Biological Sciences A Entomology
VL 3
IS 2
PS 149-153
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Mites belonging to the family stigmaeidae are known predators against
   the phytophagous mites and small soft-bodied insects. A survey was
   conducted to explore the predatory mite fauna of Punjab (Pakistan), a
   new predatory mite species of genus Eust igmaeus (Eust igmaeus hooriaae)
   was col lected from Ameen Pur Bangla, 20 mi les away north from district
   Faisalabad (Punjab) from Triticum aestivum (straw husk) by Bilal Saeed
   Khan and described here in this manuscript . Specimens were mounted on
   the glass slides with the help of Hoyer's medium. The drawings of
   different body parts were made with the help of an ocular grid in a high
   power microscope. These specimens were compared with the already
   described species. Ceremonial description, illustration of main body
   parts, host range and comparison remarks are also given. Eighteen (18)
   paratype females were collected. Twelve (12) from the same collection
   data and six (6) were collected from R.Y.Khan from leaf litter. All
   specimens were deposited in the Acarology Research Laboratory,
   Department of Agri. Entomology, University of Agriculture, Faisalabad
   Pakistan.
C1 Khan, Bilal Saeed; Deptt. of Agri. Entomology, University of Agricult.,
   Faisalabad, Egypt, Egypt.
EM bsk_1703@yahoo.com

   region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI On some exogonines (Polychaeta, Syllidae, Exogoninae) from the north
   coast of Egypt.
AU Abd-Elnaby, Faiza A. (Faiza_abdelnaby@yahoo.com) 
SO Egyptian Journal of Aquatic Research
VL 36
IS 2
PS 277-292
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Many specimens of Syllidae were sampled during several collection trips
   to different parts of Egyptian coastline from North to West. Most of
   these are typical meiofaunal species belonging to the subfamilies
   Exogoninae, Eusyllinae and Syllinae. In this paper, 9 species belonging
   to subfamily Exogoninae, genera Exogne, Sphaerosyllis and Brania are
   described. Two of them (Sphaerosyllis giandoi Somaschini and San Martin,
   1994 and Exogone (Parexogone) gambiae Lanera, Sordino & San Martin,
   1994) are endemic to the Mediterranean, while Brania arminii
   Hartmann-Schroder, 1971 is circumtropical species. Sphaerosyllis sp. San
   Martin, 2003, Sphaerosyllis glandulata San Martin, 1991 and
   Sphaerosyllis sandrae Alvarez and San Martin, 2008 are amphi-Atlantic,
   while, Prosphaerosyllis fujianensis Ding & Westheide, 2008 and Exogone
   (Parexogone) sexoculata Hartmann-Schroder, 1979 are Indo Pacific
   species, they seem to be Lessepsian migrant species.
C1 Abd-Elnaby, Faiza A.; National Institute of Oceanography and Fisheries,
   Alexandria, Egypt, Egypt.
EM Faiza_abdelnaby@yahoo.com

   [Mediterranean Sea / Egypt / New record].

LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of Dyscolus Dejean (Platynini) are given based on
   morphological features specially those used by PERRAULT (1992) to
   separate species due to thoracic measures: Prothoracic Index (IP),
   Maximum Length (WP) and Medial Length (LP). Type specimens were
   deposited in Museum of Natural History of the Universidad Pedagogica
   Nacional de Colombia (UPN-MHN) and paratypes were labeled in Personal
   Collection of Edgar Camero-R. (CPECR) under consecutive collection
   numbers. Ecological information of types and their taxonomic
   relationships with similar species are mentioned as complement.

TI Revision of the subgenus Eucatops Portevin, 1903 (Coleoptera: Leiodidae:
   Cholevinae: Eucatopini).
FT Revision del subgenero Eucatops Portevin, 1903 (coleoptera: Leiodidae:
   Cholevinae: Eucatopini).
AU Salgado, Jose Ma (jmsalgadocostas@uvigo.es) 
SO Elytron (Barcelona)
VL 24
PS 27-76
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB The subgenus Eucatops Portevin, 1903 is revised. It is actually
   represented by 30 species, with Neotropical distribution; this paper
   provides an identification key for them. Two new species of subgenus
   Eucatops are described; E. (E) peruensis sp. n. and E. (E.)
   tungurahuaensis sp. n. Two new synonymies are established; E. (E.)
   minutus Peck & Cook from E. obtusus Gnaspini and E. (E.) curvipes
   dilatatus Salgado from E. (E.) curvipes Portevin. Numerous new records
   for several species are mentioned.

TI SYSTEMATICS OF THE GENUS OVIEDINUS NOV. (COLEOPTERA: PTINIDAE),
   INCLUDING A FOSSIL NEW SPECIES FROM DOMINICAN AMBER, BIOGEOGRAPHICAL
   REMARKS AND AN ACCOUNT ON FOSSIL PTINIDS.
AU Belles, Xavier (xavier.belles@ibe.upf-csic.es) 
SO Elytron (Barcelona)
VL 24
PS 77-88
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Oviedinus gen. n. (Coleoptera: Ptinidae) is described from the
   Caribbean region, including the species Ptinus semiobscurus Pic and
   Ptinus lotus Pic from Brazil, Minus tesellatus Gorham from Moustique
   Island, Ptinus strangulatus Fall from Florida, Ptinus dufaui Pic from
   Guadalupe, Ptinus angustithorax Belles from Venezuela. Ptinus espanyoli
   Belles from Jamaica and the fossil new species Oviedinus hispaniolensis
   from Dominican amber collected at Hispaniola. Oviedinus falls in the
   vicinity of Gynopterus Mulsant & Rey, but the peculiar structure of the
   prothorax of the new genus, with the posterior constriction showing a
   well delimited smooth groove, distinguishes it from Gynopterus, which
   presents a simple constriction.

AB A new species of genus Stagetus Wollaston, 1861, (Coleoptera, Ptinidae,
   Dorcatominae) is described from Aragon, in the provinces of Huesca and
   Zaragoza. The specimens were collected during campaigns set up in the
   area of La Retuerta by J. Blasco Zumeta, to study the biodiversity of
   insects in 1993, and in the area of northern Monegros by R. Macia and J.
   Ylla, to study the biodiversity of Lepidoptera in 2011. Stagetus maciai
   sp. n. is well characterized and differentiated from other species of
   the genus by the shape of the prothorax, by punctured elytral striae and
   the surface of the intervals, and especially by the shape of the middle
   lobe of the aedeagus, the lobes of the parameres and the structure of
   the internal sac of median lobe evaginated, in addition to other details
   of the external morphology, antennae, last segment of the maxillary
   palps, pubescence, etc.
C1 Vinolas, Amador; Univ Barcelona, Fac Biol, Ave Diagonal 645, Barcelona,
   E-08028, Spain, Spain.
EM av.rodama@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0214-1353
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Stagetus maciai [Spain /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14701005489
DT Article
TI Pityogenes chalcographus (Coleoptera: Scolytinae) at the southernmost
   borderline of Norway spruce (Picea abies) in Greece.
AU Avtzis, D.N. (dimitrios.avtzis@fri.gr) 
   Arthofer, W.
   Stauffer, C.
   Avtzis, N.
   Wegensteiner, R.
SO Entomologia Hellenica
VL 19
PS 3-13
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The six toothed bark beetle, Pityogenes chalcographus L. (Coleoptera:
   Scolytinae) is a widely distributed pest in Europe, infesting mainly
   Norway spruce (Picea abies) as well as other conifer species such as
   Pinus sp., Abies alba, Larix deciduas, L. sibirica and Pseudotsuga
   douglasii. Even though the distribution of this bark beetle coincides
   that of its main host tree, P. abies, the occurrence of P. chalcographus
   has never been recorded in the spruce forest of Elatia-Drama, Northern
   Greece, which is the southernmost area of the natural, autochthonous
   distribution of P. abies. In this study we installed five pheromone
   traps baited with chalcogran dispensers in the forest of Elatia. The
   total number of bark beetles attracted to these traps exceeded several
   thousands of individuals. Norway spruce trees growing in the natural
   forest of Elatia demonstrate low vigor, something that can be attributed
   to the marginal environmental conditions in concert with the effects of
   climate change. The combination of these factors inhibits the regular
   growth of spruce, rendering trees more susceptible to the attack of P.
   chalcographus.
C1 Avtzis, D.N.; Forest Research Institute, National Agricultural Research
   Foundation, Vasilika, Greece, Greece.
EM dimitrios.avtzis@fri.gr
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0254-5381
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Pityogenes chalcographus [Plant hosts / Picea abies / New record]
   [Greece / Elatia Drama / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Pityogenes chalcographus (Curculionidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701005489
DA 2020-09-17

TI First record of the ant-loving cricket Myrmecophilus ochraceus for
   Zakynthos (Greece) with notes on the synonymy of Myrmecophilus salomonis
   (Orthoptera: Myrmecophilidae).
AU Stalling, Thomas (Stalling@gmx.de) 
SO Entomologia Hellenica
VL 19
PS 34-38
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The first record of Myrmecophilus ochraceus Fischer, 1853 (Orthoptera:
   Myrmecophilidae) for Zakynthos (Greece) is given. Photographs of this
   species and its habitat are presented for the first time. Myrmecophilus
   salomonis Wasmann, 1890 is recognized as a junior synonym of
   Myrmecophilus ochraceus.

DT Article
TI The Bougainvillea mealybug Phenacoccus peruvianus, a rapid invader from
   South America to Europe.
AU Beltra, A.
   Soto, A. (asoto@eaf.upv.es) 
   Germain, J.-F.
   Matile-Ferrero, D.
   Mazzeo, G.
   Pellizzari, G.
   Russo, A.
   Franco, J.C.
   Williams, D.J.
SO Entomologia Hellenica
VL 19
PS 137-143
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Scale insects are frequent invaders of new territories. The
   Bougainvillea mealybug, Phe- nacoccus peruvianus Granara de Willink,
   2007, was recorded in Europe for the first time in 1999 in Spain
   (Almeria) and later in 2002 in Italy (Sicily). Initially, this unknown
   species was identified provisionally as Phenacoccus sp. Records of this
   species became frequent later when it was found in other localities in
   Spain (including the Balearic Islands), Great Britain, France (including
   Corsica), Monaco, and Portugal. The host plants of this mealybug were in
   most cases species of Bougainvillea.
C1 Soto, A.; Institut Agroforestal Mediterrani, CPI Acceso 8E, Universitat
   Politecnica de Valencia, 46022 Valencia, Spain, Spain.
EM asoto@eaf.upv.es

DT Article
TI REVISION OF THE PLANT BUG TRIBE PHYLINI FROM NEPAL (HETEROPTERA:
   MIRIDAE: PHYLINAE).
AU Duwal, Ram Keshari
   Yasunaga, Tomohide (tyasunaga@amnh.org) 
   Lee, Seunghwan
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 116
IS 1-2
PS 1-48
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Thirty species in 13 genera of plant bugs (Phylinae: Phylini) from Nepal
   are revised in a first attempt to comprehensively clarify the fauna from
   this country. Five new genera, Alnopsallus, Aplagiognathus, Leucophylus,
   Psallomorpha and Zanchiophylus, are proposed. The following 21 species
   are described as new: Alnopsallus godawari, Al. jiriensis,
   Aplagiognathus albopilosus, Atractotomoidea monticola, Al. orientalis,
   Campylomma buddlejae, C chitwanense, Decomia bhaktapurana, Europiella
   langtangensis, E. puspae, Leucophylus variegatus, Moissonia schuhi, M.
   terai, Psallomorpha alba, P. castanopsis, P. kathmandu, P. quercicola,
   P. tenella, P. tomokunii, Rubrocuneocoris nigriceps, and Zanchiophylus
   hyaloviridis. Nine described species of the genera Badezorus,
   Campylomma, Decomia, Opuna, and Moissonia are reported from Nepal for
   the first time and are diagnosed. Opuna Yasunaga is proposed as a junior
   synonym of Moissonia importunitas (Distant). Digital photographic images
   of live individuals and detailed male genitalic figures are presented
   for most species. Female genitalic structures, which have been
   insufficiently employed for previous phyline classification, are also
   described and illustrated for 20 species. Zoogeography and
   characteristics of the Nepalese phyline fauna are also discussed. Host
   plants are confirmed for 12 species.

TI DESCRIPTION OF SCHUHISTES N. GEN (HETEROPTERA: MIRIDAE: PHYLINAE), A NEW
   PLANT BUG GENUS FOUND ON ENDEMIC LYCIUM SPP. (SOLANACEAE) FROM SOUTH
   AFRICA.
AU Menard, Katrina L. (menardk@copper.net) 
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 116
IS 1-2
PS 49-57
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Schuhistes, a new genus of Leucophoropterini (Heteroptera: Miridae:
   Phylinae) is described from South Africa to accommodate two new species,
   Schuhistes lyciae and Schuhistes lekkersingia. Diagnoses, digital
   habitus images, illustrations of male and female genitalic structures,
   and detailed locality data are provided. Host data, scanning micrographs
   of diagnostic morphological structures the head, vestiture, scent-gland
   evaporatory area, gonopore, and pretarsus - are included for both
   species.

TI BACILLOMETROIDES, A NEW GENUS OF HYDROMETRIDAE (HETEROPTERA) FOR THREE
   PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED SPECIES FROM SOUTH AMERICA.
AU Polhemus, John T.
   Polhemus, Dan A. (bugman@bishopmuseum.org) 
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 116
IS 1-2
PS 58-63
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The South American genus Bacillometra as previously interpreted does not
   represent a monophyletic assemblage, thus Bacillometroides n. gen. is
   proposed to hold all species previously contained in this genus with the
   exception of B. ventralis Esaki, the type species of Bacillometra. The
   following new combinations are proposed: Bacillometra fuallagana Drake,
   1956 = Bacillometroides fuallagana (Drake); Bacillometra mulfordi
   (Hungerford, 1927) = Bacillometroides mulfordi (Hungerford);
   Bacillometra woytkowskii Hungerford, 1935 = Bacillometroides woytkowskii
   (Hungerford). Figures are provided of the dorsal habitus for
   Bacillometra ventralis and Bacillometroides woytkowskii, and a
   distribution map is provided for all species in both genera.
C1 Polhemus, Dan A.; Bishop Museum, Dept Nat Sci, 1525 Bernice St,
   Honolulu, HI, USA, USA.
EM bugman@bishopmuseum.org

   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key

   New genus Bacillometroides, p. 60].

   62].

   to, New genus Bacillometroides, p. 62].

   mulfordi Hungerford 1927, p. 58; Key to species, P. 63].

DT Article
TI NEOTERMES GNATHOFERRUM (ISOPTERA: KALOTERMITIDAE), A NEW SPECIES FROM
   FIJI THAT INFESTS MAHOGANY.
AU Ware, Jessica L. (jware@amnh.org) 
   Lal, Sanjana
   Grimaldi, David A.
SO Entomologica Americana
VL 116
IS 1-2
PS 64-72
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of Neotermes, N. gnathoferrum, is described based on
   soldiers, imagoes, queens and workers. Neotermes gnathoferrum is one of
   three Fijian species of Neotermes, along with N. papua and N. samoanus,
   known to infest mahogany as well as other economically important native
   trees. A diagnostic key is provided to distinguish these species. The
   lectotype and paralectotypes for Neotermes papua are also designated
   here.
C1 Ware, Jessica L.; Amer Museum Nat Hist, Div Invertebrate Zool, 81 St &
   Cent Pk W, New York, NY, USA, USA.
EM jware@amnh.org
OI Ware, Jessica/0000-0002-4066-7681

   Key; Land zones; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

TI Aphidius geranii sp n. (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) from southeast Europe -
   a new member of the Aphidius urticae s. str. group.
AU Petrovic, Andjeljko
   Tomanovic, Zeljko (ztoman@bio.bg.ac.rs) 
   Kavallieratos, Nickolas G.
   Stary, Petr
   Zikic, Vladimir
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 20
IS 4
PS 233-238
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Aphidius geranii Tomanovic and Kavallieratos, sp. n., is described as an
   additional member of the Aphidius urticae s. str. group from
   high-mountain habitats of Southeast Europe. The new species was reared
   from Amphorophora sp./Geranium coeruleatum associations. Parasitoid
   guilds associated with G. coeruleatum are discussed. Key for
   identification of Aphidius spp. on Geranium plants in Europe is given.

DT Article
TI New taxa of oribatid mites of the family Liacaridae (Acariformes:
   Oribatida) from the Caucasus.
AU Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya. (umukusum@mail.ru) 
   Subias, Luis S.
   Arillo, Antonio
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 20
IS 4
PS 245-248
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper new taxa belonging to the family Liacaridae from the
   Caucasus (Georgia) are described: a new subgenus and species Adoristes
   (Gordeeviella) krivolutskyi subg. n., sp. n. and a new species Liacarus
   (Liacarus) longipilis sp. n. The new subgenus Adoristes (Gordeeviella)
   differs from Adoristes (Adoristes) Hull, 1916 by the shape of its
   sensilla, with the tip sharply pointed, and of its lamellae, without
   cuspis. The new species Liacarus (L.) longipilis differs from the rest
   of species of Liacarus by the presence of very long notogastral setae.
C1 Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya.; Russian Acad Sci, Caspian Inst Biol
   Resources, Makhachkala, Russia, Russia.
EM umukusum@mail.ru
OI Arillo, Antonio/0000-0002-4878-5797

SN 0785-8760

   Eurasia; Asia

   [Georgia-Asia /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari

   (Gordeeviella) krivolutskyi, p. 245].

TI Description of two new species of Hypogastrura Bourlet, 1839 of the H.
   crassaegranulata group (Collembola: Hypogastruridae) from the Caucasus,
   with notes on some related species.
AU Skarzynski, Dariusz (hypogast@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
   Babenko, Anatoly
SO Entomologica Fennica
VL 20
IS 4
PS 275-280
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A revision of 'Hypogastrura crassaegranulata' material from the eastern
   Palaearctic was done as all records before 2006 referred to H.
   crassaegranulata have become unclear after recent redescription of the
   species. It shown that among four forms mentioned under this name by
   Babenko et al. (1994) none belongs to true H. crassaegranulata. Two of
   these forms are in fact species new to science described and illustrated
   below as H. tepli sp. n. and H. aushensis sp. n. (Russia, Northern
   Caucasus). Two others appear to be H. franconiana (Stach, 1949) and H.
   szeptyckii Skarzynski, 2006 firstly recorded from Kazakhstan (Tien Shan)
   and Ukraine (Carpathians), respectively.
C1 Skarzynski, Dariusz; Univ Wroclaw, Inst Zool, Przybyszewskiego 63-77,
   Wroclaw, Poland, Poland.
EM hypogast@biol.uni.wroc.pl

   Gurbuz, Mehmet Faruk

VL 121
IS 1
PS 53-58
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new Phaenolobus species from Turkey is described and Figured. This
   species is close to Phaenolobus areolator Constantineanu and
   Constantineanu (1968), and it is distinguished by its smaller body, head
   roundly narrowed behind, smaller number of flagellomeres, absence of
   ramulus on discocubital vein, longer subgenital plate and ovipositor
   sheath, black labrum and coloration Of the body. A key for Western
   Palaearctic Phaenolobus species is given. A check list for Turkish
   Acaenitinae is added.

TI Review of family Lucanidae (Insecta: Coleoptera) in Korea with the
   description of one new species.
AU Il Kim, Sang (skim10@choate.edu) 
   Kim, Jin Ill
SO Entomological Research (Seoul)
VL 40
IS 1
PS 55-81
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper provides a review of the family Lucanidae in Korea, which
   consists of 17 species belonging to 9 genera. One new species, Dorcus
   tenuihirsutus sp. nov., is described and the following taxonomical
   changes are proposed: Aegus laevicollis Saunders, 1854 is newly
   identified as Aegus laevicollis subnitidus Waterhouse, 1873; Macrodorcas
   striatipennis Motschulsky, 1861 is removed from the Korean fauna because
   this record is thought to have been based on the misinterpretation of
   locality and misidentification; Neolucanus saundersii Parry, 1864 is
   removed from the Korean fauna because this record is thought to have
   been based on misidentification.
C1 Il Kim, Sang; Choate Rosemary Hall,333 Christian St, Wallingford, CT,
   USA, USA.
EM skim10@choate.edu
OI Kim, Sangil/0000-0003-2758-8943
SC Zoology
SN 1738-2297
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI A new genus of the family Dictyopharidae (Homoptera) from Argentina.
AU Emeljanov, A.F.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 2
PS 410-412
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new monotypical genus with a new species, Phormotegus lenociniosus
   gen. et sp. n., is described from Argentina. The new genus is closely
   related to the genera Taosa Distant and Brachytaosa Muir, but differs
   from them in the reticulate venation of the submacropterous fore wings
   with outcurved apices and in the unique position of the hind wings
   projecting laterally from the apices of the fore wings.
C1 Emeljanov, A.F.; Zoologicheskii institut RAN, Sankt-Peterburg, Russia,
   Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Phormotegus lenociniosus [Argentina /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Dictyopharidae
OR Brachytaosa - Muir (Dictyopharidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 411]. 
   Phormotegus (Dictyopharidae): [Gen nov, Type species Phormotegus
   lenociniosus, p. 410]. 
   Phormotegus lenociniosus (Dictyopharidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 411]. 
   Taosa - Distant (Dictyopharidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 411].

DT Article
TI New synonyms, combinations and faunistic records of Western Palaearctic
   planthoppers of the family Issidae (Homoptera, Fulgoroidea).
AU Gnezdilov, V.M.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 2
PS 413-422
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the frame of a study of the Western Palaearctic Issidae 2 generic and
   4 species synonyms are established: Logvinenkoana Gnezdilov, 2002 is
   placed in synonymy under Anatotodus Dlabola, 1982; Falcidiopsis
   Kusnezov, 1930 - under Kervillea Bergevin, 1918; Hysteropterum ignavum
   Dlabola, 1981 - under Aeluropsis karabachica Logvinenko, 1975;
   Hysteropterum alciranum Gnezdilov, 2003 - under Hysteropterum alicantium
   Dlabola, 1986; Hysteropterum tangirum Matsumura, 1910 - under
   Hysteropterum guadarramense Melichar, 1906, and Mycterodus syriacus
   Gnezdilov, 2008 - under Mycterodus bicornutus Dlabola, 1986. Subgenus
   Corymbius Gnezdilov, 2002 is upgraded to genus. 12 new generic
   combinations are established: Aeluropsis karabachica Logvinenko, 1975,
   A. midica Logvinenko, 1975, Hysteropterum pictifrons Melichar, 1906 and
   H. transcaucasicum Melichar, 1914 are transferred to the genus
   Anatolodus Dlabola, 1982; Bubastia carinata Logvinenko, 1978 and B.
   parva Logvinenko, 1977 - to the genus Inflatodus Dlabola, 1982;
   Quadra-stylum tubulatum Dlabola, 1989 - to the genus Rhissolepus
   Emeljanov, 1971; Hysteropterum laminatum Horvath, 1911 - to the genus
   Libanissum Dlabola, 1980; Hysteropterum drahamense Linnavuori, 1965 - to
   the genus Bergevinium Gnezdilov, 2003; Conosimus ochaninei Puton, 1890 -
   to the genus Quadriva Ghauri, 1965; Hysteropterum guadarramense
   Melichar, 1906 - to the genus Tingissus Gnezdilov, 2003; Agalmatium
   corsicum Dlabola, 1982 - to the genus Fieberium Dlabola, 1980. New
   faunistic records are given for 18 species.
C1 Gnezdilov, V.M.; Zoologicheskii institut RAN, Sankt-Peterburg, Russia,
   Russia.

PT J

DT Article
TI Review of encyrtid wasps of the genus Anicetus Howard, 1896
   (Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Encyrtidae) of the New World, Hawaiian
   islands and Australia with description of new species from Mexico.
AU Trjapitzin, V.A.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 2
PS 438-453
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The review contains a characteristic (with diagnosis) of the genus
   Anicetus Howard, 1896, a key to females of 12 species known from the New
   World, Hawaiian Islands and Australia, and a synopsis of species with
   data on their distribution, hosts, biology, ecesis and use in biological
   control of injurious coccids. Two new species are described from Mexico:
   Anicetus myartsevae sp. n. and A. villarreali sp. n. Anicetus
   carolinensis J. Meyer, 2001 from the USA is excluded from the genus and
   transferred to Homosemion Annecke, 1967. A new combination is arranged:
   Anicetus argentinus (Fidalgo, 1979), comb. n., from Paraceraptrocerus
   Girault, 1920 which is a synonym of Anicetus. The paper is based on the
   author's work in the insect depositories of the USA (Washington, San
   Francisco, and Riverside), Mexico (Ciudad Victoria) and Russia (St.
   Petersburg). Anicetus myartsevae sp. n. is compared with the Mexican A.
   primus (Howard, 1898), from which it differs in the antennal scape
   dorsally half as long as at base (as long as in A. primus), legs more or
   less extensively dark (mainly yellow in A. primus), and face with dark
   transverse stripe (without stripe in A. primus). Anicetus villarrieli
   sp. n. is a short-winged species.
C1 Trjapitzin, V.A.; Russkoe entomologicheskoe obshchestvo, Moskva, Russia,
   Russia.
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Australasia; Oceanic islands;
   Pacific Ocean islands
DE Anicetus [Hemipteran hosts / Coccidae / Systematics] [Land zones / New
   World / Key to species] [ /  / biology; distribution] [Australia /  / ]
   [ /  / ] [Hawaii /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Anicetus myartsevae; Anicetus villarreali [Mexico /  / New species]. 
   Coccidae [Hymenopteran parasites / Anicetus / ] [Land zones / New World
   / ] [Australia /  / ] [Hawaii /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Coccoidea, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia, Chalcidoidea, Encyrtidae
OR Coccidae (Coccoidea): [Host]. 
   Anicetus - Howard 1896 (Encyrtidae): [Diagnosis, P. 439; Key to species,
   Australia, Hawaii & New World, Females, p. 440; Parasite]. 
   Anicetus argentinus - (Fidalgo 1979) (Encyrtidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Paraceraptrocerus, p. 445]. 
   Anicetus carolinensis - Meyer 2001 (Encyrtidae): [Referred to,
   Homosemion, p. 440]. 
   Anicetus myartsevae (Encyrtidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 446]. 
   Anicetus primus - (Howard 1898) (Encyrtidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   Female, p. 441]. 
   Anicetus villarreali (Encyrtidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 449]. 
   Homosemion carolinensis - (Meyer 2001) (Encyrtidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Anicetus, p. 440].

DT Article
TI A review of the genus Trilia Vachal (Hymenoptera, Halictidae,
   Rophitinae).
AU Astafurova, Yu.V.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 2
PS 454-458
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB An annotated list and original illustrated key to 5 Trilia species are
   given. Lectotype of Trilia deserticola Popov, 1957 is designated. Trilia
   sola sp. n. is described from Western Kazakhstan. The new species
   differs from all congeners in the following characters: head
   transverse-elliptical in front view; maxillary palpi short; marginal
   cell of forewing short, as long (along costal margin) as pterostigma.
   The holotype is deposited in the Zoological Institute of the Russian
   Academy of Sciences (St. Petersburg).
C1 Astafurova, Yu.V.; Zoologicheskii institut RAN, Sankt-Peterburg, Russia,
   Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Taxonomy; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia
DE Trilia [Checklists / Annotated checklist / ]. 
   Trilia sola [Kazakhstan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Apoidea,
   Halictidae
OR Trilia - Vachal 1899 (Halictidae): [Key to species, P. 455]. 
   Trilia deserticola - Popov 1957 (Halictidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   456]. 
   Trilia sola (Halictidae): [Sp nov, Kazakhstan, P. 457].

TI New data on the genus Neostylopyga Shelford, 1911 (Dictyoptera,
   Blattidae) with description of a new species from Laos.
AU Anisyutkin, L.N.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 3
PS 596-602
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of the genus Neostylopyga Shelford, 1911, N. laosana sp.
   n., is described from Laos and the male genitalia are examined in
   detail. The type species of the genus Neostylopyga, N. rhombifolia
   (Stoll, 1813), is redescribed and the taxonomic position of the genus is
   discussed.

TI Contribution to the knowledge of the leaf-beetle fauna (Coleoptera,
   Chrysomelidae) of East Kazakhstan.
AU Lopatin, I.K.
   Mikhailov, Yu.E.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 3
PS 603-611
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Chrysolina undulata asperata Lopatin is promoted to species Chrysolina
   asperata Lop., stat. n., and its re-description is given. A new species
   Chrysolina tatianae Mikhailov, sp. n. close to Ch. ordinata Gebl. is
   described from Narym-Bukhtarma Depression from adults and second instar
   larva. New data on the ecology and distribution of Chrysolina kabaki
   Lop., Ch. katonica Lop. and Ch. oirota Lop. are given.

DT Article
TI Review of species of the genus Elasmus Westwood (Hymenoptera,
   Eulophidae) from Russia and neighbouring countries.
AU Yefremova, Z.A.
   Strakhova, I.S.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 3
PS 634-661
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Five species of Elasmus are described as new to science from Russia (E.
   altaicus sp. n., E. ekaterinae sp. n. and E. maritimus sp. n.),
   Turkmenia (E. turkmenicus sp. n.), and Mongolia (E. emeljanovi sp. n.).
   The redescription of E. nikolskayae Myartseva et Dzhanokmen, 1989 is
   given. Elasmus obesoceratus Trjapitzin, 1979 is placed in synonymy to
   Elasmus rufiventris Ferriere, 1947. Sixteen species are recorded for the
   first time for the fauna of Russia, six for Tajikistan and Turkmenia,
   five for Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan, four for Ukraine and Mongolia, two
   for Moldova, Georgia, Armenia, Uzbekistan, China and S. Korea, and also
   single new records are given for Poland, Slovakia, Abkhazia, Afghanistan
   and Iran. New hosts are recorded for seven species: E. flabellatus
   Fonscolombe, E. longiclava Graham, E. nudus (Nees), E. platyedrae
   Ferriere, E. schmitti Ruschka, E. steffani Viggiani and E. westwoodi
   Giraud. A key to twenty-six species of Elasmus is constructed.
C1 Yefremova, Z.A.; Ulyanovsk State university, Ulyanovsk, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the fauna and systematics of the
   Stenopelmatoidea (Orthoptera) of Indochina and some other territories.
   IX.
AU Gorochov, A.V.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 4
PS 805-827
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Material of the Indo-Malayan and Papuan Rhaphidophorinae
   (Rhaphidophoridae) from the genera Eurhaphidaphora Gor.,
   Minirhaphidophora Gor., Stonychophora Karny, and Neorhaphidophora Gor.
   is considered. 21 new species and the previously unknown male of
   Minirhaphidophora are described. Rhaphidophora foeda Br.-W. is
   transferred to Stonychophora; Rh. sumatrana Zacher is removed from
   Stonychophora and from synonyms of S. crenulata (Br.-W.); S. tatiana
   falsa Gor. is treated as a separate species. New data on composition of
   the genera studied, on diagnostic characters of these genera and of some
   species previously described, and on the distribution of some species
   are given.
C1 Gorochov, A.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, 199034,
   Russia, Russia.

SN 0367-1445

PT J

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of the carabid genus Harpalus Latr. from
   the southwestern United States, with remarks on the composition of the
   subgenus Glanodes Casey (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Kataev, B.M.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 4
PS 828-834
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Harpalus apache sp. n. is described from the eastern part of New Mexico,
   U. S. A. (type locality: Hwy I 40, near Santa Rosa, Guadalupe Co). The
   new species is very similar in appearance to H. cordatus (LeConte, 1853)
   but readily distinguished from it by the male genitalia structure. These
   two species constitute a natural taxon which is included as the
   cordatus' group (= Opadius Casey, 1914) in the subgenus Glanodes Casey,
   1914. Distinctive characters, distribution and composition of the
   subgenus Glanodes and two its species groups ('obliquus' and cordatus')
   are provided. Two names, H. cordatus (LeConte, 1853) (= H. tadorcus
   Ball, 1972) and H. puncticeps (Casey, 1914) (= H. cunctipeps Ball,
   1973), rejected because of the secondary homonymy, are reinstated as
   valid since they are not homonymous now with Ophonus cordatus
   (Duftschmid, 1812) and Ophonus puncticeps Stephens, 1828, respectively.
C1 Kataev, B.M.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, 199034,
   Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Available name; Taxonomy; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Harpalus (Glanodes) apache [New Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Harpalus (Glanodes) - Casey 1914 (Carabidae): [Status, P. 831]. 
   Harpalus (Glanodes) apache (Carabidae): [Sp nov, New Mexico, P. 828]. 
   Harpalus (Glanodes) cordatus group (Carabidae): [New species group, P.
   833]. 
   Harpalus (Glanodes) obliquus group (Carabidae): [New species group, P.
   833]. 
   Harpalus cordatus - Le Conte 1853 (Carabidae): [Valid name, P. 830]. 
   Harpalus cunctipeps - Ball 1973 (Carabidae): [Invalid name, P. 831]. 
   Harpalus puncticeps - Casey 1914 (Carabidae): [Valid name, P. 831]. 
   Harpalus tadorcus - Ball 1972 (Carabidae): [Invalid name, P. 830].

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Triodontus Westwood (Coleoptera,
   Scarabaeidae, Orphninae) from southern Madagascar.
AU Frolov, A.V.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 4
PS 835-839
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the endemic genus Triodontus Westwood, T. hanskii sp.
   n., is described from Madagascar. Triodontus hanskii sp. n. clearly
   differs from similar species with 2 admedian tubercles on pronotum (T.
   owas Westwood, T. itremoi Paulian, T. copridoides Paulian) in the shape
   of the parameres with upper lobes lacking dentation or excisions of the
   lateral edge.
C1 Frolov, A.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, 199034,
   Russia, Russia.
RI Frolov, Andrey/N-2628-2013

PT J
AN ZOOR15303014040
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of darkling-beetles of the tribe Helopini
   (Coleoptera, Tenebrionidae) from Turkey.
AU Nabozhenko, M.V.
   Keskin, B.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 89
IS 4
PS 840-844
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species Microdocnemis xerophilicus gen. et sp. n. of the
   tenebrionid-beetle tribe Helopini is described from south-western
   Turkey. The new genus belongs to the cylindrinotoid group of genera and
   is close to the genus Odocnemis Allard, 1876 in the structure of the
   male genitalia, genital ducts of female, and denticulation of the inner
   margin of the fore tibia. Microdocnemis differs from Odocnemis in the
   following characters: very weakly flattened dorsally and ventrally body;
   pubescent apical part of the elytra, underside of the body and the
   epipleura; double border of the anal sternite; presence of short thick
   spines on the apical margin of the tibiae. The only species of the new
   genus inhabits xerophytic stony biotopes and was found under stones;
   species of the genus Odocnemis live on trunks of trees covered with
   lichens.
C1 Nabozhenko, M.V.; Russian Acad Sci, So Sci Ctr, Rostov On Don, Russia,
   Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Microdocnemis xerophilicus [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Microdocnemis (Tenebrionidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Helopini, Type species
   Microdocnemis xerophilicus, p. 841]. 
   Microdocnemis xerophilicus (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 842].

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the Asilidae (Diptera: Brachycera) from
   Fars Province (Iran).
AU Tomasovic, G. (guytomasovic@yahoo.fr) 
   Saghaei, N.
SO Entomologie Faunistique
VL 62
IS 2
PS 45-56
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A list of 27 species of Asilidae belonging to 6 subfamilies, 21 genera
   collected, in the vicinity of Shiraz in the Fars province (southwest of
   Iran) is given. Three new species, namely Paramochtherus persicus,
   Andrenosoma farsicola, Stenopogon shirazi and a new subspecies
   Aneomochtherus ochriventris persicus are described. The male genitalia
   of the described species and those of Philodicus spectabilis Loew 1871
   are illustrated. Polysarcodes moestes Paramonov 1937 is recorded in the
   Iranian fauna and four species are recorded in the Fars province,
   Aneomochtherus perplexus (Becker 1923), Philonicus albiceps (Meigen
   1820), Molobratia teutonus Linne 1767 and Ancylorrhynchus argyrogaster
   (Seguy 1932).
C1 Tomasovic, G.; Collaborateur scientifique a la l'Universite de Liege,
   Gembloux Agro-Bio Tech, Unite d'Entomologie fonctionnelle et evolutive
   (Prof. E. Haubruge), Passage des Deportes 2, B-5030 Gembloux, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM guytomasovic@yahoo.fr
SC Zoology
SN 2030-6318

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Asilidae

TI A new species of the genus Cyphon PAYKULL, 1799 from North India
   (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Cyphon PAYKULL, 1799 aus Nordindien
   (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
AU Klausnitzer, B.

VL 54

LA German

AB A new species of the genus Cyphon PAYKULL, 1799 is described from North
   India. It is placed in the Cyphon carus-subgroup and compared with
   Cyphon suspiciosus KLAUSNITZER, 1980. A catalogue of the presently known
   species of the C. corns-subgroup is presented.

   Scirtidae

PT J
AN ZOOR15201000258
DT Article
TI Caloptilia jurateae sp.n., a sibling species of Caloptilia semifascia
   (Haworth, 1828) (Lepidoptera Gracillariidae).
AU Bengtsson, Bengt A. (bengt.a.bengtsson@gmail.com) 
SO Entomologisk Tidskrift
VL 131
IS 2
PS 105-112
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Caloptilia jurateae sp.n., in the family of
   Gracillariidae is described and compared to the closely related
   Caloptilia semifascia (Haworth, 1828). The two species can be
   distinguished on the male and female genitalia. They are probably also
   different in their host choice, as the new species seems to exclusively
   mine leaves of Acer platanoides while C. semifascia only feeds on Acer
   campestre. Records of Caloptilia jurateae are known from Sweden, Norway,
   Finland, Poland and Germany.
C1 Bengtsson, Bengt A.; Lokegatan 3, Farjestaden, S-38693, Sweden, Sweden.
EM bengt.a.bengtsson@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0013-886X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Caloptilia jurateae [Sweden /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tineoidea, Gracillariidae
OR Caloptilia jurateae (Gracillariidae): [Sp nov, Sweden, P. 107]. 
   Caloptilia semifascia - (Haworth 1828) (Gracillariidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 108].

PT J
AN ZOOR15106033416
DT Article
TI Two Pollen Beetles, Meligethes subrugosus (Gyllenhal, 1808) and
   Meligethes substrigosus Erichson, 1845 in Northern Europe.
AU Rutanen, Ilpo
   Wanntorp, Hans-Erik
   Fagerstrom, Christoffer
SO Entomologisk Tidskrift
VL 131
IS 3
PS 177-184
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB There has been confusion regarding the identity of the pollen beetles
   Meligethes caudatus Guillebeau 1897 and M. subrugosus (Gyllenhal, 1808).
   The correct name for the pollen beetle generally known as Meligethes
   caudatus is here shown to be M. subrugosus and M. caudatus is a junior
   synonym. The correct name for the species generally known as M.
   subrugosus is Meligethes substrigosus Erichson, 1845. The two species
   have generally been thought to differ only by the shape of the female
   pygidium and their status as separate species has therefore been
   questioned. We demonstrate that the two taxa are distinct species with
   clear differences also in the male genitalia. Meligethes subrugosus is
   shown to be the common species in the Nordic Countries, occurring also
   in mountainous areas of Central and Southern Europe. M. substrigosus is
   widespread in the Palaearctic region, in the Nordic Countries entering
   Finland from the east and with a restricted distribution in southernmost
   Sweden.
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0013-886X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Nutrition;
   Diet; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Meligethes subrugosus; Meligethes substrigosus [Food plants /  / Plant
   list; systematics] [Europe / North / distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea,
   Nitidulidae
OR Meligethes subrugosus - (Gyllenhal 1808) (Nitidulidae): [Syn nov,
   Meligethes caudatus Guillebeau 1897, p. 180]. 
   Meligethes substrigosus - Erichson 1845 (Nitidulidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 180; Status, P. 180]. 
   Nitidula subrugosa - Gyllenhal 1808 (Nitidulidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 180]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15106033416
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14607049454
DT Article
TI A revised check-list of the genus Zygaena Fabricius, 1775 (Lepidoptera:
   Zygaenidae, Zygaeninae), based on the biospecies concept.
AU Hofmann, A. (hofmann@abl-freiburg.de) 
   Tremewan, W.G.
SO Entomologist's Gazette
VL 61
IS 2
PS 119-131
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on the biospecies concept, a check-list of the 108 currently
   recognized species representing the monophyletic genus Zygaena
   Fabricius, 1775, is provided. Three subgenera are recognized: of these,
   Mesembrynus Hubner, (1819), is monophyletic, while Agrumenia Hubner,
   (1819), and Zygaena Fabricius, 1775, are paraphyletic. Three nominal
   taxa that were originally described as subspecies (two belonging to the
   Zygaena manlia-group, one belonging to the purpuralis-group, all within
   the subgenus Mesembrynus) are newly raised to species level, while two
   (one in the manlia-group, one in Agrumenia) are newly reinstated as
   valid species. Moreover, eight new combinations are established at
   subspecies level. Biological/ecological data and comparisons with other
   taxa are provided in support of such taxonomic placements.
C1 Hofmann, A.; Pentreath, 6 Carlyon Rd,Playing Pl, Truro, Cornwall, United
   Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM hofmann@abl-freiburg.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8894
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Documentation;
   Publications

   Zygaenoidea, Zygaenidae

DT Article
TI A new species of Cyclocephala Dejean from Peru, with the redescription
   of C. spilopyga Erichson, 1847 and C. pygidiata Dupuis, 1999
   (Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Dynastinae, Cyclocephalini).
FT Una nueva especie de Cyclocephala Dejean de Peru, con la redescripcion
   de C. spilopyga Erichson, 1847 y C. pygidiata Dupuis, 1999 (Coleoptera,
   Scarabaeidae, Dynastinae, Cyclocephalini).
AU Joly, Luis J. (ljjoly@intercable.net.ve) 
SO Entomotropica
VL 25
IS 3
PS 133-148
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB The study of the Lectotype of Cyclocephala spilopyga Erichson, 1847 let
   us to define and differentiate three closely related species:
   Cyclocephala spilopyga Erichson, 1847, C. pygidiata Dupuis, 1999 and C.
   genieri sp. n. from Peru. Males of the three species can be
   differentiated mainly by the presence or absence of pilosity on head,
   pronotum and pygidium, the striation of protarsomeres 4-5, the shape of
   the largest claw of anterior legs and the shape of aedeagus. Females can
   be differentiated by the shape of lateral swelling of the elytra and
   epipleurae. Known distribution: Cyclocephala spilopyga: Ecuador, Peru,
   Brazil and Bolivia; C. pygidiata: Colombia; C. genieri sp. n.: Peru.
C1 Joly, Luis J.; Museo del Instituto de Zoologia Agricola "Francisco
   Fernandez Yepez" (MIZA), Facultad de Agronomia, Universidad Central de
   Venezuela, Apartado 4579, Maracay, 2101-A, Venezuela, Venezuela.
EM ljjoly@intercable.net.ve

AN ZOOR14605033355
DT Article
TI Two new species and a new record of the genus Sinogastromyzon
   (Teleostei: Balitoridae) from Yunnan, China.
AU Liu, Shu-Wei (chenxy@mail.kiz.ac.cn) 
   Chen, Xiao-Yong
   Yang, Jun-Xing
SO Environmental Biology of Fishes
VL 87
IS 1
PS 25-37
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species and a new record of Sinogastromyzon are described from
   Lixianjiang River of Yunnan province, China. Sinogastromyzon
   lixianjiangensis, new species, can be distinguished from its congeners
   by the following characters: pectoral fin with XIII-XIV, 15-17 rays;
   pelvic fin with X-XI, 10-12 rays; 60-65 lateral-line scales; no scales
   on the dorsum of paired fins or the region between axilla of pectoral
   fin and pelvic-fin origin; tip of pelvic fin close to anus; tip of anal
   fin close to caudal-fin base; anal-fin origin nearer to the caudal-fin
   base than to the posterior pelvic-fin base; anus nearer to anal-fin
   origin than to the posterior pelvic-fin base; dorsal side of the body
   with 9-11 black blotches. Sinogastromyzon macrostoma, new species can be
   distinguished from its congeners by the following characters: pectoral
   fin with XII-XIV, 12-15 rays; pelvic fin with VII-IX, 11-13 rays; 48-56
   lateral-line scales; mouth extremely big, slightly arched; no scales on
   the dorsum of paired fins or the region between axilla of pectoral fin
   and pelvic-fin origin; tip of pelvic fin far beyond anus; tip of anal
   fin far from caudal-fin base; anal-fin origin about midway between the
   posterior pelvic-fin base and caudal-fin base; anus nearer to posterior
   pelvic-fin base than to anal-fin origin; dorsal side of the body
   uniformly gray, without regular blotches in formalin preserved specimen.
   Sinogastromyzon cf. multiocellum is firstly recorded in China.
C1 Liu, Shu-Wei; Chinese Acad Sci, Kunming Inst Zool, 32 Jiao Chang Dong
   Rd, Kunming 650223, Yunnan, China, China.
EM chenxy@mail.kiz.ac.cn

DT Article
TI Re-examination of the snow algal species Chloromonas miwae (Fukushima)
   Muramoto et al., comb. nov (Volvocales, Chlorophyceae) from Japan, based
   on molecular phylogeny and cultured material.
AU Muramoto, Kyohei
   Nakada, Takashi
   Shitara, Tomofumi
   Hara, Yoshiaki
   Nozaki, Hisayoshi (nozaki@biol.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp) 
SO European Journal of Phycology
VL 45
IS 1
PS 27-37
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Carteria (Ca.) miwae was identified as a volvocalean snow alga
   distributed in Japan. Although Ca. miwae was recorded from various
   mountainous areas of Japan in its original description, this species has
   not been studied in over 40 years. We re-examined Ca. miwae, using
   culture techniques, electron microscopy and molecular phylogenetic
   analysis on snow samples collected from Mt. Hakkoda, Aomori Prefecture,
   and Mt. Gassan, Yamagata Prefecture, Japan. Light and transmission
   electron microscopy (TEM) of ellipsoidal or elongate-ovoid
   quadriflagellate cells from field samples revealed the presence of two
   eyespots and the absence of typical pyrenoids surrounded by starch
   grains in the chloroplasts, which are both characteristic of Ca. miwae.
   Single-cell sequencing demonstrated that quadriflagellate and naked
   biflagellate cells with a single eyespot growing in the same snow sample
   had identical gene sequences (1128 bp) in the large subunit of Rubisco
   (rbcL), suggesting that these two cell types represent different stages
   in the sexual cycle of a single species. Our molecular phylogenetic
   analysis showed that the quadriflagellate and biflagellate cells, and
   two new strains of the biflagellate volvocalean genus Chloromonas (Cr.)
   in the Japanese snow samples, form a small clade within the Chloromonas
   snow taxa. Thus, quadriflagellate cells can be considered planozygotes
   within the life cycle of a Chloromonas species growing in snow in Japan,
   and the new combination Chloromonas miwae (Fukushima) Muramoto et al. is
   proposed, based on Carteria miwae. The unique morphological
   characteristics and distinct phylogenetic position of Cr. miwae revealed
   in the present study suggest that this Japanese species has its own
   peculiar evolutionary history within the worldwide Chloromonas snow
   taxa.
C1 Nozaki, Hisayoshi; Univ Tokyo, Grad Sch Sci, 7-3-1 Hongo, Tokyo, Japan,
   Japan.
EM nozaki@biol.s.u-tokyo.ac.jp
RI NOZAKI, HISAYOSHI/G-4926-2014
OI Nozaki, Hisayoshi/0000-0002-9308-4498
SC Cell Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0967-0262
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Cytology; Genetics; Evolution; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   taxonomic implications] [Molecular genetics / RbcL sequence phylogeny /

PT J
AN ZOOR14610067764
DT Article
TI Chlorogonium complexum sp. nov. (Volvocales, Chlorophyceae), and
   morphological evolution of Chlorogonium.
AU Nakada, Takashi (naktak@ttck.keio.ac.jp) 
   Soga, Tomoyoshi
   Tomita, Masaru
   Nozaki, Hisayoshi
SO European Journal of Phycology
VL 45
IS 1
PS 97-106
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 2
U2 5
AB We isolated strains of a new species of Chlorogonium (Cg.), Cg.
   complexum Nakada sp. nov. The genus Chlorogonium was recently emended to
   have several, irregularly distributed contractile vacuoles, two-to-many
   pyrenoids associated with fragmented starch plates and tubular thylakoid
   lamellae penetrating their matrices, and stigma composed of a single
   layer of globules. Chlorogonium complexum has these diagnostic
   characters of the emended genus. It is distinguished from other species
   of Chlorogonium, Cg. euchlorum, Cg. elongatum and Cg. capillatum, on the
   combination of diagnostic characters, such as the number and stability
   of pyrenoids and the mode of encystment. Based on a dataset combining
   18S rRNA, RuBisCO large subunit (rbcL) and P700 chl a-apoprotein A2
   (psaB) gene sequences, the phylogenetic position of Chlorogonium was
   determined. Chlorogonium complexum represented an independent lineage,
   sister to Cg. euchlorum and Cg. capillatum. The evolution of diagnostic
   characters among Chlorogonium species is discussed based on the
   molecular phylogenetic analyses, and a key to species of Chlorogonium
   and fusiform chlamydomonads with irregularly distributed contractile
   vacuoles is presented.
C1 Nakada, Takashi; Keio Univ, Inst Adv Biosci, 246-2 Mizukami, Yamagata,

DT Article
TI Unikaryon phyllotretae sp. n. (Protista, Microspora), a new
   microsporidian pathogen of Phyllotreta undulata (Coleoptera;
   Chrysomelidae).
AU Yaman, Mustafa (muyaman@hotmail.com) 
   Radek, Renate
   Weiser, Jaroslav
   Toguebaye, Bhen Sikina
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 46
IS 1
PS 10-16
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 8
AB The microsporidium Unikaryon phyllotretae sp. n., a new pathogen of
   Phyllotreta undulata, is described based on light microscopic and
   ultrastructural characteristics. Microscopic examination of parasitized
   individuals revealed two types of spores. The majority of the spores
   were of the first type, which are oval and measured 2.74 [plus or minus]
   0.17 x 1.93 [plus or minus] 0.17 [mu]m when fresh. Fresh spores of the
   second type (very rare) are elongated and measured 4.39 [plus or minus]
   0.18 x 1.61 [plus or minus] 0.20 [mu]m. All life stages have single
   nuclei. Sporogony ends with uninucleate single sporoblasts and spores.
   The spores were only observed in Malpighian tubules. The isofilar polar
   filament of the parasite has six to eight coils, and a well-developed
   polaroplast was of the lamellated type, with closely packed anterior
   lamellae and loosely packed posterior lamellae. (C) 2009 Published by
   Elsevier GmbH.
C1 Yaman, Mustafa; Karadeniz Tech Univ, Dept Biol, Trabzon, Turkey, Turkey.
EM muyaman@hotmail.com

   Phyllotreta undulata [Protozoan parasites / Unikaryon phyllotretae / New
   parasite species] [Turkey /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
   Unikaryon [Coleopteran hosts / Chrysomelidae / Host parasite list]. 
   Unikaryon phyllotretae [Coleopteran hosts / Phyllotreta undulata / New
   parasite species] [Turkey /  / New species from coleopteran host].

PM 20018499
DT Article
TI Two vicariant Semispathidium species from tropical Africa and central
   Europe: S. fraterculum nov spec. and S. pukhrum nov spec. (Ciliophora,
   Haptorida).
AU Foissner, Wilhelm (wilhelm.foissner@sbg.ac.at) 
   Hess, Sebastian
   Al-Rasheid, Khaled
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 46
IS 1
PS 61-73
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Using standard methods, we describe two new Semispathidium species from
   semiterrestrial habitats of tropical Africa and central Europe.
   Semispathidium fraterculum nov. spec. and S. pulchrum nov. spec. differ
   from each other and from two Namibian (Southwest African) congeners by
   body size, the shape and location of the extrusomes; the shape of the
   macronucleus, the number of ciliary rows, the number of cilia within the
   rows, and the number of dikinetids comprising the dorsal brush rows. The
   globular resting cyst of S. fraterculum is unique in having countless
   granules on the inside of the external layer, forming sharp-angled rows.
   The distribution of these and two further, not yet described south
   African species indicates that the genus Semispathidium evolved in
   subtropical Africa. Semispathidium fraterculum and S. pulchrum are
   highly similar, both morphologically and ecologically, differing in
   mainly one important feature: the shape and location of the extrusomes
   used for prey capture. This suggests that they evolved from a common
   ancestor whose areal was divided by a vicariant event, causing an
   independent evolution of the split populations. We argue that this and
   other species pairs indicate that the vicariance speciation model is
   applicable to protists. (C) 2009 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.
C1 Foissner, Wilhelm; Salzburg Univ, FB Organism Biol, Hellbrunnerstr 34,
   Salzburg, Austria, Austria.
EM wilhelm.foissner@sbg.ac.at
RI AL-Rasheid, Khaled A S/C-2486-2008
OI AL-Rasheid, Khaled A S/0000-0002-3404-3397
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0932-4739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Africa; Eurasia; Europe
DE Semispathidium [Speciation / Vicariance speciation / ] [Zoogeography / 
   / ]. 
   Semispathidium fraterculum [Botswana /  / New species]. 
   Semispathidium pulchrum [Austria /  / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Kinetofragminophorea, Gymnostomatia, Prostomatida
OR Semispathidium (Prostomatida). 
   Semispathidium fraterculum - Foissner & Al-Rasheid 2010 (Prostomatida):
   [Sp nov, Botswana, P. 62]. 
   Semispathidium pulchrum (Prostomatida): [Sp nov, Austria, P. 67]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14606042761

TI Two new species of Trichodina Ehrenberg, 1830 (Ciliophora:
   Trichodinidae) from Silurus triostigus [triostegus] in Iraq.
AU Abdulkarim Shwani, Abdulkarim Abdulaziz
   Amin Abdullah, Shamall Mohammad
   Asmat, Ghazi
SO European Journal of Scientific Research
VL 40
IS 4
PS 598-604
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Trichodina Ehrenberg, 1830 were described from the
   skin, fins and gills of Asian catfish, Silurus triostigus Heckel, 1843
   from Greater Zab river passing Guwer district in Erbil city, Kurdistan
   region in the north of Iraq, between June 2007 and July 2008. These are
   T. erbilensis and T. kurdistani. Taxonomic and morphometric data for
   these trichodinids based on wet silver nitrate impregnated specimens
   were presented. The adhesive disc of these two species are probably more
   closely related to those of T. gobii and T. ranae respectively.

TI A new species of the genus Oiclus Simon, 1880 (Scorpiones: Scorpionidae:
   Diplocentrinae) from Guadeloupe, Lesser Antilles.
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
   Chazal, Leonard
SO Euscorpius
VL 92
PS 1-9
PD January 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/pubs.htm
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2010_92.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Oiclus Simon, 1880 is described from Guadeloupe in
   Lesser Antilles. It is closely related to Oiclus purvesii s. s. (Becker,
   1880), and represents the first record of this genus from mainland
   Guadeloupe. The previous record of O. purvesii s. s. from Terre-de-Haut
   (Les Saintes, a small islet offshore Basse-Terre) is regarded as
   dubious, as it possibly refers to the new taxon herein described. Also,
   some topics on the taxonomy and distribution of this genus are briefly
   discussed.

DT Article
TI Two new Hemiscorpius Peters, 1861 (Scorpiones: Hemiscorpiidae) from
   northern Oman.
AU Lowe, Graeme (loweg@monell.org) 
SO Euscorpius
VL 91
PS 1-24
PD January 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/pubs.htm
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2010_91.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Hemiscorpius, H. falcifer, sp. nov. and H.
   flagelliraptor, sp. nov., are described from the Al Hajar Mountains of
   northern Oman. Although both are lithophilic or ultralithophilic
   scorpions beautifully adapted for living in rock crevices, they exhibit
   divergent morphologies and may not be closely related. H. falcifer is
   distinguished by: smaller size, relatively short compact metasoma,
   bulbous telson, relatively distal placement of lamellar double hook of
   hemispermatophore, pedipalp chela with wide, sub-triangular manus and
   exceptionally elongated fingers with single file dentition along distal
   half of movable finger (in adults); H. flagelliraptor is distinguished
   by: extremely elongated, sexually dimorphic metasoma, slender telson,
   proximal placement of lamellar double hook of hemispermatophore, slender
   pedipalp chela with double denticle rows along the distal half of
   movable finger. Although orthobothriotaxic, in other respects H.
   flagelliraptor appears most similar to the neobothriotaxic species H.
   enischnochela Monod et LourenYo, 2005 and H. gaillardi (Vachon, 1974)
   from Iran.
C1 Lowe, Graeme; Monell Chemical Senses Center, 3500 Market St,
   Philadelphia, PA 19104-3308, USA, USA.
EM loweg@monell.org
SC Zoology

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Hemiscorpius falcifer; Hemiscorpius flagelliraptor [Oman /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Hemiscorpius - Peters 1861 (Scorpiones): [Key to species, Females, p.
   22]. 
   Hemiscorpius falcifer (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Oman, P. 2]. 
   Hemiscorpius flagelliraptor (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Oman, P. 10].

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041190
DT Article
TI Mayflies (Insecta, Ephemeroptera) of the Selenga River basin.
AU Tiunova, T.M. (tiunova@ibss.dvo.ru) 
   Bazova, N.V.
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 3
PS 319-330
PD Sentyabr 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Information on the mayfly fauna of transboundary Selenga River Basin
   based on literature sources and original data is presented. The faunal
   list is represented by 99 species in 28 genera and 15 families, of which
   37 species lie within the Russian part of the Selenga River Basin.
   Cinygmula sapporensis (Matsumura), Rhithrogena klugei sp.n., Ametropus
   fragilis Albarda, Baetis bacillus Kluge, Uracanthella punctisetae
   (Matsumura) and Caenis macrura Stephens are newly recorded for the river
   basin. With the exception of Cinygmula minuta Braasch, Drunella
   submontana Brodsky and Caenis jungi Braasch, all species occurring
   within the Mongolian part of river basin, are present in the fauna of
   Russia. The mayfly fauna of Selenga River Basin consists mainly of East
   Palaearctic (47%) species, but Transpalaearctic (23%) and Palaearctic
   (9%) species cover extensive areas, and there also a rather high number
   of Palearchearctic (14%) species.
C1 Tiunova, T.M.; Institute of Biology and Soil Science, Russian Academy of
   Sciences, Far East Branch, 100 let Vladivostok ave. 159, Vladivostok,
   690022, Russia, Russia.
EM tiunova@ibss.dvo.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1684-4866

   Uracanthella punctisetae [Russia / Selenga River basin / New record]. 
   Baetis (Nigrobaetis) bacillus?; Caenis macrura [Mongolia / Selenga River
   basin / New record].

PS 379-386

AB Data on the stonefly (Plecoptera) fauna ofor the Northern, Central and
   South-Western parts of the Okhotsk Region, and the State Nature Reserve
   "Dzhugdzhurskyi" are provided for the first time. The annotated list
   includes 39 species from 26 genera and 7 families, of which Leuctra
   fusca, Amphinemura borealis, Protonemura sp. and Megarcys pseudochracea
   are recorded for the first time from the north-east of the Far East of
   Russia.

TI Hydrobaenus tiunovi sp. n. (Diptera, Chironomidae, Orthocladiinae) from
   Sokhondinsky State Biosphere Reserve (Zabaikalsky Territory, Russia).
AU Makarchenko, E.A. (makarchenko@biosoil.ru) 
   Makarchenko, M.A.
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 3
PS 411-412
PD Sentyabr 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species, Hydrobaenus tiunovi Makarchenko et Makarchenko, sp.n., is
   described from Sokhondinsky State Biosphere Reserve (Zabaikal'sky
   Territory, Russia) by male imago. A new species is close related to H.
   laticaudus Stnther, 1976 but can be good separated from late by features
   of hypopygium, namely by roundish tergite IX, virga consists of 2 setae,
   transverse sternapodeme almost straight and narrow in middle part,
   gonostylus with megaseta and 2 long setae which are situated nearest and
   the same size or little longer of megaseta.

   Imamura, 1954 is reported from Russia for the first time.

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041242
DT Article
TI Phylogeny of the family Nemonychidae (Coleoptera) with description of
   new taxa.
AU Legalov, A.A. (legalov@ngs.ru) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 3
PS 457-473
PD Sentyabr 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The phylogeny of the Nemonychidae family has been reconstructed and the
   composition of this family and 12 subfamilies determined. Two
   monophyletic groups are assigned to this family. The position of the
   families Nemonychidae and Obrieniidae in Curculionoidea system is
   clarified. The distribution of fossil evidence and recent Nemonychidae
   records is discussed. Data on trophic relations are summarised. Three
   new taxa (Martynovirhynchus Legalov, gen.n., Martynovirhynchus arnoldii
   Legalov, sp.n., Medmetrioxenoidesini Legalov, trib.n. and
   Megametrioxenoidesini Legalov, trib.n.) are described. New systematic
   placements are made: the genera Ampliceps L. Arnoldi, 1977, placem.n.
   and Scelocamptus L. Arnoldi, 1977, placem.n. are transferred from tribe
   Oxycorynoidini to tribe Karataucarini, the genus Belonotaris L. Arnoldi,
   1977 from tribe Oxycorynoidini to tribe Probelini, and Distenorrhinus
   (Distenorrhinus) ponomarenkoi (L. Arnoldi, 1977), comb.n., placem.n.
   from genus Oxycorynoides of tribe Oxycorynoidini (Eobelinae) to nominate
   subgenus of genus Distenorrhinus (Distenorrhininae).
C1 Legalov, A.A.; Siberian Zoological Museum, Institute of Systematics and
   Ecology of Animals, Russian Academy of Sciences, Siberian Branch, Frunze
   str. 11, Novosibirsk 630091, Russia, Russia.
EM legalov@ngs.ru

SN 1684-4866

   Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   stratigraphical distribution] [Mesozoic /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Eobelidae, Nemonychidae
OR Nemonychidae (Curculionoidea): [Fossil]. 
   Ampliceps - Arnoldi 1977 (Eobelidae): [Referred to, Karataucarini from
   Oxycorynoidini, p. 463; Fossil].

   Oxycorynoidini, p. 463; Fossil]. 
   Distenorrhinus (Distenorrhinus) ponomarenkoi - (Arnoldi 1977)
   (Eobelidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Oxycorynoides, p. 463; Fossil].

   Distenorrhinus (Distenorrhinus), p. 463; Fossil].

   type genus for new tribe, Medmetrioxenoidesini, p. 471; Fossil].

   Metrioxenoidinae, Type genus Medmetrioxenoides Gratshev & Legalov 2009,

TI A new species of the genus Lathrobium Gravenhorst, 1802 (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae, Paederinae) from Koryakia (Kamchatka Peninsula).
AU Ryabukhin, A.S. (asr@ibpn.ru) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 3
PS 489-491
PD Sentyabr 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lathrobium (s. str.) ossorum Ryabukhin, sp.n. from Koryakia (Kamchatka
   Peninsula) is described and illustrated. It is similar to L. tshucoticum
   Tichomirova, 1976, L. mentitum Ryabukhin, 1993 and L. naeliae Ryabukhin,
   2005, but differs from those by its smaller size, darker colouration,
   and the shape, proportions and sculpture of particular body parts. The
   new species can be distinguished from all other species of Lathrobium by
   the shape of the aedeagus.
C1 Ryabukhin, A.S.; Institute of Biological Problems of the North, Russian
   Academy of Sciences, Far Eastern Branch, Portovaya str. 18, Magadan
   685000, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI New data on the fauna of the family Dolichopodidae (Diptera) from
   Russia, with a description of a new species of the genus Argyra Mcq.
AU Negrobov, O.P. (negrobov@list.ru) 
   Barkalov, A.V.
   Selivanova, O.V.
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 3
PS 522-524
PD Sentyabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During studies of materials housed in the Department of Ecology and
   Systematics of Invertebrate Animals, Voronezh State University, in the
   Siberian Zoological Museum of the Institute of Systematics and Ecology
   of Animals, Siberian Branch of RAS (Novosibirsk) and in the Zoological
   Institute (St Petersburg), 14 species of Dolichopodidae were found and
   knowledge of their distributions greatly improved. Hydrophorus
   rogenhoferi Mik and Rhaphium latimanum Kah. were found to be present in
   Russia for the first time, and Dolichopus uralensis Stack. and
   Hydrophorus norvegicus Ringd. were found for the first time in Siberia.
   In addition to well-known 75 species of the Altai fauna, three new
   species are given, one of which, Argyra bickeliana sp. n., is described
   as new for science. This species is close to A. setimana Lw. but differs
   by its completely black femora and by the absence of large yellow spots
   on the III tergum of the abdomen. The holotype of A. bickeliana is
   deposited in the Siberian Zoological Museum.
C1 Negrobov, O.P.; Department of Ecology and Systematics of Invertebrata
   Animals, Biological-Soil Sciences Faculty, Voronezh State University,
   Universitetskaja pl. 1, Voronezh 394006, Russia, Russia.
EM negrobov@list.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1684-4866

   region; Eurasia
DE Argyra bickeliana [Russia /  / New species]. 
   Dolichopodidae [Russia /  / Distribution; new record; systematics;
   annotated faunal list]. 
   Dolichopus uralensis; Hydrophorus norvegicus [Russia / Siberia / New
   record]. 
   Hydrophorus rogenhoferi; Rhaphium latimanum [Russia /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

   first time. A detailed description of the imago morphology, together

   Yamanaka, 2006, syn. n. established.

TI Morpho-karyological description of Synendotendipes kaluginae sp.n.
   (Diptera, Chironomidae, Chironominae) from Saratovskaya Oblast, Russia.
AU Durnova, N.A. (ndumova@mail.ru) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 4
PS 651-659
PD Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Synendotendipes kaluginae sp.n., from Saratovskaya Oblast
   of Russia is described and illustrated by the male imagines, pupa and
   larva. The karyo-type (2n=8) and chromosome polymorphism of S. kaluginae
   sp. n. is studied. In total, 11 banding sequences were described.
   Frequencies of individuals with heterozygous inversions are represented
   by 33.3[long dash]47.0 (42.5) %. The average number of heterozygous
   inversions per specimen is	a. 0.33-0 64 (0.51).

   Saratov 41001, Russia, Russia.

TI On the fauna of the plume moths (Lepidoptera, Pterophoridae) of KwaZulu
   Natal province (South-African Republic).
AU Ustjuzhanin, P.Ya. (petrust@mail.ru) 
   Kovtunovich, V.K.
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 4
PS 689-719
PD Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the Pterophoridae species of KwaZulu Natal province,
   South-African Republic is given. A total 0116 species have been revealed
   (in 32 genera and 3 subbmilies) has been determined, of which eight are
   described new for science, Platyptilia barbarae Ustjuzhanin et
   Kovtunovich, sp.n.; Stenoptilia johnistella Ustjuzhanin et Kovtunovich,
   sp.n.; Stenoptilia natalensis Ustjuzhanin et Kovnmovich, sp.n.;
   Stenodacma richardi Ustjuzhanin et Kovtunovich, sp.n.; Arcoptilia
   pongola Ustjuzhanin et Kovtunovich, sp.n.; Pschnophorus zulu Ustjuzhanin
   et Kovtunovich sp.n.; Gypsochares londti Ustjuzhanin et Kovtunovich,
   sp.n. and Pterophorus africanus Ustjuzhanin et Kovtunovich, sp.n. New
   synonymy has been determined for three genera: Titanoptilus Hampson,
   1905 = Macrotinactis Meyrick, 1912, syn.n.: Megalorhipida Amsel, 1935 =
   Antarches Gibeaux, 1994, syn.n.; Hellinsia Tutt, 1905 = Paulianilus
   Gibeaux, 1994. syn.n. and 17 species: Macrotinactis stenodactylus
   (Fletcher, 1911) = Titanoptilus patellatus Meyrick, 1913, syn.n.;
   Macrotinactis stenodactylus (Fletcher, 1911) = Titanoptilus laniger
   Bigot, 1969, syn.n.; Platyptila farfarella Zeller, 1867 = Platyptilia
   molopias Meyrick, 1906, syn.n.; Vietteihts vigens (Felder, Rogenhofer,
   1875) = Platyptilia maligna Meyrick, 1913, syn. n. = Vietteilus
   borbonica (Viette, 1957), syn.n.; Bipunctiphorus dimorpha (Fletcher,
   1910) = Platyptilia patriarcha Meyrick, 1912, syn.n.; Bipunctiphorus
   dimorpha (Fletcher, 1910) = Bipunctiphorus etiennei Gibeaux, 1994,
   syn.n.; Lantanophaga pusillidactyla (Walker, 1864) = Platyptilia
   amphiloga Meyrick, 1909, syn.n.; Eucapperia bullifera (Meyrick, 1918) =
   Eucappea longiductus (Gibeaux, 1992), syn.n.; Megalorhipida tessmanni
   (Strand, 1912) = Oxyptihts aquessei Bigot, 1964, syn.n.; Megalorhipida
   tessmanni (Strand, 1912) = Antarches luqueti Gibeaux, 1994, syn.n.;
   Trichoptilus negotiosus Meyrick, 1926 = Buckleria vanderwolfi Gielis,
   2008, syn.n.; Trichoptilus festus Meyrick, 1920 = Trichoptilus animosus
   Meyrick, 1921, syn.n.; Trichoptilis suhtilis Rebel, 1907 = Trichoptilis
   macerates, Meyrick, 1909, syn.n.; Marasmarcha bonaespei (Walsingham,
   1881) = Marasmarcha verax (Meyrick, 1909), syn.n.; Exelastis pumilio
   (Zeller, 1873) = Marasmarcha tenax Meyrick, 1913, syn.n.; Hellinsia
   tripunctatus (Walsingham, 1881) = Hellinsia serpens (Meyrick, 1909),
   syn.n.New combinations have been established for 14 species,
   Walsinghamiella prolai (Gibeaux, 1994). comb.n.; Walsinghamiella vibrans
   (Meyrick, 1921), comb.n.; Titanoptilus stenodactylus (Fletcher, 1911),
   comb.n.; Platyptilia longalis (Walker, 1864), comb.n.; Vietteilus vigens
   (Felder, Rogenhofer, 1875), comb.n.; Bipunctiphorus dimorpha (Fletcher,
   1910), comb.n.; Megalorhipida tessmanni (Strand, 1912), comb.n.;
   Buckleria negotiosus (Meyrick, 1926), comb.n.; Megalorhipida vivax
   (Meyrick, 1909), comb.n.; Marasmarcha empedota (Meyrick, 1908), comb.n.;
   Gypsochares corniculata (Meyrick, 1913), comb. Hellinsia madecasseus
   (Bigot, 1964), comb.n. and Crassuncus timidus (Meyrick, 1908), comb. n.
   Male genitalia for Cosmoclostis brachyhela Fletcher, 1947 are
   illustrated for the first time.

AN ZOOR14706043177
DT Article
TI Creatonotos fasciatus (Candeze, 1927) (Lepidoptera, Arctiidae), a little
   known species from an Indochina sibling to C. gangis (Linnaeus, 1763),
   with a description of a new subspecies from Laos and Hong Kong.
AU Dubatolov, V.V. (vvdubat@mail.ru) 
SO Evraziatskii Entomologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 9
IS 4
PS 727-730
PD Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new subspecies, Creatonotos fasciatus pljustshi Dubatolov, ssp.n.,
   from Laos and Hong Kong which is morphologically related to C. fasciatus
   (Candeze, 1927) from Cambodia, is described. The species is
   characterized by dentate male antennae, whitish hind-wings in males, but
   the new subspecies has better than the C. fascinatus fascinatus
   expressed darker forewing colouration similar to the type of C. gangis.
   The closely related C. gangis - C. interrrupta species complex is
   characterized by flagellate antennae and the darker colouration of the
   hind-wings and the ventral side of abdomen in males.
C1 Dubatolov, V.V.; Zoological Museum, Institute of Systematics and Ecology
   of Animals, Siberian Branch of Russian Academy of Sciences, Frunze II,
   Novosibirsk 630091, Russia, Russia.
EM vvdubat@mail.ru

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

PT J
