PM 19303009
DT Article
TI Taxonomy and species delimitation in Cryptosporidium.
AU Fayer, Ronald (Ronald.Fayer@ars.usda.gov) 
SO Experimental Parasitology
VL 124
IS 1
PS 90-97
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 29
AB Amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals serve as hosts for 19 species of
   Cryptosporidium. All 19 species have been confirmed by morphological,
   biological, and molecular data. Fish serve as hosts for three additional
   species, all of which lack supporting molecular data. In addition to the
   named species, gene sequence data from more than 40 isolates from
   various vertebrate hosts are reported in the scientific literature or
   are listed in GenBank. These isolates lack taxonomic status and are
   referred to as genotypes based on the host of origin. Undoubtedly, some
   will eventually be recognized as species. For them to receive taxonomic
   status sufficient morphological, biological, and molecular data are
   required and names must comply with the rules of the International Code
   for Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN). Because the ICZN rules may be
   interpreted differently by persons proposing names, original names might
   be improperly assigned, original literature might be overlooked, or new
   scientific methods might be applicable to determining taxonomic status,
   the names of species and higher taxa are not immutable. The rapidly
   evolving taxonomic status of Cryptosporidium sp. reflects these
   considerations. Published by Elsevier Inc.
C1 Fayer, Ronald; ARS, USDA, Beltsville, MD, USA, USA.
EM Ronald.Fayer@ars.usda.gov
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0014-4894
BD Systematics; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites
DE Cryptosporidium [Hosts / Vertebrata / Systematics]. 
   Vertebrata [Protozoan parasites / Cryptosporidium / Parasite
   systematics]. 
TN Chordates; Protozoans; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea, Coccidia
OR Vertebrata (Chordata): [Host]. 
   Cryptosporidium (Coccidia): [Parasite].

DT Article
TI Taxonomic notes on Araschnia Doris Leech, 1892 (Lepidoptera,
   Nymphalidae) from China.
AU Lang, S.Y. (langsongyun@gmail.com) 
SO Far Eastern Entomologist
VL 204
PS 1-5
PD January 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new synonyms are proposed: Araschnia doris Leech, 1892 = A. burejana
   leechi Oberthuer, 1909, syn. n., = A. zhangi Chou, 1994, syn. n. The
   taxon leechi is well known as a subspecies of A. burejana (Bremer,
   1861), but it is actually the first generation of A. doris. The male and
   female genitalia of all confirmed species of the genus Araschnia Hubner,
   1819 are illustrated.
C1 Lang, S.Y.; 1-7-10 Wang Fu Hua Yuan 2#, Shuangliu, 610200, Chengdu,
   China, China.
EM langsongyun@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology

   Reproduction; Reproductive system

   [Illustrations /  / ] [Genitalia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

DT Article
TI Thyasira ockelmanni (Mollusca: Bivalvia: Veneroidea), A new species of
   Thyasiridae from the Norwegian Sea.
AU Keuning, Rozemarijn
   Schander, Christoffer (Christoffer.Schander@bio.uib.no) 
SO Fauna Norvegica
VL 30
PS 21-24
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Thyasiridae, Thyasira ockelmanni n.sp. is described
   from the abyssal depths of the Norwegian Sea. The generic assignment is
   tentative and possible alternatives are discussed. The new species has
   some resemblance to Thyasira subovata (Jeffreys, 1881) and Adontorhina
   similis Barry & McCormack, 2007, but the posterior outline is rounded
   and not angulate or truncate as in these species.
C1 Schander, Christoffer; Department of Biology, University of Bergen, 5020
   Bergen, Norway, Norway.
EM Christoffer.Schander@bio.uib.no

   Ocean
DE Thyasira ockelmanni [Arctic Ocean / Norway / New species] [North
   Atlantic /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Veneroida, Lucinoidea
OR Adontorhina similis - Barry & McCormack 2007 (Lucinoidea): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 22]. 
   Thyasira ockelmanni (Lucinoidea): [Sp nov, Norway (marine), P. 22]. 
   Thyasira subovata - (Jeffreys 1881) (Lucinoidea): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 22].

TI Izatha (Insecta: Lepidoptera: Gelechioidea: Oecophoridae).
AU Hoare, Robert J.B.
SO Fauna of New Zealand
VL 65
PS 8-201
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The endemic New Zealand genus Izatha Walker (Oecophoridae) is revised
   Forty species are recognised, including the following 15 species
   described as new Izatha blepharitdota n sp, I dasydisca n sp, I dulcior
   n sp, I gekkonella n sp, I gibbsi n sp, I haumu n sp, I katadiktya n sp,
   I lignyarcha n sp, I minimira n sp, I notodoxa n sp, I quinquejacula n
   sp, I spheniscella n sp, I taingo n sp, I voluptuosa n sp and I walkerae
   n sp Three new synonymies are established Ztrosarts amorbas Meyrick and
   Trachypepla amorbas Meyrick are sunk as junior subjective synonyms of I
   copiosella (Walker) and I plumbosa Philpott as a junior subjective
   synonym of I mira Philpott Izatha huttonii Butler is removed from
   synonymy with I peroneanella (Walker), and I acmonias Philpott from
   synonymy with I picarella (Walker) Izatha griseata Hudson is removed
   from Oecophoridae and transferred to Gelechudae as a junior subjective
   synonym of Anarsia dryinopa Lower The adults of all species are
   described and Illustrated in colour, along with the genitalia of both
   sexes, where known Larvae are briefly described for all species for
   which positive associations have been made Seven informal species-groups
   are recognised, based on characters of the head, wing pattern, and male
   and female genitalia The larvae of most species that have been reared
   feed in dead rotten wood, but the larvae of I gekkonella n sp and
   probably I convulsella (Walker) and I phaeoptila (Meyrick) feed on
   lichens (and/or epiphytic mosses), and I prasophyta Meynck was once
   reared from a fruiting body of the bracket fungus Bjerkandera adusta The
   systematic position of Izatha is discussed it is assigned to the
   Hierodoris group of Hoare, and is considered most closely related to
   dead-wood feeding members of the genus Gymnobathra Meynck, which is also
   endemic to New Zealand The diversity and distribution patterns of Izatha
   are discussed It is the second largest genus of true (i e non-pyraloid)
   Microlepidoptera in New Zealand after Tingena (Oecophoridae), though
   Stigmella (Nepticulidae) when revised will probably rival Izatha in
   diversity Among New Zealand Lepidoptera genera containing over 30
   species, Izatha is unique in having more species endemic to the North
   Island than to the South Island 22 species are confined to the North
   Island (Including offshore islands), 10 to the South Island, and 6 are
   shared between both islands, 2 further species are endemic to the
   subantarctic Snares Islands This pattern of diversity is similar to that
   observed in other Insect groups associated with dead wood and fungi in
   forest habitats, e g, Aradidae (Hemiptera Heteroptera), and may reflect
   the persistence of greater areas of forest refugia in the North Island
   (especially Northland) during the last glaciation Izatha displays
   remarkable diversity in the structure of the genitalia, and this is
   discussed with respect to sexual selection and sexually antagonistic
   coevolution Males of many species have strongly spit-lose phalli, and
   there is evidence of corresponding damage to the female genital tract
   Females of some species have the ductus bursae strongly reinforced with
   sclerotised scobinations A group of 11 predominantly North Island
   species have deciduous cornuti in the male vesica, which are left behind
   in the female tract after mating, all cornuti are apparently committed
   to the first mating From spermatophore counts, the females are known to
   mate up to 4 times Adult Izatha are cryptically patterned bark and/or
   lichen mimics Most species have raised scale-tufts on labial palpi,
   legs, and forewings that enhance the crypsis, the forewing tufts consist
   of strongly curled scales The shining leaden or golden iridescent
   undersides of the curled scales may further break up the pattern, the
   iridescence is due to the very fine corrugations of the lower scale
   lamina, which act as a diffraction grating Most species of Izatha are
   widespread, although some are known from very few localities Species
   likely to be endemic to restricted areas are I quinquejacula n sp (Three
   Kings Islands), I haumu n sp and I taingo n sp (Aupouri peninsula), I
   dulcior n sp (Poor Knights Islands), and I oleariae Dugdale and I
   spheniscella n sp (Snares Islands) Three species are considered of
   immediate conservation concern I rigescens Meyrick, not collected since
   its discovery on the Wellington coast in 1929, I psychra (Meyrick),
   currently only known from a single Mackenzie Country shrubland, which is
   vulnerable to fire and pine invasion, and I caustopa (Meyrick), which
   has been seen only 3 times in the last 70 years, and may have been
   affected by the decline of its only known host tree, Fuchsia
   excorticata, due to attack by introduced possums.
C1 Hoare, Robert J.B.; Landcare Res, Private Bag 92170, Auckland, New
   Zealand, New Zealand.
SC Zoology
SN 0111-5383

   Zoogeography; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia

TI Pisauridae (Arachnida: Araneae).
AU Vink, Cor J.
   Duperre, Nadine
SO Fauna of New Zealand
VL 64
PS 1-60
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four species of Pisauridae, all in the genus Dolomedes Latreille, 1804,
   are found in New Zealand; D. minor L. Koch, 1876 nomen protectum (=D.
   lateralis White, 1849, new synonymy, nomen oblitum, D. sagittiger White,
   1849, new synonymy, D. imperiostis L. Koch, 1876, and D. tridentatus
   Hogg, 1911, new synonymy), D. aquaticus Goyen, 1888, D. schcminslandi
   Simon, 1899 (=D. hutioni Hogg, 1908, D. trippi Hogg, 1908, new
   synonymies) and D. dondalei sp. nov. The genus and all species are
   described, with information on synonymy, type data, material examined,
   and geographical distribution. Habitus images of adults, illustrations
   of important structural features, and distribution maps are provided. A
   key to adults is given. A molecular phylogcnetic analysis examining the
   relationships of New Zealand species in the genus Doloniedes is
   presented. Mitochondria) DNA (cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 C01) and
   nuclear DNA (actin 5C) was sequenced from all four New Zealand Dolomedes
   species. COI divergence between species was low and introgression
   appears to have occurred between D. minor and D. aquaticus.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation

DT Article
TI Auchenorrhyncha (Insecta: Hemiptera): catalogue.
AU Lariviere, M.-C.
   Fletcher, M. J.
   Larochelle, A.
SO Fauna of New Zealand
VL 63
PS 5-231
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Auchenorrhyncha are a highly diverse group of hemimetabolous insects and
   a major component of the phytophagous insect fauna in most terrestrial
   ecosystems worldwide. They are treated here as a suborder of the
   Hemiptera and include the planthoppers (infraorder Fulgoromorpha),
   cicadas, froghoppers, spittlebugs, treehoppers, and leafhoppers
   (infraorder Cicadomorpha). With their piercing sucking mouthparts the
   majority of Auchenorrhyncha species feed on phloem or xylem (plant sap)
   or plant cell contents (parenchyma or cell ruptures) although some
   species feed on mosses or fungi. This economically important group
   includes several plant pests pests and several vectors of plant
   pathogens, including phytoplasmas, viruses, and bacteria.
SC Zoology
SN 0111-5383

   Australasian region; Australasia

DT Article
TI Trechini (Insecta: Coleoptera: Carabidae: Trechinae).
AU Townsend, James Ian
SO Fauna of New Zealand
VL 62
PS 5-8
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English; Maori
U1 0
U2 0
AB New Zealand Carabidae of the tribe Trechini are revised and
   relationships to the world fauna are discussed. Five lineages are
   recognised in the Trechini, 3 of which occur in New Zealand. The New
   Zealand fauna includes representatives of lineages that were previously
   regarded as the subtribes Aepina, Homaloderina, and Trechina. Newly
   described are 3 new genera (Oarotrechus, Waiputrechus, and
   Kettlotrechus), 1 new subgenus (Mayotrechus) in the genus Duvaliomimus,
   18 new species, and 2 new subspecies. A total of 34 species plus 3
   subspecies are recognised as follows: Aepine lineage Kenodactylus
   audouini (Guerin-Meneville), Kiwitrechus karenscottae Larochelle &
   Lariviere, Maoritrechus rangitotoensis Brookes, M. nunni n. sp., M
   stewartensis n. sp., Neanops caecus (Britton), N. pritchardi Valentine,
   Oarotrechus gracilentus n. gen., n. sp., Waiputrechus cavernicola n.
   gen., n. sp.; Homaloderine lineage Erebotrechus infernus Britton,
   Kupetrechus lamberti (Britton), K. gracilis n. sp., K. larsonae n. sp.;
   Trechine lineage Duvaliomimus (D.) walker walkeri (Broun), D. (D.)
   walker brittoni Jeannel (new status), D. (D.) australis n. sp., D. (D.)
   chrystallae n. sp., D. (D.) crypticus n. sp., D. (D.) Maori (Jeannel)
   (re-instated), D. (D.) megawattus n. sp., D. (D.) obscurus n. sp., D.
   (D.) orientalis Giachino, D. (D.) pseudostyx n. sp., D. (D.) styx
   Britton, D. (D.) taieriensis n. sp., D. (D.) watti Britton, Duvaliomimus
   (Mayotrechus) mayae mayae Britton, D. (M.) mayae mayorum n. subsp.,
   Kettlotrechus orpheus (Britton), K. edridgeae n. sp., K. marchanti n.
   sp., K. millari n.sp., K. pluto (Britton), Scototrechus orcinus Britton.
   S. hardingi hardingi n. sp., S. hardingi worthyi n. subsp., and S. morti
   n. sp. Their survival during changing geological episodes is discussed.
SC Zoology
SN 0111-5383

TI Insecta : Coleoptera : Coccinellidae.
AU Chakraborty, S.K.
ED The Director, Zoological Survey of India
SO Fauna of Uttarakhand (part-2): insects. [State Fauna Series, 18.]
PS 283-301
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper deals with 914 examples of Coccinellidae beetles
   belonging to 39 species under 23 genera and 5 subfamilies. Out of 39
   species 8 species were recorded earlier from Kumaon Hills and other
   places under U.P., Two species are recorded first time from India as
   well as the state. A new species, H. chamolika has been described. Genus
   Egius Mulsant has been recorded for the first time from India as well as
   the state. A new combination has been reported (Epilachna expansa
   (Dieke) = Afissa expansa Dieke) Keys to the subfamilies, tribes, genera
   and species have been provided. Relevant synonymies, collection data and
   geographical distribution have also been provided.

TI Nematoda : plant and soil nematodes.
AU Rizvi, Anjum Nasreen
ED The Director, Zoological Survey of India
SO Fauna of Uttarakhand (part-3). [State Fauna Series, 18.]
PS 81-166
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The present paper reports 196 species, which have been reported from
   Uttarakhand till date. These 196 species have been found to occur in 93
   genera and 37 families of 11 orders namely, Tylenchida (72 species),
   Aphelenchida (02 species), Rhabditida (11 species), Araeolaimida, (04
   species), Monhysterida (01 species), Chromadorida (02 species), Enoplida
   (05 species), Dorylaimida (51 species), Alaimida (05 species),
   Mononchida (38 species) and Triplonchida (05 species). Out of these 196,
   two species are new records from India (Rizvi & Bhandari, 2008), 17
   species are new distributional records for the state, of which 8 species
   were recorded from Western Doon Shivalik region (Rizvi, 2007), 2 species
   from Corbett Tiger reserve (CTR), district Nainital (Rizvi, 2008), 4
   species from Dehradun and 1 species from district Chamoli (Rizvi &
   Bhutia, 2009), other two new records from the state are reported herein.
   Besides, two new combinations are also proposed and several new hosts /
   habitats are recorded for these nematodes.

AN ZOOR14611078767
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI The first diplobelid coleoid from the Cenomanian of south-eastern India.
AU Fuchs, Dirk (drig@zedat.fu-berlin.de) 
   Vartak, Ajit
   Kendrick, George
   Ghare, Mukund
SO Ferrantia
VL 59
PS 51-59
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A single breviconic phragmocone from an outcrop near Odiyam (Ariyalur
   district, Tamil Nadu, south-eastern India) has proofed to represent a
   previously unknown species of Conoteuthis, a well-known diplobelid genus
   from the Lower Cretaceous of Europe. Conoteuthis azizi n. sp. has been
   found in deposits that belong to the Cenomanian Karai Formation. A
   morphological comparison has shown that Conoteuthis azizi n. sp.
   slightly differs from the type species Conoteuthis dupiniana from the
   Aptian of Europe through a slightly larger apical angle and septa that
   are lesser inclined. Conoteuthis azizi n. sp. is the first unambiguous
   evidence of the Diplobelida in Upper Cretaceous rocks and the second
   diplobelid species from the southern hemisphere.
C1 Fuchs, Dirk; Freie Universitaet Berlin, Institute of Geological
   Sciences, Branch Palaeontology, Malteserstr. 74-100, D-12249 Berlin,
   Germany, Germany.
EM drig@zedat.fu-berlin.de
SC Zoology
SN 1682-5519

   Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   / Cenomanian / ]. 
   Conoteuthis azizi [Tamil Nadu /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Diplobelida [Land zones / Southern Hemisphere / new record] [India /  /
   ] [Cretaceous / Cenomanian / ] [ /  / ].

AN ZOOR14611078769
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A rare and unusual teudopseid coleoid from the Upper Cretaceous of Haqel
   (Lebanon).
AU Fuchs, Dirk (drig@zedat.fu-berlin.de) 
SO Ferrantia
VL 59
PS 61-72
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new vampyropod coleoid from the late Cenomanian limestones of Haqel.
   (north-west Lebanon) is described. Teudopsinia n. gen. haasi n. sp.
   preserves a complete gladius. Owing to a sharply pointed anterior
   gladius extremity, Teudopsinia n. gen. haasi n. sp. is classified as a
   representative of the Teudopseina. A morphological comparison with other
   teudopseid groups shows that lower level attributions are, however,
   problematic since the general gladius outline is unique. The most
   unusual character is the relative length of the hyperbolar zones.
   Whereas teudopseid families are normally typified by hyperbolar zones
   not longer than the half gladius length, those of Teudopsinia n. gen.
   haasi n. sp. occupy c. 55% of the total gladius length. This observation
   indicates that the comparatively narrow anterior median field of
   Teudopsinia n. gen. haasi n. sp. is not only reduced in width but also
   in length. A gladius with a strongly reduced median field is presumed
   for the (hypothetical) last common ancestor of the Octopoda and
   Cirroctopoda. A side branch of the Teudopsidae leading from early
   Jurassic genus Teudopsis to late Cretaceous Teudopsinia n. gen. haasi n.
   sp. is therefore considered to be a possible root-stock of the
   Octobrachia.
C1 Fuchs, Dirk; Freie Universitaet Berlin, Institute of Geological
   Sciences, Branch Palaeontology, Malteserstr. 74-100, D-12249 Berlin,
   Germany, Germany.
EM drig@zedat.fu-berlin.de
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1682-5519
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Teudopseina [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Teudopsinia [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Teudopsinia haasi [Lebanon /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Coleoidea, Teuthida, Vampyromorpha
OR Beloteuthis libanotica - Naef 1922 (Teuthida): [Systematics, Taxonomic
   history, p. 66]. 
   Teudopseina (Vampyromorpha): [Fossil]. 
   Teudopsinia (Vampyromorpha): [Gen nov, Of family Teuopsidae, Type
   species Teudopsinia haasi, p. 62, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Teudopsinia haasi (Vampyromorpha): [Sp nov, Lebanon, Cretaceous, P. 64;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14611078783
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Fossil coleoids from the Late Cretaceous (Campanian & Maastrichtian) of
   the Western Interior.
AU Larson, Neal L. (ammoniteguy@bhigr.com) 
SO Ferrantia
VL 59
PS 78-113
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Coleoid cephalopods have been reported from the Campanian and
   Maastrichtian of the Western Interior for more than 150 years, yet they
   remain poorly described, scantily represented, and rarely published.
   Meek & Hayden (1856) described Belemnitella bulbosa from the Fox Hills
   group of the Upper Missouri Cretaceous series (upper Maastrichtian).
   Jeletzky (1966) figured a single specimen; Kennedy et al. (1998),
   Stoffer et al. (2001) & Stoffer (2003) examined several specimens and
   compared B. bulbosa to B americana. This paper revisits Belemnitella
   bulbosa and describes many previously undescribed features of the
   phragmocone. Actinosepia canadensis was reported from the upper
   Campanian Baculites compressus through B. reesidei Zones to the upper
   Maastrichtian Jeletzkytes nebrascensis Zone sediments throughout the
   northern portions of the Western Interior (Whiteaves 1897; Landes 1940;
   Waage 1965). A. canadensis is found to be restricted to the upper
   Campanian (and possibly the lower Maastrichtian) of the Western Interior
   while A. landmani n. sp. and A. mapesi n. sp. are described from the
   upper Maastrichtian. Tusoteuthis longa Logan, 1898 was described from
   the Santonian or lower Campanian Smoky Hill Chalk, Niobrara Formation of
   western Kansas. Miller & Walker (1968) described Enchoteuthis melanae
   from the lower Campanian, Smoky Hill Member of the Niobrara Formation.
   T. longa was also reported from the lower middle Campanian Pierre Shale
   (Nicholls & Isaak 1987). The types along with new specimens of T. longa
   and E. melanae are re-examined; Tusoteuthis cobbani n. sp. is described
   from the upper Campanian Pierre Shale; and new family, Enchoteuthidae,
   is erected for these unique coleoids. Meek & Hayden (1860) described
   Phylloteuthis subovatus from the Fox Hills group. P. subovatus is
   examined and confirms what Green (1977) suspected, Phylloteuthis is
   nothing more than a leaf.
C1 Larson, Neal L.; Black Hills Institute of Geological Research & Black
   Hills Museum of Natural History, PO Box 643, 117 Main Street, Hill City,
   South Dakota 57745, USA, USA.
EM ammoniteguy@bhigr.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1682-5519
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Diagnosis; Description;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Fossilization; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14611078783

PT J
AN ZOOR14611078785
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A new late Carboniferous coleoid preserved with an ink sac from
   Nebraska, USA.
AU Mapes, Royal H. (mapes@ohio.edu) 
   Doguzhaeva, Larisa A.
   Mutvei, Harry
   Pabian, Roger
SO Ferrantia
VL 59
PS 126-136
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The presence of an ink-filled sac within the crushed shell of an
   orthoconic cephalopod from the Stark Shale (Upper Carboniferous -
   Kasimovian), southeastern Nebraska, USA, leads to the conclusion that
   the specimen should be assigned to the Subclass Coleoidea. Because of
   incomplete preservation, interpretation of some of the shell morphology
   of this coleoid remains unresolved. The fossil shows the imprint and
   impression of a crushed, bluntly pointed shell with a short final
   chamber that contains a relatively large undistorted ink sac bearing the
   mural parts of four septa on its top. Septal fragments and/or shell
   debris are missing in the shale surrounding the fossil. The posterior of
   the shell appears to be missing. Three taphonomic scenarios are
   considered to explain the preservation of the specimen. The coleoid
   specimen is described as Flowerites bellevuensis n. gen. et sp. and
   referred to the family Floweritidae n. fam. with an as yet uncertain
   ordinal affiliation.
C1 Mapes, Royal H.; Department of Geological Sciences, Ohio University,
   Athens, OH 45701, USA, USA.
EM mapes@ohio.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1682-5519
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Flowerites [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Flowerites bellevuensis [Nebraska /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Floweritidae [Cretaceous /  / New family]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Coleoidea
OR Coleoidea (Cephalopoda): [Classification, Palaeozoic taxa, p. 132]. 
   Flowerites (Coleoidea): [Gen nov, Of new family Floweritidae, Type
   species Flowerites bellevuensis, p. 133, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Flowerites bellevuensis (Coleoidea): [Sp nov, Nebraska, Cretaceous, P.
   133; Fossil]. 
   Floweritidae (Coleoidea): [Fam nov, Of superorder Belemnoida, order
   incertae sedis, Type genus Flowerites, p. 133, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14611078785

PT J
AN ZOOR14611078790
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Naefia sp. from the Cenomanian of south-eastern India.
AU Vartak, Ajit (vartakajit@yahoo.com) 
   Fuchs, Dirk
   Ghare, Mukund
SO Ferrantia
VL 59
PS 176-183
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Since Blanford (1865) figured a Naefia-like phragmocone from the
   Cenomanian of south-eastern India, the definite existence of Naefia from
   the Cenomanian of India has not been confirmed. Longiconic phragmocones
   with comparatively high chambers collected from an outcrop near Odiyam
   (Ariyalur district, Tamil Nadu, south-eastern India) have now proofed to
   represent Naefia sp. The collection site belongs to the Cenomanian
   Kunnam Member of the Karai Formation. The phragmocones are poorly
   preserved why systematically relevant characters are scarce. A specific
   determination is therefore problematic. However, one specimen exhibits a
   maximum phragmocone diameter of 13 mm, the largest diameter recorded in
   the genus Naefia. Paleobiogeographically, the specimens represent the
   first evidence of Cenomanian Naefia outside the paleopacific and the
   northern hemisphere.
C1 Vartak, Ajit; Department of Geology and Petroleum Technology, Nowrosjee
   Wadia College, Pune 411001, India, India.
EM vartakajit@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1682-5519
BD Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Naefia [India /  / new record] [Tamil Nadu / Ariyalur district, Odiyam /
   systematics] [Cretaceous / Cenomanian / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Coleoidea
OR Naefia - Wetzel 1930 (Coleoidea): [Fossil; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14611078790
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14610072189
DT Article
TI [Marine Fauna of the Wiltz strata (Upper Emsian, Lower Devonian) of the
   Wiltz syncline and the Daleider syncline group (Luxembourg, Germany):
   part 1.]
FT Marine Fauna der Wiltz-Schichten (Ober-Emsium, Unter-Devon) der Mulde
   von Wiltz und der Daleider Mulden-Gruppe (Luxemburg, Deutschland): Teil
   1.
AU Franke, Christian
SO Ferrantia
VL 58
PS 5-62
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A multitude of new finds permit a fundamental revision of the fossil
   contents of he Wiltz layers. For this purpose, approx. 5,700 proofs of
   finds were evaluated. Due to the numerous finds, the study will be
   published in several parts. It turns out that the species-diversity is
   very much greater than assumed to date. The presence of many of genera
   and species known from other sedimentation areas have now been proved
   for the Wiltz-layers in the Wiltz-basin and Daleiden Synclinal Group
   This publication includes plant fossils, Rhaphidopora sp. cf.
   Rhaphidopora lonsdalei, Cornulites sp. and Pterygotoidea fam. et gen. et
   sp. indet. The trilobite Leonaspis grafi n. sp. is redescribed. Finally,
   the area examined can be defined as an extensive long-lived deposit
   region of a shallow water situation extending from close to and far from
   the coast of he Ardenno-Rhenish continental shelf with multifold
   faunistic correspondences to other regions in the Variscan sea during
   the upper Emsian.
C1 Franke, Christian; Musee national d'histoire naturelle de Luxembourg,
   Section Paleontologie, 25, rue Muenster, L-2160 Luxembourg-Grund,
   Luxembourg.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1682-5519

PT J
AN ZOOR14610072191
DT Article
TI [Early presence of the genus Kerforneidictyum represented by K.
   oeslingensis n. sp. (Cnidaria, Tabulata) in the Lower Emsian of the
   Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.]
FT Presence precoce du genre Kerforneidictyum represente par K.
   oeslingensis n. sp. (Cnidaria, Tabulata) dans l'Emsien inferieur du
   Grand-Duche de Luxembourg.
AU Plusquellec, Yves
   Franke, Christian
SO Ferrantia
VL 58
PS 72-80
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Kerforneidictyum, K. oeslingensis n. sp., is described.
   It is mainly characterized by the following features : apical angle
   reaching up to 160[degree], deep calices with numerous small spines
   roughly of the same size, setted in two rows or scattered on septal
   ridges which are wider than the interseptal furrows, no obvious cardinal
   ridge, tabulae scarce or missing. The species has been collected in the
   lowermost Emsian of the Givonne-Eislek Anticlinorium in Luxembourg. It
   is 1) the first record of the genus in the Devonian of Luxembourg and 2)
   in the autochtonous part (S.E. Laurussia) of the Ardenno- Rhenish
   Mountains and 3) very likely the first - or one of the two first -
   representative of the genus taking into account Gondwana and Laurussia.
C1 Plusquellec, Yves; Laboratoire de Paleontologie, (UMR 6538 Domaines
   Oceaniques), Universite de Bretagne Occidentale, UFR Sciences &
   Techniques, 6 avenue Le Gorgeu, F-29238 BREST Cedex 3, France, France.
SC Zoology
SN 1682-5519
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Kerforneidictyum [Zoogeography /  / New record] [Luxembourg /  / ]
   [Devonian /  / ]. 
   Kerforneidictyum oeslingensis [Luxembourg /  / new species] [Devonian / 
   / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Tabulata
OR Kerforneidictyum (Tabulata): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Kerforneidictyum oeslingensis (Tabulata): [Sp nov, Luxembourg, Devonian,
   P. 75; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Miocene brachiopods from the Lipovica quarry above Brise, Slovenia.
FT Miocenski ramenonozci iz Kamnoloma Lipovica nad Brisami.
AU Mikuz, Vasja (mikuz@uni-lj.si) 
SO Folia Biologica et Geologica
VL 51
IS 1
PS 27-34
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Slovenian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the contribution are considered Middle Miocene - Badenian brachiopods
   from the Lipovica quarry above Brise. Remains of brachiopods there are
   very rare, they are most often damaged and therefore not easily
   determinable. The presented specimens belong indubitably to family
   Terebratulidae and genus Terebratula (sensu lato) sp.

DT Article
TI A revision of the Anthaxia (Haplanthaxia) melancholica and A. (H.)
   thunbergi species-groups (Coleoptera: Buprestidae: Buprestinae:
   Anthaxiini).
AU Bily, Svatopluk (svatopluk_bily@nm.cz) 
   Kuban, Vitezslav
SO Folia Heyrovskyana
VL 18
IS 1-3
PS 25-58
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A taxonomic revision of the Anthaxia (Haplanthuria) melancholica and A.
   (H.) thunbergi species-groups) with the description of six new species:
   Anthaxia (Haplanthaxia) africandra sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of the
   Congo, Republic of South Africa), A. (H.) brunneipilis sp. nov.
   (Zambia), A. (H.) egeniformis sp. nov. (Benin), A. (H.) ruth sp. nov.
   (Namibia, Republic of South Africa, Tanzania), A. (H.) sphenoptera sp.
   nov. (Mozambique) and A. (H.) tanzanica sp. nov. (Tanzania). Lectotype
   designations are given for A. (H.) alhovillosa Kerremans, 1913, A. (H.)
   dollmani Obenberger, 1931, A. (H.) katangae Obenberger, 1924, A. (H.)
   lukesi Obenberger, 1931, A. (H.) melancholica Gory, 1841, A. (H.)
   nerissa Obenberger, 1931, A. (H.) sjoestedti Kerremans, 1908 and A. (H.)
   thunbergi Gory & Laporte, 1839. New synomyms are proposed: Anthaxia (H.)
   egena Kerremans, 1913 = A. (H.) decimata Thery, 1947, syn. nov., = A.
   (H.) nerissa Obenberger, 1931, syn. nov., = A. (H.) rhodesiae
   Obenberger, 1924, syn. nov.; A. (H.) thunbergi Gory & Laporte, 1839 = A.
   (H.) davidi Obenberger, 1931, syn. nov., =A. (H.) expectanda Obenberger,
   1922, syn. nov., = A. (H.) implexa Fahraeus, 1851, syn. nov., = A. (H.)
   pflanzeri Obenberger, 1931, syn. nov., = A. (H.) recisa Thery, 1947,
   syn. nov., = A. (H.) uzeli Obenberger, 1931, syn. nov. Keys to the
   species of both species-groups are provided and all species are
   illustrated.

TI Phymatodes (Phymatoderus) vandae sp. nov. from Greece (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae).
AU Danilevsky, Mikhail L. (danilevskym1@rambler.ru) 
SO Folia Heyrovskyana
VL 18
IS 1-3
PS 67-70
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Phymatodes (Phymatoderus) vandae sp. nov., close to P. (P.) lividus
   (Rossi, 1794), is described from Kefalonia Island (Greece) from two
   female specimens. The new species is characterized by the very wide
   black prothorax which is laterally angulate. The description is
   accompanied with a color photo of the holotype and differential
   diagnosis.

DT Book
TI Fossil acanthopterygian fishes (Teleostei, Acanthopterygii).
FT [Iskolaemye kolyucheperye ryby (Teleostei, Acanthopterygii).]
AU Bannikov, A.F.
BA Bannikov, A.F.
SO Fossil acanthopterygian fishes (Teleostei, Acanthopterygii). [Fossil
   vertebrates of Russia and adjacent countries.]
PS 1-244
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The volume "Spiny-rayed fishes (Acanthopterygii)" contains descriptions
   of taxa found in marine and brackish-water deposits of Russia, Ukraine,
   Moldavia, Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan, Abkhazia,
   Georgia and Armenia. Diagnoses of 194 species, 139 genera, 79 families
   and 11 orders of acanthopterygians are presented; data on doubtful
   species and taxa described with open nomenclature (those not
   identifiable precisely to the species level) also are included.
   Acanthopterygii are regarded here in the sense of Greenwood et al.
   (1966) plus Atherinomorpha because subsequent attempts to define
   spiny-rayed fishes were not entirely successful. Acanthopterygii
   (Percomorpha) is the largest and most diverse group of bony fishes,
   which includes about 15000 Recent species representing about 275
   families. It contains about one-third of all extant vertebrates.
   Acanthopterygians are characterized by the presence of spines in the
   dorsal, anal and pelvic fins (at least in the most primitive or
   phylogenetically basal members of respective orders), pelvic fins
   primarily thoracic in position, basicranium/shoulder girdle connection
   ligamentous, relatively high position of the pectoral fins, no more than
   four pectoral radials, lack of a mesocoracoid, predominance of ctenoid
   scales, etc. The latest ideas concerning the systematics of fossil
   acanthopterygians are reflected in the descriptive chapter. A number of
   generic (Eurasialates, Eosasia, Synagropoides, Karelinia,
   Apscheronichthys) and species names are regarded here as synonyms; the
   genus Xenoscombrinus is regarded as doubtful; the Recent perciform fish
   families Serranidae, Terapontidae and Centrolophidae are rejected from
   the fish faunas of the Tethys and Paratethys of Russia and adjacent
   countries; the Paleocene percoid family Asianthidae is abolished as
   inadequately substantiated. A new percoid genus Oliganodon gen. nov. is
   erected to accommodate two Oligocene Paratethian species formerly
   classified with Serranus. Two taxa [long dash] Sarmata prozritelevi
   Bogatshov, 1933 and Uylyaichthys eugeniae Prokofiev, 2002 [long dash]
   are regarded as being based on falsified specimens of perciforms and
   therefore not valid. The percentage of acanthopterygian genera among the
   total number of teleost fish genera is traced through the better known
   Cenomanian to Pliocene teleost faunas of the Tethys and Paratethys. It
   was shown that acanthopterygians strongly predominate already in the
   earliest known Cenozoic fish assemblage, that of the late Paleocene of
   Turkmenistan. Comparative analysis of the stratigraphic distribution of
   fossil fish taxa based on otoliths only and on osteological material has
   led us to the conclusion that only the younger otoliths (Holocene to
   Miocene and, more questionably, Oligocene) can be confidently classified
   with the Recent taxa of generic and higher category. The systematics of
   Eocene to Cretaceous otoliths should be regarded as formal rather than
   natural. Some problems of classifying generalised fossil percoid fishes
   (Perciformes) are also discussed. In cases when various groups of
   Acanthopterygii are relatively well-represented in the fossil record, it
   becames possible to either trace evolutionary history of these groups or
   to draw data on both their extinct and extant representatives for the
   cladistic analysis of phylogenetic relationships. Examples of such
   groups are the families Zeidae (Zeiformes) and Carangidae (Perciformes),
   as well as the suborders Acanthuroidei and Scombroidei of the
   perciforms. A data set of 45 putatively informative morphological
   characters (mostly osteological, and a few external features) is
   analyzed for 12 extant and fossil species belonging to the buckler dory
   fish genera Zeus and Zenopsis, which together constitute the family
   Zeidae, and for two outgroup taxa (Santini et al., 2006). Both Zeus and
   Zenopsis date back to at least the Oligocene (36 MYA). The analysis of
   the full data set (extant + fossil) provides strong support for the
   monophyly of the Zeidae but only weak support for the monophyly of
   Zenopsis, and it calls into question the existence of a clade formed by
   the extant and fossil taxa assigned to Zeus. Additional cladistic
   analyses confirm a strongly supported clade formed by Zeus + Zenopsis
   and of a much less strongly supported clade formed by the extant and
   fossil species of Zenopsis. The analyses do not provide support for a
   clade formed by extant and fossil species previously assigned to the
   genus Zeus, even though when the fossil species are excluded from the
   analysis, the two extant species of Zeus appear as each other's sister
   groups in one of three equally parsimonious cladograms. Our
   non-cladistic phylogenetic analysis of the family Carangidae (Bannikov,
   1990a) led to recognizing of six subfamilies of horse mackerels
   (Seriolinae, Archaeinae, Vomeropsinae, Trachinotinae, Scomberoidinae and
   Caranginae), which are present as early as in the Eocene. It was
   proposed that the origin of carangids was connected to more generalised
   percoids, such as the Pomatomidae or their ancient relatives. Apolectids
   were regarded as a separate family closely related to the Carangidae.
   Modern research on the fossil acanthuroids (Bannikov, Tyler, 1995, 2002;
   Tyler, Bannikov, 1997, 2005) has resulted in the recognition of the
   superfamilies Luvaroidea and Zancloidea and the elucidation of the
   phylogenetic relationships of the fishes belonging to these
   superfamilies and to the family Siganidae. Incidentally, the phyletic
   sequence Siganidae [long dash] Luvaridae [long dash] Zanclidae [long
   dash] Acanthuridae proposed by Tyler et al. (1989) for extant
   acanthuroids remains unchanged. The suborder Scombroidei sensu stricto
   includes two superfamilies, Scombroidea and Trichiuroidea. The author
   does not support the idea of Johnson (1986) about sphyraenids as the
   most basal scombroids and billfishes as a terminal subgroup of the
   Scombridae. Both Sphyraenoidei and Xiphioidei are regarded here as
   separate suborders of perciforms. According to Bannikov (1985a), the
   family Scombridae can be subdivided into three subfamilies (Scombrinae,
   Scomberomorinae and Thunninae), distinguishable as early as the late
   Paleocene. The Scombrinae is the most basal subfamily of the scombrids.
PU GEOS
PA Moscow
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
BN 978-5-89118-504-3
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Documentation; Publications; General
   morphology; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

   [Eurasia / Central / distribution; stratigraphical distribution]

   Oliganodon [Oligocene /  / New genus].

   Serranus budensis - (Heckel 1856) (Serranidae): [Referred to, New genus

DT Article
TI The ammonoids from the Gres du Kahla superieur of Timimoun (Middle-Early
   Late Tournaisian; Gourara, Algeria).
AU Korn, Dieter (dieter.korn@mfn.berlin.de) 
   Ebbighausen, Volker
   Boeckwinkel, Juergen
SO Fossil Record
VL 13
IS 1
PS 13-34
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The ammonoids from two very prolific horizons in the upper Kahla
   Sandstone (Tournaisian, Early Carboniferous) of Timimoun (Gourara,
   Algeria) are described monographically. Nine new ammonoid species are
   introduced: Imitoceras altilobatum n. sp., Triimitoceras amplisellattum
   n. sp., Kazakhstania inequalis n. sp., Acrocanites imperfectus n. sp.,
   Xinjiangites scalaris n. sp., and Becanites canalifer n. sp. from the
   North African Kazakhstania-Acrocanites Assemblage as well as Acrocanites
   recurvus n. sp., Becanites singularis n. sp., and Becanites inflateralis
   n. sp. from the Pericyclus-Progoniatites Assemblage. The first of these
   is one of the most diverse ammonoid faunas known from this time
   interval.

TI The ammonoids from the Argiles de Teguentour of Oued Temertasset (early
   Late Tournaisian; Mouydir, Algeria).
AU Korn, Dieter (dieter.korn@mfn.berlin.de)

AB The ammonoids from the Teguentour Shales (Tournaisian, Early
   Carboniferous) of Oued Temertasset (Mouydir, Algeria) are described
   monographically. The following new ammonoid taxa arc introduced:
   Imitoceras dimidium n. sp., Imitoceras strictu"I n. sp., Triimitoceras
   tantulum n. sp., Acrocanites disparilis n. sp., Jdaidites cultellus n.
   sp., Pericyclus tortuosus n. sp., Pericyclus circulus n. sp., Pericyclus
   trochus n. sp., Pericyclus intercisus n. sp., Nodopericyclus n. gen.,
   Nodopericychlus circuninodosus n. sp., Nodopericyclus dcficerus n. sp.,
   Ammonellipsites serits n. sp., Helicoelyclus for mosus n. sp.,
   Helicocyclus inornatits n. sp., Helicocyclus laxaris it. sp.,
   Ouaouflialites creber n. sp., family Temertassetiidae n. fam.,
   Temertassetia n. gen., Temertassetia temertassetensis n. sp.,
   Temerlassetia sectinda n. sp., Temerfassetia decorata n. sp.,
   Temertassetia coarta n. sp., derania n. gen., Jerania jeranensis n. sp.,
   Jerania sicilicula n. sp., Jerania ptisillens n. sp., Jerania subvexa n.
   sp., Jerania persimilis n. sp., Kusinia n. gen., Kusinia fialcifera n.
   sp., Bolthamedites insulahensis n. sp., Muensteroceras subparallelum n.
   sp., Muensteroceras multitudum n. sp., Follotites n. gen., Follotites
   folloti n. sp., Follotites stehis n. sp., Follotites flextis n. sp,
   family Rotopericyclidae n. fam., Euriles permuttis n. sp., Eurites
   cloliaris n. sp., Mou.yclirici n. gen., Moulvdiria mouydirensis n. sp.,
   Mott ' y(firia scuttila n. sp., Rotopericyclus kaqj ianni n. sp.,
   Rotopericyclus rathi n. sp., Rotopericychis wendli n. sp.,
   RotoI)erielychis hibesecleri n. sp., subfamily Dzhaprakoceratinae n.
   subfarn., Dzhal)rakoceras punction n. sp., Dzhaprakoceras amphan n. sp.,
   Dzhaprakoceras vergum n. sp., Dzhal)rak-oceras biconvextim n. sp.,
   Progoniatitinae n. subfiam., Progoniatites uncus n. sp., Progoniatites
   pilus n. sp., Progoniatites paenacutus n. sp., Progoniatites globithis
   n. sp., Habadraitinae n. subfam., Habadrailes n. gen., Rabadraites
   weyeri n. sp., Habadraites supralatus n. sp., Priniogoniatites n. gen.,
   Primogon ia tiles findator n. sp., Antegoniatitinae n. subfam.,
   Antegoniatites n. gen., and Antegoniatites anticiparis n. sp.. The
   ammonoids occur in three successive assemblages and are the richest
   ammonoid faunas of the time interval worldwide.

PT J
AN ZOOR14608051744
DT Article
TI The ammonoids from the Dalle a Merocanites of Timimoun (Late
   Tournaisian- Early Visean; Gourara, Algeria).
AU Ebbighausen, Volker
   Korn, Dieter (dieter.korn@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Bockwinkel, Juergen
SO Fossil Record
VL 13
IS 1
PS 153-202
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The ammonoids from the Early Carboniferous (Mississippian) Dalle a
   Merocanites of Timimoun (Gourara, Algeria) are described. The following
   new ammonoid taxa are introduced: subfamily Flammatocyclinae n. subfam.,
   Hammatocyclus pollex n. sp., Hammatocyclus corrugatus n. sp.,
   Neopericyclus arenosus n. sp., Ammonellipsites pareyni n. sp.,
   Ammonellipsites menchikoffi! n. sp., Ammonellipsites conradae n. sp.,
   Muensteroceras fabrei n. sp., Eurites commutatus n. sp., Eurites pondus
   n. sp., subfamily Trimorphoccratinae n. subfam., Trimorphoceras n. gen,
   Trimorphoceras crassilens n. sp., Trimorphoceras absolutum n. sp.,
   Trimorphoceras molestum n. sp., Obturgites n. gen., Obturgites
   polysarcus n. sp., Obturgites oligosarcus n. sp., Dzhaprakoceras
   dzhazairense n. sp., and Merocanites nierocanites n. sp. These species
   occur in one very prolific horizon and can be attributed to the North
   African Ammonellipsites-Merocanites Assemblage
   (Fuscipericyclus-Ammonellipsites Genus Zone; Late Tournaisian to Early
   Visean). They represent one of the most diverse ammonoid faunas known
   from this time interval.
C1 Korn, Dieter; Museum Nat Kunde Berlin, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, Germany,
   Germany.
EM dieter.korn@mfn-berlin.de
RI Korn, Dieter/B-2963-2009

DT Article
TI Ammonoids from the Dalle des Iridet of the Mouydir and Ahnet (Central
   Sahara) and the Formation d'Hassi Sguilma of the Saoura Valley (Late
   Tournaisian-Early Visean; Algeria).
AU Korn, Dieter (dieter.korn@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Ebbighausen, Volker
   Bockwinkel, Juergen
SO Fossil Record
VL 13
IS 1
PS 203-214
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four ammonoid species are described from the Early Carboniferous
   (Mississippian) Iridet Formation of the Ahnet and Mouydir (Central
   Sahara, Algeria); three of which are new: Eurites temertassetensis n.
   sp., Trimorphoceras teguentourense n. sp., and Trimorphoceras
   azzelmattiense n. sp. The species can be attributed to the North African
   Ammonellipsites-Merocanites Assemblage (Fascipericyclus-Ammonellipsites
   Genus Zone; Late Tournaisian to Early Visean). Additionally, the two new
   species Ammonellipsites sguilmensis n. sp. and Muensteroceras
   beniabbesense it. sp. are described from the time equivalent Hassi
   Sguilma Formation of the Saoura Valley (north-western Algeria).
C1 Korn, Dieter; Museum Nat Kunde Berlin, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, Germany,
   Germany.
EM dieter.korn@mfn-berlin.de
RI Korn, Dieter/B-2963-2009
OI Korn, Dieter/0000-0003-1104-6939

   region; Africa; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   beniabbesense; Trimorphoceras azzelmattiense; Trimorphoceras
   teguentourense [Algeria /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
   Ammonoidea [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Algeria / Ahnet &
   Mouydir regions & Saoura Valley / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Carboniferous / Late Tournaisian-Early Visean / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Ammonellipsites sguilmensis (Goniatitida): [Sp nov, Algeria,
   Carboniferous, P. 205; Fossil]. 
   Eurites temertassetensis (Goniatitida): [Sp nov, Algeria, Carboniferous,
   P. 208; Fossil].

   Carboniferous, P. 207; Fossil].

   Carboniferous, P. 210; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14608051746
DT Article
TI The ammonoids from the Argiles de Timimoun of Timimoun (Early and Middle
   Visean; Gourara, Algeria).
AU Bockwinkel, Juergen (jbockwinkel@t-online.de) 
   Korn, Dieter
   Ebbighausen, Volker
SO Fossil Record
VL 13
IS 1
PS 215-278
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty-seven ammonoid species are described from the Argiles de Timimoun
   of Timimoun (Gourara, Algeria). The following taxa are newly described:
   Rhnetites n. gen., Rhnetites rhnetensis n. sp., Rhnetites
   ouladallalensis n. sp., Parahammatocyclus mutaris n. sp., Bollandoceras
   nitens n. sp., Bollandoceras subangulare n. sp., Bollandoceras politum
   n. sp., Bollandoceras aridum n. sp., Bollandoceras zuhara n. sp.,
   Bollandoceras mirrih n. sp., Benimehlalites n. gen., Benimehialites
   benimehlalensis n. sp., Benimehlalites belk-assemensis n. sp.,
   Benimehlalites brinkmanni n. sp., Pachybollandoceras n, gen.,
   Pachybollandocems intraevolutum n. sp., Pachybollandoceras repens n.
   sp., Bollanditinae n. subfam., Gourarites n. gen., Gourarites hagaraswad
   n. sp., Gourarites hagarkarim n. sp., Gourarites mustari n. sp.,
   Gourarites zuhal n. sp., Semibollandites n. gen., Semibollandites k-amil
   n. sp., Semibollandites paucidus n. sp., Semiibollandites qawiy n. sp.,
   Timiniounia n. gen., Timimounia timiniounensis n. sp., Timimounia hinida
   n. sp., Daaitidae n. fam., Daaites n. gen., Daaites daaensis n. sp.,
   Dimophoceras lanceolobatum n. sp., Nomismoceras salim? n. sp., and
   Nomismoceras waltoni n. sp. The species occur in three successive
   horizons and can be attributed to the Bollandites-Bollandoceras Genus
   Zone (Early and Middle Visean). They represent the most diverse ammonoid
   fauna known from this time interval.
C1 Bockwinkel, Juergen; Museum Nat Kunde Berlin, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin,
   Germany, Germany.
EM jbockwinkel@t-online.de
RI Korn, Dieter/B-2963-2009
OI Korn, Dieter/0000-0003-1104-6939

   time periods; Palaeozoic

   [Algeria /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  / ].

   Daaitidae [Carboniferous /  / New family].

PT J
AN ZOOR14701004783
DT Article
TI The first record of Late Jurassic crossognathiform fishes from Europe
   and their phylogenetic importance for teleostean phylogeny.
AU Arratia, Gloria (garratia@ku.edu) 
   Tischlinger, Helmut
SO Fossil Record
VL 13
IS 2
PS 317-341
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Late Jurassic Bavarichthys incognitus, n. gen. n. sp. from Ettling,
   Bavaria, is described. The new species represents the oldest record of a
   crossognathiform in Europe and together with Chongichthys from the
   Oxfordian of South America stands at the basal levels of a clade
   including crossognathids and pachyrhizodontoids. In addition, the new
   fish represents the first record of a crossognathiform in the Solnhofen
   Limestones. The new genus is characterized by numerous features such as
   the presence of infraorbitals 1-3 independent and 4 + 5 fused; two
   supramaxillary bones present; supramaxilla 2 considerably shorter than
   supramaxilla 1 and lacking an antero-dorsal process; well-developed
   series of epineural, epicentral and epipleural intermuscular bones;
   parhypural and hypurals 1 and 2 partially fused to each other; a series
   of epaxial basal fulcra; and a few, elongate fringing fulcra associated
   with the dorsal leading margin of caudal fin.
C1 Arratia, Gloria; Univ Kansas, Biodivers Res Ctr, Dyche Hall, Lawrence,
   KS, USA, USA.
EM garratia@ku.edu
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Bavarichthys [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Bavarichthys incognitus [Germany /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
   Crossognathiformes [Germany / Bavaria, Ettling / new record] [Jurassic /
   Late Jurassic / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii
OR Bavarichthys (Actinopterygii): [Gen nov, Of order Crossognathiformes,
   Type species Bavarichthys incognitus, p. 321, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Bavarichthys incognitus (Actinopterygii): [Sp nov, Germany, Jurassic, P.
   322; Fossil]. 
   Crossognathiformes (Actinopterygii): [Fossil; New record].

OA DOAJ Gold

AN ZOOR14605034928
DT Article
TI Mystifications of Knut Rognes in there taxonomy of the Bengaliidae
   family (Diptera).
FT Mystifications de Knut Rognes dans la taxonomie de la famille
   Bengaliidae (Diptera).
AU Lehrer, Andy Z. (azl_diptera@yahoo.fr) 
SO Fragmenta Dipterologica
VL 23
PS 1-22
PD Janvier 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB By the analysis of the mystified data and published by Rognes on the
   "Bengalia peuhi species-group" were proven the following synonyms and
   nomina dubia : Bengalia emarginata : Rognes 2009 is a junior synonyms of
   Afridigalia bezziella Lehrer, 2005 - n. syn. ; Bengalia emarginatoides
   Rognes 2009 is a junior synonyms of Afridigalia emarginata (Malloch,
   1927) - n. syn. ; Bengalia emdeniella (part. fanzideliana) : Rognes 2009
   is a junior synonyms of Afridigalia fanzideliana Lehrer, 2005 - n. syn.
   ; Bengalia inermis : Rognes 2009 is a junior synonyms of Afridigalia
   nusantara Lehrer, 2005 - n. syn. ; Bengalia latro : Rognes 2009 is a
   nomen falsum et dubium ; Bengalia lyneborgi : Rognes, 2009 is a junior
   synonyms of Afridigalia jamesi Lehrer, 2005 - n. syn. ; Bengalia taksina
   (part.) Rognes, 2009 is a junior synonyms of Afridigalia thaisia Lehrer,
   2008 - n. syn. ; Bengalia varicolor : Rognes, 2009 is a nomen dubium. It
   is proven that his "digital" photographs are not adequate for the
   scientific knowledge of the microstructures of the male genitalia and
   that the terminology, invented and used by Rognes is vulgar, confused,
   inappropriate and cannot replace the recognized scientific terminology.
   One established that the expression of "Bengalia peuhi species-group"
   sensu Rognes is a absurdity, ilogic formula and synonymous with the kind
   Afridigalia Lehrer 2005.
C1 Lehrer, Andy Z.; TAU - Zoologie, Sed. Hanasai 49/1, P.O.B. 7049, Maalot,
   Israel, Israel.
EM azl_diptera@yahoo.fr
SC Zoology

   position
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Calliphoridae
OR Afridigalia bezziella - Lehrer 2005 (Calliphoridae): [Synonymy, P. 5,
   Cited by author as syn nov]. 
   Afridigalia emarginata - (Malloch 1927) (Calliphoridae): [Syn nov,
   Bengalia emarginatoides Rognes 2009, p. 7].

   Cited by author as syn nov].

   (Calliphoridae): [Comb nov, Transferred from Bengalia, p. 16].

   Cited by author as syn nov].

DT Article
TI Diagnosis of Forcipomyia sahariensis Kieffer (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae)
   with the first description of immature stages.
AU Lewanczyk, Aleksandra (biorys@univ.gda.pl) 
   Szadiewski, Ryszard
   Dominiak, Patrycja
SO Fragmenta Faunistica (Warsaw)
VL 52
IS 2
PS 149-155
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Forcipomyia sahariensis Kieffer, 1923 is diagnosed in all stages. Larvae
   and pupae reared from rotting roots are described for the first time.
   Forcipomyia tuzeti Huttel et Huttel, 1952 from France and F.
   acanthophora Remm in Havelka, 1976 from Germany are recognized as new
   junior synonyms of F. sahariensis. A supplemented key for identification
   of known larvae and pupae of Polish species of the subgenus Forcipomyia
   s. str. is also provided.
C1 Lewanczyk, Aleksandra; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, University of
   Gdansk, Marszalka Pilsudskiego 46, 81-378 Gdynia, Poland, Poland.

TI ON THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF TELENOMUS HALIDAY OF THE BRACHIALIS AND
   TURESIS GROUPS (HYM. PLATYGASTROIDEA: SCELIONIDAE TELENOMINAE).
AU Mineo, Giovanni (gmineo35@libero.it) 
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 33
PS 51-69
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this note the brachialis and the turesis species groups of Telenomus
   Haliday are defined whose Palaearctic relative members yet known or new
   for the Science are discussed. For many species of these two natural
   associations are also known their hosts and that are belonging to the
   following pentatomoid genera: Aganoscelis, Antestia, Graphosoma, Nezara,
   Piezodorus, Raphigaster and Scotinophara. With regard to the species
   treated, some of their morphological aspects are also illustrated
   throughout the paper.

TI DESCRIPTION OF THAUMATODRYINUS SHARKEYI, NEW SPECIES OF DRYINIDAE FROM
   MALAYSIA (HYMENOPTERA: CHRYSIDOIDEA).
AU Olmi, Massimo (olmimassimo@gmail.com) 
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 33
PS 96-101
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Thaumatodryinus sharkeyi, new species of Dryinidae (Hymenoptera:
   Chrysidoidea), is described from Malaysia, Perlis. The new species is
   different from all other known world Thaumatodryinus because the
   enlarged claw has three subapical teeth and is not provided of lamellae,
   replaced by hairs.
C1 Olmi, Massimo; Via De Gasperi 10, Viterbo, I-01100, Italy, Italy.

PT J
AN ZOOR14912064221
DT Article
TI NEW HYMENOPTERA CHRYSIDIDAE FROM SOUTH WESTERN SAUDI ARABIA.
AU Stumia, Franco (strumia@df.unipi.it) 
   Dawah, Hassan
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 33
PS 171-179
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Hymenoptera fauna of the large Arabian region is of particular
   interest for its mixture of Palearctic and Afrotropical elements, in
   addition to a large number of endemic species. As a consequence of the
   territory vastness, even small samples usually give interesting results.
   About sixty specimens of Chrysididae captured with Malaise trap
   operating in the Asir Region (Saudi Arabia) are studied. They are
   attributed to 18 species, among which four new for Saudi Arabia
   (Cluysidea pumila Klug, 1845; Chrysis nilensis Linsenmaier, 1959;
   Holophris mochianus Strumia, 1995; Trichrysis longispina Mocsary, 1912).
   One species is considered new to science, Chrysis dawahi n. sp., and is
   described upon three females from Asir and one additional female from
   the United Arab Emirates.
C1 Stumia, Franco; Dipartimento Fis, Largo Pontecorvo 3, Pisa, I-56127,
   Italy, Italy.
EM strumia@df.unipi.it
SC Zoology
SN 0532-7679
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Chrysidea pumila; Chrysis nilensis; Holophris mochianus; Trichrysis
   longispina [Saudi Arabia /  / New record]. 
   Chrysididae [Saudi Arabia / Asir Region / Faunal list]. 
   Chrysis dawahi [Saudi Arabia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Chrysidoidea, Chrysididae
OR Chrysididae (Chrysidoidea). 
   Chrysidea pumila (Chrysididae): [New record]. 
   Chrysis dawahi - Strumia 2011 (Chrysididae): [Sp nov, Saudi Arabia, P.
   174]. 
   Chrysis nilensis (Chrysididae): [New record]. 
   Holophris mochianus (Chrysididae): [New record]. 
   Trichrysis longispina (Chrysididae): [New record].

   kawensis; Anteon holtsense, jacksoni, transkeianum, tschirnhausi and
   umtatense; Bocchinae: Bacchus turneri; Dryininae: Dryinus caledonianus,
   monteithi and robustus; Pseudodryinus piceus; Gonatopodinae: Gonatopus
   camerounensis, jacksoni, piceus and schierli; Neodryinus karaentensis;
   Apodryininae: Bocchopsis burwelli. The previously unknown males of
   Gonatopus autoxenobius (R. Perkins, 1907) and Gonatopus variabilis Olmi,
   1993, are described. The following new name is proposed: Janzeniola (on
   the place of Janzenia Olmi, 2000, preoccupied by Janzenia Marsh, 1993).
   The following new synonymy is proposed: Gonatopus mimus (R. Perkins,
   1907) = Gonatopus andersoni Olmi, 1995. A new host record for Gonatopus
   autoxenobius (R. Perkins) is presented: Stobaera concinna (Stal)
   (Delphacidae).
C1 Olmi, Massimo; Dipartimento di Protezione delle piante, Via S. Camillo
   de Lellis, Universita della Tuscia, Viterbo, Italy, Italy.
EM olmi@unitus.it

AB Dryinus velteni, a new fossil species of Dryinidae (Hymenoptera
   Chrysoidoidea), is described from Baltic amber. A new key to the

VL 32
IS 45
PS 101-110
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The bulk of the Mymaridae and Trichogrammatidae (Hymenoptera:
   Chalcidoidea) collected by S. Nowicki is preserved in the Dipartimento
   di Entomologia e Zoologia agraria "Filippo Silvestri", University degli
   Studi di Napoli "Federico II", Portici (NA). Information is given on the
   identified specimens. Of two species of Aphelinoidea described by S.
   Nowicki some morphological details arc illustrated.

DT Article
TI Dyscitobaeini: a new tribe of Scelionidae (Hymenoptera: Platygastroidea)
   with two new genera and a new species.
AU Mineo, Giovanni (gmineo35@libero.it) 
   O'Connor, James P.
   Ashe, Patrick
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 32
IS 45
PS 111-129
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Dyscritobaeini, a new tribe of Scelionidae (Hymenoptera:
   Platygastroidea), is erected. This taxon contains five genera viz.
   Cardalnaumannus gen.n., Dyscritobaeus Perkins, Mirotelenomus Dodd, Okapa
   Minco and Caleca, and Titta gen.n. A key is provided for their
   identification. In addition, Mirotelenomus incertus sp.n. is described
   from Australia and Titta Festiva (Kieffer) is reported new to the
   Democratic Republic of the Congo (Zaire).
C1 Mineo, Giovanni; Viale Michelangelo 200, 90145 Palermo, Italy, Italy.
EM gmineo35@libero.it

SN 0532-7679

   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Australasia; Australia

   Proctotrupoidea, Scelionidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14610069673
DT Article
TI A contribution to the knowledge of Dryinidae from the Oriental,
   Nearctic, Neotropical and Australian regions (Hymenoptera Chrysidoidea).
AU Olmi, Massimo
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 31
IS 44
PS 11-34
PD 2008(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following new species of Dryinidae are described: Aphelopinae:
   Aphelopus wushensis and indicus; Anteoninae: Deinodryinus broomfieldi
   and cooperi; Anteon dravidicum, catarinense and masneri; Bocchinae:
   Bocchus elegans; Dryininae: Dryinus darwinensis; Gonatopodinae:
   Gonatopus apensis; Neodryinus forestalis; Apodryininae: Bocchopsis
   cedarensis. The previously unknown female of Aphelopus spadiceus Xu &
   He, 1997, is described, together with the previously unknown male of
   Bocchus rubrithorax Olmi, 2005. The following new names are proposed:
   Dryinus dorsaloides (on the place of Dryinus (= Mesodryinus) dorsalis
   (Olmi, 1984), preoccupied by Dryinus dorsalis Nees, 1834); Gonatopus
   virginiensis (on the place of Gonatopus (= Plectrogonatopoides)
   nearcticus (Olmi, 1984) preoccupied by Gonatopus (= Pachygonatopus)
   nearcticus (Fenton, 1927)); Ponomarenkoa, new name for the genus
   Laherites N. Ponomarenko, 1988 (unvalid because N. Ponomarenko did not
   designate a type species (Art. 13 of International Code of Zoological
   Nomenclature) and because it is only a collective name including fossils
   (Art. 20 of International Code of Zoological Nomenclature));
   Ponomarenkoinae, new name for the subfamily Laberitinae Olmi, 1991
   (unvalid because based on Laberites N. Ponomarenko, an unvalid genus).
C1 Olmi, Massimo; Dipartimento di Protezione delle piante, Universita della
   Tuscia, Viterbo, Italy, Italy.

TI Descriptions of new species of Dryinidae and Embolemidae from Madagascar
   (Hymenoptera Chrysidoidea).
AU Olmi, Massimo
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 31
IS 44
PS 53-76
PD 2008(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following new species from Madagascar are described: Dryinidae:
   Conganteon fisheri; Deinodryinus pulcher and harinhalai and
   namorokensis; Anteon sublobatum and harinhalai; Gonatopus ruvidus,
   masoalensis, tulearensis and griswoldi. Embolemidae: Ampulicomorpha
   forestalis (present also in South Africa); Embolemus fisheri. The
   previously unknown male of Bocchus seyrigi (Benoit, 1953) is described.
   Changes to the keys to Afrotropical Conganteon, Deinodryinus, Anteon,
   Bocchus, Gonatopus, Ampulicomorpha and Embolemus are presented.

   Tuscia, Viterbo, Italy, Italy.

AN ZOOR14610069684
DT Article
TI A contribution to the knowledge of Dryinidae of Argentina: descriptions
   of the hitherto unknown males of Gonatopus argentinus Olmi and
   Trichogonatopus richardsi Olmi (Hymenoptera Chrysidoidea).
AU Virla, Eduardo
   Espinosa, Martin S.
   Olmi, Massimo
SO Frustula Entomologica
VL 31
IS 44
PS 125-134
PD 2008(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The males of Gonatopus argentinus Olmi and Trichogonatopus richardsi
   Olmi are described for the first time. In consequence of the discovery
   of its male, Gonatopus argentinus Olmi, 1986, in the past considered
   senior synonym of Gonatopus doellojuradoi (Ogloblin, 1938), is revalued
   and considered a good species. In consequence of the discovery of its
   male, Trichogonatopus richardsi Olmi is transferred from Trichogonatopus
   Kieffer, 1909, to Gonatopus Ljungh, 1810. Gonatopus richardsi (Olmi) new
   comb. is preoccupied by Plectrogonatopus (= Gonatopus) richardsi Moczar,
   1965, so that Gonatopus trichosoma new name is proposed for G. richardsi
   (Olmi). The hosts of both above species are discovered: Spangbergiella
   vulnerata (Uhler) (Cicadellidae Deltocephalinae) for G. argentinus;
   Curtara pagina DeLong & Freytag (Cicadellidae Gyponinae) and Mendozellus
   asunctia Cheng (Cicadellidae Deltocephalinae), for G. trichosoma.
C1 Virla, Eduardo; PROIMI-Biotecnologia (Biological Control division),
   CONICET, Av. Belgrano y Pje. Caseros, 4000, S.M. de Tucuman, Argentina,
   Argentina.
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0532-7679
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Combination; Available name;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Curtara pagina; Mendozellus asunctia [Hymenopteran parasites / Gonatopus
   richardsi / New record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Gonatopus argentinus [Hemipteran hosts / Spangbergiella vulnerata / New
   record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Gonatopus richardsi [Hemipteran hosts / Curtara pagina / New record] [ /
   Mendozellus asunctia / ] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Spangbergiella vulnerata [Hymenopteran parasites / Gonatopus argentinus
   / New record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Cicadelloidea, Cicadellidae, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Chrysidoidea, Dryinidae
OR Curtara pagina (Cicadellidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Mendozellus asunctia (Cicadellidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Spangbergiella vulnerata (Cicadellidae): [Host; New record].

   Male, p. 130; Comb nov, Transferred from Trichogonatopus, p. 132;
   Preoccupied name replaced by, Gonatopus trichosoma, p. 129; Parasite;
   New record].

   (Olmi 1984), p. 129].

PT J
AN ZOOR14801002019
DT Article
TI New neuropteran insects (Osmylidae, Palaeoleontidae, Araripeneuridae and
   Psychopsidae) from the Santana Formation, Early Cretaceous NE Brazil.
AU Martins-Neto, Rafael Gioia
   Rodrigues, Viviane Zeringota (vivianezr@yahoo.com.br) 
SO Gaea
VL 6
IS 1
PS 1-8
PD jan-jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper aims to present the results of a taxonomic study with the
   fossil Neuroptera from the Crato Member, Santana Formation, Lower
   Cretaceous from Araripe Basin, Ceara, Brazil. Based on these results, it
   is proposed the following new taxa: Nuddsia repatriata n. sp.
   (Osmylidae), Neurastenyx conani n. sp. (Palaeoleontidae), Diegopteryx
   raptorius n. gen. et n. sp. (Araripeneuridae, Cratopteryxinae n.
   subfam.), and Putzneura parcimoniosa n. gen. et n. sp. (Psychopsidae).
   The new taxa attests the success of the Neuroptera in equatorial areas
   of Gondawana during the end of Mesozoic, similar to that reached in
   Northern Hemisphere, which is valid mainly to the Psychopsidae from
   Brazil, that show big-size and conspicuous colour patterns, intense
   pubescence, and it is associated to other endemic forms.
C1 Rodrigues, Viviane Zeringota; Centro de Ensino Superior de Juiz de Fora
   - CES/JF, Programa de Pos-graduacao em Biologia, Universidade Federal de
   Juiz de Fora - UFJF, Campus Universitario Martelos, 36036-900, Juiz de
   Fora, MG, Brazil, Brazil.
EM vivianezr@yahoo.com.br

PT J
AN ZOOR14801002020
DT Article
TI New Blattoptera from Early Cretaceous of Santana Formation (Araripe
   Basin, NE Brazil) and a review of Arariplebatta Mendes, 2000.
AU Martins-Neto, Rafael Gioia
   Assis, Cynthia de Olveira (cynthia.assis@gmail.com) 
   Tassi, Lara Vaz
SO Gaea
VL 6
IS 1
PS 9-13
PD jan-jun 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Arariplebatta Mendes is here reviewed taking into account its previous
   diagnosis in Portuguese, the proposal of a new species, A. cesi, and an
   emended diagnosis of Blattulopsis beckeri Mendes. To include the genus
   and the new related forms the new family Araripeblattidae is presented
   and Elisama americana Vrsansky is considered a synonym of Araripeblatta
   brevis Mendes. Those Blattoptera came from the same laminated limestones
   from the basal part of Santana Formation, Ceara State, Northeast Brazil,
   Late Aptian in age, where the original samples were collected.
C1 Assis, Cynthia de Olveira; Centro de Ensino Superior de Juiz de Fora,
   Rua Dr. Constantino Paleta, 100/202 Centro, 36.015-450, Juiz de Fora,
   MG, Brazil, Brazil.
EM cynthia.assis@gmail.com

PT J
AN ZOOR14709066855
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Distribution, relative abundance and habitat use by mountain ungulates
   in Prek Chu catchment, Khangchendzonga Biosphere Reserve, Sikkim, India.
AU Bhattacharya, Tapajit
   Bashir, Tawqir
   Poudyal, Kamal
   Sathyakumar, Sambandam (ssk@wii.gov.in) 
   Bisht, Shikha
   Saha, Goutam Kumar
SO Galemys
VL 22
SU (Numero Especial)
PS 149-170
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We assessed the distribution patterns and relative abundance of mountain
   ungulates in Prek Chu catchment of Khangchendzonga Biosphere Reserve
   (BR) during 2008-2009 by sampling trails/transects, vantage points and
   using camera traps. Presence of goral (Naemorhaedus goral), barking deer
   (Muntiacus muntjac), serow (Naemorhaedus sumatraensis), musk deer
   (Moschus sp.) and blue sheep (Pseudois nayaur) was confirmed through
   direct and indirect evidence. Presence of Himalayan tahr (Hemitragus
   jemlahicus) was confirmed only through camera traps. Blue sheep herds
   were readily detectable (n= 31) with the highest detection probability.
   Photo capture rate of goral (n= 156) was the highest. Differential use
   of elevation categories along with vegetation categories depicted blue
   sheep and musk deer as specialists for areas at (Krummholtz zone) and
   above treeline (>4000 m); and barking deer as specialist for lower
   elevation (>2500 m) wet temperate forested habitats. Goral and serow
   were generalists as they used all the forested areas of low altitude
   (<2000 m) subtropical forest, medium altitude (2000-3000 m) wet
   temperate forest and subalpine forests (3000-4000 m). Livestock grazing
   and pack animal presence in the study area along with garbage
   accumulation due to tourism are the main concerns for degradation of
   mountain ungulate habitats in Prek Chu catchment.
C1 Sathyakumar, Sambandam; Wildlife Institute of India, P.O. Box 18,
   Chandrabani, Dehradun-248 001, Uttarakhand, India, India.
EM ssk@wii.gov.in
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1137-8700
BD Ecology; Community structure; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Hemitragus jemlahicus; Moschus; Muntiacus muntjac; Naemorhaedus goral;
   Naemorhaedus sumatraensis; Pseudois nayaur [Relative abundance /  / ]
   [Habitat utilization /  / ] [Mountain habitat /  / distribution] [Sikkim
   / Khangchendzonga Biosphere Reserve, Prek Chu catchment / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Bovidae,
   Cervidae
OR Hemitragus jemlahicus (Bovidae). 
   Naemorhaedus goral (Bovidae). 
   Naemorhaedus sumatraensis (Bovidae). 
   Pseudois nayaur (Bovidae). 
   Moschus (Cervidae). 
   Muntiacus muntjac (Cervidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709066855

PT J
AN ZOOR14709066891
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Habitat use and food habits of Kashmir red deer or hangul (Cervus
   elaphus hanglu) at Dachigam National Park, Kashmir, India.
AU Sharma, Lalit Kumar
   Charoo, Samina Amin
   Sathyakumar, Sambandam (ssk@wii.gov.in) 
SO Galemys
VL 22
SU (Numero Especial)
PS 309-329
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We investigated the habitat use and food habits of Kashmir Red deer or
   Hangul (Cervus elaphus hanglu) at Dachigam National Park, Kashmir,
   India, from April 2007 to June 2009. We characterized Hangul habitats
   based on vegetation plots (n= 98) along 13 transects / trails that
   systematically covered Lower Dachigam (ca. 90 km2), our intensive study
   area. We classified five Hangul habitats viz., Riverine (1,600-1,900 m),
   Lower Temperate Mixed (Celtis australis, Morus alba, Aesculus indica,
   Juglans regia and Parrotiopsis jacquemontiana, 1,800-2,200 m), Lower
   Temperate Pine Mixed (Pinus wallichiana and others, 1,800-2,400 m), Mid
   Temperate Mixed (Ulmus wallichana, C. australis, A. indica and P.
   jacquemontiana, 2,300-2,600 m), and Temperate Grassland and Scrubland
   (Parrotiopsis jacquemontiana, Themeda anethra, 1,900-2,900 m). We
   recorded 404 visual encounters and signs of Hangul and found that the
   habitat use was significantly different across seasons ([chi]2= 32.33
   df= 4, P< 0.001). Maximum number of sightings and evidences (39%) were
   recorded in Temperate grassland/scrub habitat followed by Riverine (26%)
   and Lower Temperate pine mixed (9%). Temperate grassland/scrub habitat
   was used more than its availability (0.36 <= P <= 0.487) in all seasons.
   Based on 404 Hangul use plots and 121 available plots, we found that
   there was a significant difference in the use of elevation zones by
   Hangul between seasons ([chi]2= 12, df= 12, P< 0.01). In spring, Hangul
   used the elevation categories 1,901-2,100 m (0.123 <= P<=0.321) and
   2,101-2,300 m (0.245 <=p <= 0.473) more than availability. In summer and
   autumn, maximum proportion of sightings and signs were recorded in the
   elevation ranges 1,901-2,100 m and 2,101-2,300 m and in winter Hangul
   used valley areas with elevation category of 1,700-1,900 m more than its
   availability (0.521 <= P <= 0.766). Most (40%) of the sightings and
   signs were recorded in Eastern aspect and Hangul use of aspect differed
   significantly ([chi]2= 96.33, df= 18, P= 0.00) in different seasons.
   Slope use by Hangul have differed significantly (ch2= 25.09, df= 9, P=
   0.003) and the maximum percentage of sightings and signs (37%) were
   recorded in slope category of 10[degree]-20[degree]. Based on dung
   analysis (n= 67) and direct feeding observations (n= 38), we found a
   seasonal variation in diet composition of Hangul and it was mostly
   composed of Grass/herbs (60%) in summer, forbs/fern (46.66%) in spring
   and autumn, and bark of trees (57%) mostly Salix alba during winter.
   Twenty food plant species were observed in the diet of Hangul. Some of
   these include: Berberis sp., Geranium sp., Aesculus indica, Poa annua,
   Rumax nepalensis, Hedera nepalensis, Smilax vaginata, and Rosa sp.
C1 Sathyakumar, Sambandam; Wildlife Institute of India, P.O. Box 18,
   Chandrabani, Dehradun-248 001, Uttarakhand, India, India.
EM ssk@wii.gov.in
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1137-8700
BD Nutrition; Diet; Ecology; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   India
DE Cervus elaphus hanglu [Food plants /  / Diet composition] [Habitat
   utilization /  / ] [Jammu and Kashmir / Kashmir, Dachigam National Park
   / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Cervidae
OR Cervus elaphus hanglu (Cervidae).

DT Article
TI Phylogeny of the genus Psilaspilates (Butler 1893) (Lepidoptera:
   Geometridae) and description of a new species for Fray Jorge relict
   forest, Chile.
FT Filogenia del genero Psilaspilates (Butler 1893) (Lepidoptera:
   Geometridae) con la descripcion de una nueva especie del bosque relicto
   Fray Jorge, Chile.
AU Parra, Luis E. (luparra@udec.cl) 
   Villagran-Mella, Romina
   Hernandez, Esteban A.
   Hernandez, Cristian E.
SO Gayana
VL 74
IS 2
PS 94-101
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Psilaspilates Butler 1893, P. septentrionalis Parra sp.
   nov., from the relict coastal forest of Aextoxicon punctatum R. et P.
   (olivillo) from the Parque Nacional Fray Jorge, Region de Coquimbo,
   Chile, is described. Previously kwon species of Psilaspilates distribute
   in the central-south of Chile; therefore, P. septentrionalis sp. nov. is
   the only species distributed in the northern Chile. Subsequently, the
   phylogeny of Psilaspilates was inferred using two approximations,
   maximum parsimony and Bayesian inference. The sister species of the new
   species, P. concepcionensis y P. stygiana, distribute in
   central-southern Chile, in coastal forest where olivillo is also
   present. We suggest that the ancestor of these three species was widely
   distributed in coastal olivillo forest, and that during the Last Glacial
   Maximum its populations become isolated and speciation occurs.
C1 Parra, Luis E.; Departamento de Zoologia, Universidad de Concepcion,
   Casilla 160-C, Concepcion, Chile, Chile.
EM luparra@udec.cl
RI Hernandez, Cristian E./AAS-1286-2020; Hernandez, Cristian/C-4414-2012;
   Parra, Luis/Q-6707-2019
OI Hernandez, Cristian E./0000-0002-9811-2881; 
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0717-652X

   region; South America

   Chile, P. 97].

TI A new species of Telmatobufo (Schmidt 1852) (Anura,
   Calyptocephalellidae) from a remnant of the Maulino Forest, central
   Chile.
AU Cuevas, Cesar C. (ccuevas@uach.cl) 
SO Gayana
VL 74
IS 2
PS 102-112
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species, Telmatobufo ignotus, from the Reserva Nacional Los
   Queules, Cauquenes Province, central Chile is described herein. The new
   taxon is hypothesized based on a new combination of adult, larval, and
   chromosomal characters. The new species present the more septentrional
   distribution on the coastal range and a very restrictive distribution
   area compared to its congeners; because of this, taxonomic and
   conservation comments are discussed and advanced.
C1 Cuevas, Cesar C.; Instituto de Zoologia, Facultad de Ciencias,
   Universidad Austral de Chile, Casilla 567, Valdivia, Chile, Chile.

TI Cephenniini of the Philippines. Part 3. New species of Cephennomicrus

   provided. Notes on the location of types of some Indian Mantodea are
   given.

PT J
